Water is often called the universal solvent.", "urdu_meaning": "محلل / حل کنندہ - وہ مادہ جو دوسرے مادوں (حل شونده) کو اپنے اندر حل کر کے محلول بناتا ہے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "In a saltwater solution, water acts as the solvent and salt is the solute.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Substance that dissolves a solute to form a solution.", "related_concepts": ["solute", "solution", "solubility", "polarity", "aqueous solution", "organic solvent"], "real_world_example": "Water dissolving sugar for a sweet drink."}}

{"explanation": "In thermodynamics, the surroundings refer to everything in the universe external to the chemical system being studied. Energy and matter can be exchanged between the system and its surroundings.", "urdu_meaning": "ماحول / اطراف - کیمیائی نظام کے باہر کائنات کا باقی تمام حصہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "For an exothermic reaction, heat is released from the system to its surroundings.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Everything outside the defined chemical system.", "related_concepts": ["chemical system", "boundary", "universe", "energy transfer", "heat flow"], "real_world_example": "The air and the beaker containing a reacting solution are part of the surroundings."}}

{"explanation": "Table salt is a common crystalline ionic compound, primarily sodium chloride (NaCl), used widely as a food seasoning and preservative.", "urdu_meaning": "کھانے کا نمک - بنیادی طور پر سوڈیم کلورائیڈ (NaCl) پر مشتمل عام استعمال کا نمک", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "Dissolving table salt in water creates an electrolyte solution capable of conducting electricity.", "properties": {"formula": "NaCl", "molar_mass": "58.44 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "solid", "hazards": ["Generally safe in normal consumption", "High intake can cause health issues"]}}

{"explanation": "Thermodynamics is the branch of physics and chemistry that deals with heat and its relation to other forms of energy and work. It describes how energy is transformed in physical and chemical processes.", "urdu_meaning": "حر حرکیات / تھرمو ڈائنامکس - حرارت اور توانائی کی دیگر اقسام اور کام کے مابین تعلق کا علم", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The laws of thermodynamics govern the feasibility and energy changes of chemical reactions.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Study of energy transformations and their relation to macroscopic properties.", "related_concepts": ["energy", "heat", "work", "enthalpy", "entropy", "Gibbs free energy", "laws of thermodynamics"], "real_world_example": "Designing efficient engines or power plants."}}

{"explanation": "Water is a polar inorganic compound with the chemical formula H₂O, essential for all known forms of life and existing as a liquid at standard temperature and pressure.", "urdu_meaning": "پانی - ایک قطبی غیر نامیاتی مرکب (H₂O) جو تمام معلوم زندگی کے لیے ضروری ہے", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "The unique properties of water, such as its high specific heat capacity, are crucial for regulating Earth's climate.", "properties": {"formula": "H₂O", "molar_mass": "18.015 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "liquid", "hazards": ["Generally safe", "Drowning hazard", "Can cause scalding if hot"]}}

{"explanation": "Baking soda, chemically known as sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO₃), is a white crystalline powder commonly used as a leavening agent in baking and as a mild alkali.", "urdu_meaning": "بیکنگ سوڈا / میٹھا سوڈا - سوڈیم بائی کاربونیٹ (NaHCO₃)، جو بیکنگ میں استعمال ہوتا ہے", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "When baking soda reacts with an acid, it produces carbon dioxide gas, which causes dough to rise.", "properties": {"formula": "NaHCO₃", "molar_mass": "84.007 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "solid", "hazards": ["Generally safe", "Large ingestions can cause electrolyte imbalance"]}}

{"explanation": "The bank account analogy is often used in thermochemistry to explain energy changes, where energy input is like a deposit (endothermic) and energy output is like a withdrawal (exothermic). The overall change in the account balance represents the net energy change of the system.", "urdu_meaning": "بینک اکاؤنٹ کی مثال - اینتھالپی/توانائی کی تبدیلیوں کو سمجھانے کے لیے استعمال ہونے والی تشبیہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Using the bank account analogy, an exothermic reaction is like making a withdrawal from the system's energy account, decreasing its balance.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A model to visualize energy deposits (endothermic) and withdrawals (exothermic) in a chemical system.", "related_concepts": ["enthalpy change", "endothermic reaction", "exothermic reaction", "energy conservation"], "real_world_example": "Explaining that if more energy is released (withdrawal) than absorbed (deposit), the overall reaction is exothermic (net decrease in account balance)."}}

{"explanation": "Bond energy, or bond enthalpy, is the measure of bond strength in a chemical bond, defined as the average energy required to break one mole of a specific type of bond in the gas phase.", "urdu_meaning": "بانڈ توانائی / بندھنی توانائی - کیمیائی بانڈ میں بندھن کی مضبوطی کا پیمانہ", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "Calculating the enthalpy change of a reaction can be approximated using average bond energies of reactants and products.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Energy required to break a chemical bond or released when a bond is formed.", "related_concepts": ["enthalpy change", "bond breaking (endothermic)", "bond formation (exothermic)", "Hess's Law"], "real_world_example": "The high bond energy of the N≡N triple bond in nitrogen gas makes it relatively unreactive."}}

{"explanation": "Chemical bonding refers to the attractive forces that hold atoms together to form molecules or compounds, resulting from the electrostatic attraction between opposite charges.", "urdu_meaning": "بندھن / کیمیائی بندھن - وہ قوتیں جو ایٹموں کو مالیکیول یا مرکب بنانے کے لیے جوڑ کر رکھتی ہیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Covalent bonding involves the sharing of electrons between atoms.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Attractive forces holding atoms together in molecules and compounds.", "related_concepts": ["ionic bond", "covalent bond", "metallic bond", "bond energy", "molecular structure", "electronegativity"], "real_world_example": "The formation of a water molecule (H₂O) involves covalent bonding between oxygen and hydrogen atoms."}}

{"explanation": "Carbon is a chemical element with symbol C and atomic number 6, known for its ability to form a vast number of compounds due to its tetravalency. It is the basis of organic chemistry.", "urdu_meaning": "کاربن - کیمیائی عنصر (علامت C، ایٹمی نمبر 6)، نامیاتی کیمیا کی بنیاد", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "Carbon atoms can form single, double, or triple bonds with other carbon atoms, leading to diverse molecular structures.", "properties": {"symbol": "C", "atomic_number": 6, "category": "nonmetal", "state_room_temp": "solid", "common_uses": ["Graphite (pencils, lubricants)", "Diamond (jewelry, cutting tools)", "Component of fuels (coal, oil, gas)", "Basis of all organic life"]}}

{"explanation": "Chemical energetics, also known as thermochemistry, is the study of energy changes that accompany chemical reactions and physical transformations. It primarily deals with enthalpy, entropy, and Gibbs free energy.", "urdu_meaning": "کیمیائی توانائیات / حر کیمیا - کیمیائی تعاملات اور طبعی تبدیلیوں کے ساتھ توانائی کی تبدیلیوں کا مطالعہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Chemical energetics helps predict whether a reaction will be spontaneous and how much heat it will release or absorb.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Study of energy changes in chemical processes.", "related_concepts": ["enthalpy", "entropy", "Gibbs free energy", "exothermic reaction", "endothermic reaction", "Hess's Law", "bond energy"], "real_world_example": "Determining the energy content of fuels or the efficiency of a chemical process."}}

{"explanation": "A chemical reaction is a process that involves rearrangement of the molecular or ionic structure of a substance, as opposed to a change in physical form or a nuclear reaction, resulting in the formation of new substances (products).", "urdu_meaning": "کیمیائی تعامل - ایسا عمل جس میں مادے کی سالماتی یا آئنی ساخت میں تبدیلی سے نئے مادے بنتے ہیں", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "The rusting of iron is a chemical reaction between iron, oxygen, and water.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Transformation of reactants into products through the breaking and forming of chemical bonds.", "related_concepts": ["reactants", "products", "stoichiometry", "reaction rate", "activation energy", "enthalpy change"], "real_world_example": "Photosynthesis in plants converting CO₂ and water into glucose and oxygen."}}

{"explanation": "A chemical system is a specific part of the universe that is under study, separated from its surroundings by a real or imaginary boundary, where chemical reactions or physical changes occur.", "urdu_meaning": "کیمیائی نظام - کائنات کا وہ مخصوص حصہ جس کا کیمیائی مطالعہ کیا جا رہا ہو", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "In thermochemistry, a beaker containing reactants is considered the chemical system, and the heat exchanged with the lab environment (surroundings) is measured.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A defined region where chemical processes are observed and measured.", "related_concepts": ["surroundings", "boundary", "open system", "closed system", "isolated system", "thermodynamics"], "real_world_example": "A battery undergoing discharge is a chemical system converting chemical energy to electrical energy."}}

{"explanation": "Combustion is a high-temperature exothermic chemical process involving rapid reaction between a substance (fuel) and an oxidant, usually oxygen, to produce heat and light.", "urdu_meaning": "احتراق - ایندھن اور آکسیڈنٹ کے درمیان تیز حرارت زا کیمیائی تعامل", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "The complete combustion of hydrocarbons yields carbon dioxide and water.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Rapid oxidation reaction releasing heat and light.", "related_concepts": ["exothermic reaction", "fuel", "oxidant", "flame", "activation energy", "hydrocarbons"], "real_world_example": "Burning natural gas (methane) in a stove for cooking."}}

{"explanation": "Combustion reactions are exothermic chemical reactions, typically involving a fuel reacting rapidly with an oxidant (like oxygen) to produce heat, light, and oxidized products.", "urdu_meaning": "احتراقی تعاملات - حرارت زا کیمیائی تعاملات جن میں ایندھن آکسیڈنٹ کے ساتھ تیزی سے عمل کرتا ہے", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "The study of combustion reactions is crucial for understanding engine efficiency and fire safety.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A class of rapid oxidation reactions that are highly exothermic.", "related_concepts": ["combustion", "exothermic", "fuel", "oxidant", "enthalpy of combustion", "complete combustion", "incomplete combustion"], "real_world_example": "The burning of propane in a BBQ grill."}}

{"explanation": "Constant pressure refers to a condition in a thermodynamic process where the pressure of the system remains unchanged throughout the process. Enthalpy change (ΔH) is specifically defined as the heat exchanged at constant pressure.", "urdu_meaning": "مستقل دباؤ - ایسا تھرمو ڈائنامک عمل جس میں نظام کا دباؤ تبدیل نہ ہو", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Many chemical reactions in open containers occur at constant pressure, allowing direct measurement of enthalpy change.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A thermodynamic state where pressure does not vary.", "related_concepts": ["enthalpy (ΔH)", "calorimetry", "isobaric process", "thermodynamics"], "real_world_example": "A reaction carried out in an open beaker on a lab bench is essentially at constant atmospheric pressure."}}

{"explanation": "Endothermic reactions are chemical reactions that absorb heat energy from their surroundings, causing the temperature of the surroundings to decrease and the enthalpy of the system to increase (ΔH > 0).", "urdu_meaning": "حرارت گیر تعاملات - کیمیائی تعاملات جو اپنے ماحول سے حرارت جذب کرتے ہیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The dissolution of ammonium nitrate in water is an endothermic reaction used in instant cold packs.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Chemical reactions where heat is absorbed by the system (ΔH is positive).", "related_concepts": ["endothermic", "exothermic reactions", "enthalpy change", "activation energy", "bond breaking"], "real_world_example": "Photosynthesis, where plants absorb light energy to convert CO₂ and water into glucose."}}

{"explanation": "Energy is the capacity to do work or produce heat, existing in various forms such as kinetic, potential, thermal, chemical, and nuclear energy. It is a fundamental conserved quantity in physics and chemistry.", "urdu_meaning": "توانائی - کام کرنے یا حرارت پیدا کرنے کی صلاحیت", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "Chemical reactions involve the transformation of chemical energy into other forms of energy, like heat or light.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The capacity to perform work or transfer heat.", "related_concepts": ["kinetic energy", "potential energy", "thermal energy", "chemical energy", "energy conservation", "work", "heat"], "real_world_example": "The food we eat contains chemical energy that our bodies convert to perform activities."}}

{"explanation": "Energy absorbed refers to the quantity of energy taken in by a system from its surroundings during a process, such as an endothermic chemical reaction or the heating of a substance.", "urdu_meaning": "جذب شدہ توانائی - کسی نظام کی طرف سے ماحول سے لی گئی توانائی کی مقدار", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "In an endothermic reaction, the energy absorbed to break bonds is greater than the energy released when new bonds form.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Energy taken into a system from its surroundings.", "related_concepts": ["endothermic reaction", "heat", "enthalpy change (positive ΔH)", "activation energy", "bond breaking"], "real_world_example": "Ice absorbs energy from the surroundings as it melts."}}

{"explanation": "An "energy account" is a conceptual way to track the energy changes in a chemical system, where inputs (energy absorbed) and outputs (energy released) affect the overall energy balance.", "urdu_meaning": "توانائی کا کھاتہ - کیمیائی نظام میں توانائی کی تبدیلیوں کا حساب رکھنے کا تصوراتی طریقہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "An endothermic reaction results in a net increase in the system's energy account.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A model for tracking energy inputs and outputs in a system.", "related_concepts": ["bank account analogy", "enthalpy", "energy absorbed", "energy released", "endothermic", "exothermic"], "real_world_example": "If a system's energy account increases, it means it underwent an endothermic process."}}

{"explanation": "Energy released refers to the quantity of energy given off by a system to its surroundings during a process, such as an exothermic chemical reaction or the cooling of a substance.", "urdu_meaning": "خارج شدہ توانائی - کسی نظام کی طرف سے ماحول کو دی گئی توانائی کی مقدار", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "In an exothermic reaction, energy released during bond formation is greater than the energy absorbed during bond breaking.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Energy given out by a system to its surroundings.", "related_concepts": ["exothermic reaction", "heat", "enthalpy change (negative ΔH)", "combustion", "bond formation"], "real_world_example": "A burning candle releases energy in the form of heat and light."}}

{"explanation": "Enthalpy (H) is a thermodynamic property of a system, representing the total heat content. Enthalpy change (ΔH) is the heat absorbed or released during a process at constant pressure.", "urdu_meaning": "اینتھالپی - کسی نظام کی کل حرارتی مقدار، ایک تھرمو ڈائنامک خاصیت", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The enthalpy of products is lower than the enthalpy of reactants in an exothermic reaction.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Total heat content of a system (H = U + PV).", "related_concepts": ["enthalpy change (ΔH)", "endothermic reaction", "exothermic reaction", "Hess's Law", "standard enthalpy of formation", "thermodynamics"], "real_world_example": "The specific enthalpy of steam is an important parameter in power generation."}}

{"explanation": "Enthalpy change (ΔH) represents the heat absorbed or released by a chemical system during a process occurring at constant pressure. A negative ΔH indicates an exothermic reaction, while a positive ΔH indicates an endothermic reaction.", "urdu_meaning": "اینتھالپی میں تبدیلی (ΔH) - مستقل دباؤ پر کیمیائی نظام میں جذب یا خارج ہونے والی حرارت", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The enthalpy change for the combustion of glucose is a large negative value, indicating a significant release of energy.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Measure of heat exchanged at constant pressure during a chemical or physical process.", "related_concepts": ["enthalpy", "exothermic reaction", "endothermic reaction", "standard enthalpy of reaction", "Hess's Law", "calorimetry"], "real_world_example": "The enthalpy change of fusion for water is +6.01 kJ/mol, meaning 6.01 kJ of heat is absorbed when one mole of ice melts."}}

{"explanation": "Enthalpy changes refer to the various amounts of heat absorbed or released in different chemical reactions or physical processes occurring at constant pressure.", "urdu_meaning": "اینتھالپی کی تبدیلیاں - مختلف کیمیائی تعاملات یا طبعی تبدیلیوں میں جذب یا خارج ہونے والی حرارت کی مقداریں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "We can use Hess's Law to calculate enthalpy changes for reactions that are difficult to measure directly.", "properties": {"key_principle": "General term for heat exchanges at constant pressure in various processes.", "related_concepts": ["enthalpy change (ΔH)", "standard enthalpy of formation", "standard enthalpy of combustion", "standard enthalpy of neutralization", "Hess's Law"], "real_world_example": "Comparing the enthalpy changes of combustion for different fuels to determine their energy efficiency."}}

{"explanation": "Enthalpy levels refer to the relative heat content of reactants and products in a chemical reaction, often depicted in an enthalpy level diagram (or energy profile diagram).", "urdu_meaning": "اینتھالپی کی سطحیں - کیمیائی تعامل میں متعاملات اور حاصلات کی نسبتی حرارتی مقداریں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "In an exothermic reaction, the enthalpy level of the products is lower than that of the reactants.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Relative heat content values for substances in a chemical process.", "related_concepts": ["enthalpy profile diagram", "enthalpy change", "reactants", "products", "activation energy", "exothermic", "endothermic"], "real_world_example": "An enthalpy level diagram visually shows whether a reaction is exothermic or endothermic by comparing the initial and final enthalpy levels."}}

{"explanation": "An exothermic reaction is a chemical reaction that releases energy to its surroundings, typically as heat, resulting in a decrease in the enthalpy of the system (ΔH < 0).", "urdu_meaning": "حرارت زا تعامل - ایسا کیمیائی تعامل جو اپنے ماحول میں حرارت خارج کرتا ہے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The neutralization reaction between a strong acid and a strong base is a highly exothermic reaction.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Chemical reaction where heat is released by the system (ΔH is negative).", "related_concepts": ["exothermic", "endothermic reaction", "enthalpy change", "combustion", "bond formation"], "real_world_example": "Self-heating coffee cans utilize an exothermic reaction to warm the beverage."}}

{"explanation": "Exothermic reactions are chemical processes that liberate energy, usually in the form of heat, to their surroundings, leading to a net decrease in the system's enthalpy.", "urdu_meaning": "حرارت زا تعاملات - کیمیائی عمل جو اپنے ماحول میں حرارت خارج کرتے ہیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Many spontaneous reactions are exothermic reactions because they lead to a more stable, lower energy state.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Class of chemical reactions releasing energy (negative ΔH).", "related_concepts": ["exothermic", "enthalpy change", "combustion", "respiration", "neutralization"], "real_world_example": "Burning fuel in engines and power plants are examples of exothermic reactions."}}

{"explanation": "Gas is one of the fundamental states of matter, characterized by particles that have neither a fixed volume nor a fixed shape, and that move rapidly and randomly.", "urdu_meaning": "گیس - مادے کی ایک حالت جس میں ذرات کا نہ کوئی معین حجم ہوتا ہے اور نہ ہی شکل", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Oxygen is a gas at room temperature and is essential for respiration.", "properties": {"key_principle": "State of matter with no fixed shape or volume, particles are far apart and move randomly.", "related_concepts": ["solid", "liquid", "plasma", "ideal gas law", "kinetic theory of gases", "pressure", "volume", "temperature"], "real_world_example": "Air, which is a mixture of gases like nitrogen and oxygen."}}

{"explanation": "Heat energy is the transfer of thermal energy between systems or objects due to a temperature difference. It flows from a hotter body to a colder body.", "urdu_meaning": "حرارتی توانائی / حرارت - درجہ حرارت کے فرق کی وجہ سے نظاموں کے درمیان منتقل ہونے والی تھرمل توانائی", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "During an exothermic reaction, chemical energy is converted into heat energy and released to the surroundings.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Energy transferred due to temperature difference.", "related_concepts": ["thermal energy", "temperature", "conduction", "convection", "radiation", "enthalpy", "specific heat capacity"], "real_world_example": "Heat energy from the sun warms the Earth."}}

{"explanation": "Heat transferred (q) is the amount of thermal energy that moves from a hotter system or object to a colder one. In chemical reactions at constant pressure, this is equal to the enthalpy change (ΔH).", "urdu_meaning": "منتقل شدہ حرارت - ایک نظام سے دوسرے نظام میں درجہ حرارت کے فرق کی وجہ سے منتقل ہونے والی تھرمل توانائی کی مقدار", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The heat transferred in a reaction can be measured using a calorimeter.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The quantity of thermal energy exchanged between a system and its surroundings.", "related_concepts": ["heat (q)", "enthalpy change (ΔH at constant P)", "calorimetry", "specific heat capacity", "endothermic", "exothermic"], "real_world_example": "Measuring the temperature change of water in a calorimeter allows calculation of the heat transferred from a reacting substance."}}

{"explanation": "Hess's Law states that the total enthalpy change for a chemical reaction is the same, regardless of whether the reaction occurs in one step or in a series of steps. It allows for the calculation of enthalpy changes for reactions that cannot be measured directly.", "urdu_meaning": "ہیس کا قانون - کیمیائی تعامل کے لیے کل اینتھالپی کی تبدیلی یکساں رہتی ہے، چاہے تعامل ایک مرحلے میں ہو یا کئی مراحل میں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "By using Hess's Law and known enthalpy changes of related reactions, we can determine the enthalpy of formation for many compounds.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Total enthalpy change is independent of the reaction pathway.", "related_concepts": ["enthalpy change", "state function", "standard enthalpy of formation", "thermochemical equations"], "real_world_example": "Calculating the enthalpy change for the formation of CO from C and O₂ indirectly, using the enthalpy changes for C + O₂ → CO₂ and CO + ½O₂ → CO₂."}}

{"explanation": "Hydrogen is a chemical element with symbol H and atomic number 1. It is the lightest and most abundant chemical element in the universe, commonly existing as a diatomic gas (H₂).", "urdu_meaning": "ہائیڈروجن - کیمیائی عنصر (علامت H، ایٹمی نمبر 1)، کائنات کا سب سے ہلکا اور وافر عنصر", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "Hydrogen gas (H₂) reacts with oxygen gas (O₂) in an exothermic reaction to form water.", "properties": {"symbol": "H", "atomic_number": 1, "category": "nonmetal", "state_room_temp": "gas (as H₂)", "common_uses": ["Production of ammonia", "Hydrogenation of oils", "Fuel cells", "Rocket fuel (as liquid H₂)"]}}

{"explanation": "Ice is the solid state of water (H₂O), typically forming at or below 0 degrees Celsius (32 degrees Fahrenheit). It is less dense than liquid water.", "urdu_meaning": "برف - پانی کی ٹھوس حالت (H₂O)", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "The melting of ice is an endothermic process that absorbs heat from the surroundings.", "properties": {"formula": "H₂O(s)", "molar_mass": "18.015 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "solid (at/below 0°C)", "hazards": ["Slippery surface", "Can cause frostbite with prolonged contact"]}}

{"explanation": "Intermolecular bonds, or intermolecular forces (IMFs), are the attractive or repulsive forces that exist between molecules. These forces are weaker than intramolecular bonds (like covalent or ionic bonds) but are crucial for determining the physical properties of substances.", "urdu_meaning": "بین السالماتی بندھن / بین السالماتی قوتیں - مالیکیولز کے درمیان موجود کشش یا دفع کی قوتیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Hydrogen bonding is a strong type of intermolecular bond that significantly affects the boiling point of water.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Attractive/repulsive forces between neighboring molecules.", "related_concepts": ["van der Waals forces", "London dispersion forces", "dipole-dipole interactions", "hydrogen bonding", "boiling point", "melting point", "viscosity"], "real_world_example": "The relatively high boiling point of water is due to strong hydrogen bonding between its molecules."}}

{"explanation": "Melting is a phase transition process in which a substance changes from a solid state to a liquid state when its temperature is raised to its melting point. It is an endothermic process as it requires energy input (enthalpy of fusion).", "urdu_meaning": "پگھلاؤ - ٹھوس مادے کا مائع حالت میں تبدیل ہونے کا عمل", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "The melting of ice into water occurs at 0°C and requires the absorption of heat.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Transition from solid to liquid phase, absorbing heat (endothermic).", "related_concepts": ["freezing", "melting point", "enthalpy of fusion", "phase diagram", "endothermic"], "real_world_example": "An ice cube melting in a glass of water."}}

{"explanation": "Metabolism refers to the complete set of life-sustaining chemical reactions in organisms, encompassing processes that convert food into energy (catabolism) and synthesize complex molecules (anabolism).", "urdu_meaning": "میٹابولزم / استحالہ - جانداروں میں زندگی کو برقرار رکھنے والے تمام کیمیائی تعاملات کا مجموعہ", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "The rate of metabolism can be influenced by factors like age, diet, and physical activity.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Sum of all chemical transformations in a living organism.", "related_concepts": ["catabolism", "anabolism", "enzymes", "ATP", "cellular respiration", "photosynthesis", "biochemistry"], "real_world_example": "The breakdown of carbohydrates into glucose, which is then used for energy, is a key part of metabolism."}}

{"explanation": "Methane is a simple hydrocarbon with the chemical formula CH₄, the primary component of natural gas. It is a potent greenhouse gas and a widely used fuel.", "urdu_meaning": "میتھین - قدرتی گیس کا بنیادی جزو، ایک سادہ ہائیڈرو کاربن (CH₄)", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "The standard enthalpy of combustion for methane is -890 kJ/mol.", "properties": {"formula": "CH₄", "molar_mass": "16.04 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Flammable", "Asphyxiant in high concentrations", "Greenhouse gas"]}}

{"explanation": "A mole (mol) is the SI unit for the amount of a substance, defined as containing exactly 6.022 x 10²³ elementary entities (Avogadro's number), which can be atoms, molecules, ions, or electrons.", "urdu_meaning": "مول - مادے کی مقدار کی SI اکائی، جس میں ایوگیڈرو نمبر (6.022 x 10²³) کے برابر بنیادی اکائیاں ہوتی ہیں", "term_type": "unit", "example_sentence": "One mole of carbon atoms has a mass of approximately 12.01 grams.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Represents Avogadro's number (6.022 x 10²³) of particles; links mass to number of particles.", "related_concepts": ["Avogadro's number", "molar mass", "stoichiometry", "concentration"], "real_world_example": "Chemists use the mole to measure amounts of substances for reactions, ensuring correct proportions."}}

{"explanation": "Molecular structure refers to the three-dimensional arrangement of atoms within a molecule and the chemical bonds that hold them together. It determines many of a molecule's physical and chemical properties.", "urdu_meaning": "سالماتی ساخت - مالیکیول میں ایٹموں کی سہ جہتی ترتیب اور ان کے درمیان کیمیائی بندھن", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The tetrahedral molecular structure of methane (CH₄) influences its nonpolar nature.", "properties": {"key_principle": "3D arrangement of atoms and bonds in a molecule.", "related_concepts": ["chemical bonding", "VSEPR theory", "bond angles", "bond lengths", "isomerism", "polarity"], "real_world_example": "The bent molecular structure of water leads to its polarity and ability to form hydrogen bonds."}}

{"explanation": "The mountain analogy is used to illustrate activation energy, where reactants are at the bottom of one side of a mountain, products are on the other side, and the peak represents the energy barrier (activation energy) that must be overcome for the reaction to proceed.", "urdu_meaning": "پہاڑ کی مثال - فعال سازی توانائی کو سمجھانے کے لیے استعمال ہونے والی تشبیہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "According to the mountain analogy, a catalyst provides an alternative path with a lower peak, reducing the activation energy.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A model visualizing the energy barrier (activation energy) that reactants must overcome to form products.", "related_concepts": ["activation energy", "reaction profile", "transition state", "catalyst"], "real_world_example": "Explaining why some reactions are slow at room temperature – the "mountain" is too high to cross easily without added energy."}}

{"explanation": "A negative enthalpy change (ΔH < 0) signifies an exothermic process, where the system releases heat to its surroundings, and the enthalpy of the products is lower than that of the reactants.", "urdu_meaning": "منفی اینتھالپی تبدیلی - ایک حرارت زا عمل کی علامت (ΔH < 0)، جہاں نظام ماحول میں حرارت خارج کرتا ہے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The combustion of fuels always results in a negative enthalpy change, as heat is evolved.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Indicates an exothermic reaction; system loses heat.", "related_concepts": ["exothermic reaction", "enthalpy change (ΔH)", "heat released", "bond formation > bond breaking"], "real_world_example": "The formation of water from hydrogen and oxygen (2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O) has a large negative enthalpy change."}}

{"explanation": "Nitrogen monoxide, also known as nitric oxide (NO), is a colorless gas and a simple diatomic molecule. It is an important signaling molecule in biological systems and also an air pollutant.", "urdu_meaning": "نائٹروجن مونو آکسائیڈ / نائٹرک آکسائیڈ - ایک بے رنگ گیس (NO)، جو حیاتیاتی نظاموں میں اہم سگنلنگ مالیکیول اور فضائی آلودگی کا باعث ہے", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "The formation of nitrogen monoxide from nitrogen and oxygen at high temperatures is an endothermic process.", "properties": {"formula": "NO", "molar_mass": "30.01 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Toxic", "Air pollutant", "Readily oxidizes to NO₂"]}}

{"explanation": "A nuclear weapon is an explosive device that derives its destructive force from nuclear reactions, either fission (atomic bomb) or a combination of fission and fusion (thermonuclear bomb). These reactions release immense amounts of energy.", "urdu_meaning": "جوہری ہتھیار - ایسا دھماکہ خیز آلہ جو جوہری تعاملات (فشن یا فیوژن) سے اپنی تباہ کن توانائی حاصل کرتا ہے", "term_type": "other", "example_sentence": "The energy released by a nuclear weapon is a result of converting mass into energy according to Einstein's E=mc².", "properties": {"key_principle": "Utilizes nuclear fission and/or fusion to release vast amounts of energy.", "related_concepts": ["nuclear fission", "nuclear fusion", "radioactivity", "mass-energy equivalence (E=mc²)", "chain reaction"], "real_world_example": "Atomic bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki."}}

{"explanation": "Oxygen is a chemical element with symbol O and atomic number 8. It is a highly reactive nonmetal and an oxidizing agent that readily forms oxides with most elements as well as with other compounds. In its common molecular form (O₂), it is vital for respiration.", "urdu_meaning": "آکسیجن - کیمیائی عنصر (علامت O، ایٹمی نمبر 8)، سانس لینے اور جلنے کے عمل کے لیے انتہائی اہم", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "Many combustion reactions involve the rapid combination of a substance with oxygen.", "properties": {"symbol": "O", "atomic_number": 8, "category": "nonmetal", "state_room_temp": "gas (as O₂)", "common_uses": ["Respiration", "Combustion", "Medical applications", "Steel production", "Water treatment (ozone O₃)"]}}

{"explanation": "Oxygen gases primarily refer to diatomic oxygen (O₂), essential for respiration and combustion, and triatomic oxygen or ozone (O₃), a reactive gas found in the stratosphere and as a pollutant near ground level.", "urdu_meaning": "آکسیجن گیسیں - بنیادی طور پر ڈائی آٹومک آکسیجن (O₂) اور اوزون (O₃)", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "While O₂ is vital for life, ozone, another of the oxygen gases, can be harmful at ground level but protective in the upper atmosphere.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Gaseous forms of the element oxygen, most commonly O₂ and O₃.", "related_concepts": ["oxygen (O₂)", "ozone (O₃)", "allotropes", "oxidation", "respiration", "combustion"], "real_world_example": "O₂ used in hospitals for patients with breathing difficulties; O₃ used for water disinfection."}}

{"explanation": "A positive enthalpy change (ΔH > 0) signifies an endothermic process, where the system absorbs heat from its surroundings, and the enthalpy of the products is higher than that of the reactants.", "urdu_meaning": "مثبت اینتھالپی تبدیلی - ایک حرارت گیر عمل کی علامت (ΔH > 0)، جہاں نظام ماحول سے حرارت جذب کرتا ہے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The melting of ice requires a positive enthalpy change as energy is absorbed to break intermolecular forces.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Indicates an endothermic reaction; system gains heat.", "related_concepts": ["endothermic reaction", "enthalpy change (ΔH)", "heat absorbed", "bond breaking > bond formation"], "real_world_example": "The decomposition of calcium carbonate into calcium oxide and carbon dioxide has a positive enthalpy change."}}

{"explanation": "Reliable data tables in chemistry provide standardized and experimentally verified values for various physical and chemical properties, such as bond energies, standard enthalpies of formation, and specific heat capacities.", "urdu_meaning": "قابل اعتماد کوائف کے جدول - کیمیا میں معیاری اور تجرباتی طور پر تصدیق شدہ اقدار (جیسے بانڈ توانائی) فراہم کرنے والے جدول", "term_type": "other", "example_sentence": "Chemists consult reliable data tables to find the standard enthalpy of formation needed for Hess's Law calculations.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Collections of accurate and verified chemical and physical data.", "related_concepts": ["standard enthalpy of formation", "bond energy", "thermodynamic data", "CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics"], "real_world_example": "Using a data table to look up the boiling point of a solvent or the bond dissociation energy for a C-H bond."}}

{"explanation": "Self-cooling beverage cans utilize an endothermic process, often the dissolution of certain salts (like ammonium nitrate) in water, within a compartment in the can to absorb heat from the beverage, thus cooling it.", "urdu_meaning": "خود ٹھنڈا کرنے والے مشروبات کے ڈبے - ایسے ڈبے جو مشروب کو ٹھنڈا کرنے کے لیے حرارت گیر عمل استعمال کرتے ہیں", "term_type": "other", "example_sentence": "The technology in self-cooling beverage cans relies on a significant positive enthalpy change of solution for the cooling agent.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Application of an endothermic process to lower the temperature of a beverage.", "related_concepts": ["endothermic reaction", "enthalpy of solution", "heat absorption", "ammonium nitrate"], "real_world_example": "A can design that, upon activation, mixes a salt with water inside a separate chamber, causing the beverage to cool."}}

{"explanation": "Self-cooling packs, or instant cold packs, are devices that become cold rapidly upon activation due to an endothermic chemical reaction or physical process, typically the dissolution of a salt like ammonium nitrate in water.", "urdu_meaning": "خود ٹھنڈا کرنے والے پیک - ایسے پیک جو فعال ہونے پر حرارت گیر کیمیائی عمل کی وجہ سے تیزی سے ٹھنڈے ہو جاتے ہیں", "term_type": "other", "example_sentence": "Athletes often use self-cooling packs to reduce swelling from minor injuries.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Utilizes an endothermic process to absorb heat and provide cooling.", "related_concepts": ["endothermic reaction", "enthalpy of solution", "ammonium nitrate", "first aid"], "real_world_example": "A common type involves a pouch of water and a separate pouch of ammonium nitrate; squeezing the pack breaks the inner pouch, mixing the components and initiating the cooling."}}

{"explanation": "Self-heating packs, or hand warmers, are devices that generate heat upon activation through an exothermic chemical reaction, commonly the oxidation of iron powder.", "urdu_meaning": "خود گرم کرنے والے پیک - ایسے پیک جو فعال ہونے پر حرارت زا کیمیائی عمل کی وجہ سے گرمی پیدا کرتے ہیں", "term_type": "other", "example_sentence": "Self-heating packs are popular in cold weather for providing warmth to hands or body.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Utilizes an exothermic process to release heat and provide warmth.", "related_concepts": ["exothermic reaction", "oxidation of iron", "enthalpy change", "hand warmers"], "real_world_example": "Disposable hand warmers containing iron powder, salt, water, and activated carbon that react with air (oxygen) when opened."}}

{"explanation": "Solid is one of the fundamental states of matter characterized by particles arranged in a fixed, ordered pattern (crystalline) or a disordered pattern (amorphous), with a definite shape and volume.", "urdu_meaning": "ٹھوس - مادے کی ایک حالت جس میں ذرات ایک معین ترتیب میں ہوتے ہیں اور اس کی شکل و حجم معین ہوتی ہے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Ice is the solid form of water, with molecules held in a rigid lattice structure.", "properties": {"key_principle": "State of matter with definite shape and volume; particles are tightly packed and vibrate in fixed positions.", "related_concepts": ["liquid", "gas", "crystalline solid", "amorphous solid", "melting point", "lattice structure"], "real_world_example": "A block of wood, a metal coin, or a grain of salt."}}

{"explanation": "Standard conditions in chemistry typically refer to a pressure of 1 bar (or 1 atm, though 1 bar is IUPAC standard) and a specified temperature, often 298.15 K (25 °C), used for reporting thermodynamic data.", "urdu_meaning": "معیاری حالات - کیمیا میں عام طور پر 1 بار دباؤ اور مخصوص درجہ حرارت (اکثر 298.15 K) پر مبنی حالات", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Standard enthalpy of formation values are reported at standard conditions to allow for consistent comparisons.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A defined set of pressure and temperature for consistent reporting of scientific data.", "related_concepts": ["standard state", "standard enthalpy of reaction", "thermodynamics", "SATP (Standard Ambient Temperature and Pressure)", "STP (Standard Temperature and Pressure - older definition)"], "real_world_example": "The standard enthalpy of formation of CO₂(g) is -393.5 kJ/mol at 298.15 K and 1 bar."}}

{"explanation": "The standard enthalpy of reaction (ΔH°rxn) is the enthalpy change that occurs when a reaction is carried out under standard conditions (usually 1 bar pressure and 298.15 K), with reactants and products in their standard states.", "urdu_meaning": "تعامل کی معیاری اینتھالپی (ΔH°rxn) - معیاری حالات میں ہونے والے تعامل کی اینتھالپی تبدیلی", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The standard enthalpy of reaction for the combustion of methane can be calculated using standard enthalpies of formation.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Enthalpy change for a reaction under standard conditions and states.", "related_concepts": ["enthalpy change", "standard conditions", "standard state", "standard enthalpy of formation", "Hess's Law"], "real_world_example": "ΔH°rxn for 2H₂(g) + O₂(g) → 2H₂O(l) is -571.6 kJ/mol."}}

{"explanation": "The standard state of a substance is its most stable pure form at standard pressure (1 bar) and a specified temperature (usually 298.15 K). For example, the standard state of oxygen at 25°C is O₂(g).", "urdu_meaning": "معیاری حالتیں - کسی مادے کی 1 بار دباؤ اور مخصوص درجہ حرارت پر سب سے مستحکم خالص شکل", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "By definition, the standard enthalpy of formation of an element in its standard state is zero.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Reference form of a substance for thermodynamic calculations (pure substance at 1 bar and specified T).", "related_concepts": ["standard conditions", "standard enthalpy of formation", "thermodynamics", "allotropes"], "real_world_example": "The standard state for carbon is graphite(s), for water it is H₂O(l), and for nitrogen it is N₂(g) at 25°C."}}

{"explanation": "In thermodynamics, the surroundings encompass everything in the universe external to the defined chemical system being studied. Interactions like energy and matter exchange occur between the system and its surroundings.", "urdu_meaning": "ماحول / اطراف - کیمیائی نظام کے باہر کائنات کا باقی تمام حصہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "An exothermic reaction releases heat from the system into the surroundings, increasing the temperature of the surroundings.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Everything outside the defined chemical system.", "related_concepts": ["chemical system", "boundary", "universe", "energy transfer", "heat flow", "open system", "closed system"], "real_world_example": "The air in the room, the container holding a reaction, and the lab bench are all part of the surroundings for a reaction in a beaker."}}

{"explanation": "Thermal energy is the internal energy of a system associated with the kinetic energy (motion) of its constituent atoms and molecules. Temperature is a measure of the average kinetic energy of these particles.", "urdu_meaning": "تھرمل توانائی / حرارتی توانائی - کسی نظام کی داخلی توانائی جو اس کے ایٹموں اور مالیکیولز کی حرکی توانائی سے وابستہ ہے", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "When a substance is heated, its thermal energy increases as its particles move faster.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Internal energy related to the random motion of particles.", "related_concepts": ["heat", "temperature", "kinetic energy", "specific heat capacity", "thermodynamics"], "real_world_example": "A hot cup of coffee has more thermal energy than a cold one because its water molecules are vibrating and moving more rapidly."}}

{"explanation": "A thermochemical equation is a balanced chemical equation that includes the enthalpy change (ΔH) for the reaction, as well as the physical states of all reactants and products.", "urdu_meaning": "حر کیمیائی مساوات - ایک متوازن کیمیائی مساوات جس میں تعامل کی اینتھالپی تبدیلی (ΔH) اور مادوں کی طبعی حالتیں شامل ہوں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The thermochemical equation CH₄(g) + 2O₂(g) → CO₂(g) + 2H₂O(l), ΔH = -890 kJ/mol, shows that the combustion of one mole of methane releases 890 kJ of heat.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Balanced chemical equation showing physical states and enthalpy change.", "related_concepts": ["enthalpy change (ΔH)", "stoichiometry", "Hess's Law", "standard enthalpy of reaction"], "real_world_example": "2H₂(g) + O₂(g) → 2H₂O(l)  ΔH° = -571.6 kJ."}}

{"explanation": "Thermochemistry is the branch of chemistry concerned with the quantities of heat evolved or absorbed during chemical reactions. It is a sub-discipline of thermodynamics.", "urdu_meaning": "حر کیمیا - کیمیا کی وہ شاخ جو کیمیائی تعاملات کے دوران خارج یا جذب ہونے والی حرارت کی مقداروں سے متعلق ہے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Calorimetry is an experimental technique used in thermochemistry to measure heat changes.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Study of heat changes accompanying chemical reactions.", "related_concepts": ["enthalpy", "Hess's Law", "calorimetry", "exothermic reaction", "endothermic reaction", "bond energy", "standard enthalpy of formation"], "real_world_example": "Calculating the fuel value of different foods or fuels."}}

{"explanation": "Vaporization is a phase transition process where a substance in a liquid or solid state converts into a gaseous (vapor) state. It can occur through evaporation (at the surface) or boiling (throughout the bulk of the liquid).", "urdu_meaning": "تبخیر - مائع یا ٹھوس مادے کا گیسی حالت میں تبدیل ہونے کا عمل", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "The vaporization of water requires a significant input of energy, known as the enthalpy of vaporization.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Transition from liquid/solid to gas phase, typically absorbing heat (endothermic).", "related_concepts": ["boiling", "evaporation", "sublimation", "condensation", "vapor pressure", "enthalpy of vaporization", "endothermic"], "real_world_example": "Water boiling in a kettle turns into steam (water vapor)."}}

{"explanation": "Water is a polar inorganic compound with the chemical formula H₂O, essential for all known forms of life and existing as a liquid at standard temperature and pressure.", "urdu_meaning": "پانی - ایک قطبی غیر نامیاتی مرکب (H₂O) جو تمام معلوم زندگی کے لیے ضروری ہے", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "The enthalpy of fusion for water describes the energy needed to melt ice at its melting point.", "properties": {"formula": "H₂O", "molar_mass": "18.015 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "liquid", "hazards": ["Generally safe", "Drowning hazard", "Can cause scalding if hot"]}}

{"explanation": "Water vapor is the gaseous phase of water, formed through evaporation or boiling of liquid water, or sublimation of ice. It is an invisible gas and a significant component of Earth's atmosphere.", "urdu_meaning": "آبی بخارات - پانی کی گیسی حالت، جو مائع پانی کے بخارات بننے یا ابلنے سے بنتی ہے", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "The presence of water vapor in the air contributes to humidity.", "properties": {"formula": "H₂O(g)", "molar_mass": "18.015 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Can cause scalding if hot (steam)"]}}

{"explanation": "Biological energy refers to the energy that living organisms use to power life processes, primarily derived from the chemical energy stored in organic molecules like glucose and ATP.", "urdu_meaning": "حیاتیاتی توانائی - جانداروں کی طرف سے زندگی کے عمل کو چلانے کے لیے استعمال ہونے والی توانائی", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Cellular respiration is a key process for releasing biological energy from food molecules.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Energy used and transformed by living systems to sustain life.", "related_concepts": ["ATP (adenosine triphosphate)", "metabolism", "cellular respiration", "photosynthesis", "chemical energy", "food webs"], "real_world_example": "The energy used for muscle contraction, nerve impulse transmission, and synthesis of biomolecules."}}

{"explanation": "Bond breaking is the process in a chemical reaction where existing chemical bonds between atoms in reactant molecules are cleaved. This process always requires an input of energy and is therefore endothermic.", "urdu_meaning": "بانڈ کا ٹوٹنا - کیمیائی تعامل میں متعامل مالیکیولز میں موجود کیمیائی بانڈز کا ٹوٹنا", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Energy must be supplied for bond breaking to occur in the reactants before new bonds can form.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Cleavage of chemical bonds; always requires energy input (endothermic).", "related_concepts": ["bond energy", "activation energy", "endothermic", "bond formation", "chemical reaction"], "real_world_example": "In the combustion of methane, C-H bonds in CH₄ and O=O bonds in O₂ must be broken."}}

{"explanation": "Bond energy, or bond enthalpy, is the measure of bond strength in a chemical bond, defined as the average energy required to break one mole of a specific type of bond in the gas phase.", "urdu_meaning": "بانڈ توانائی / بندھنی توانائی - کیمیائی بانڈ میں بندھن کی مضبوطی کا پیمانہ", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "Using average bond energies, one can estimate the enthalpy change of a reaction by summing the energies of bonds broken and bonds formed.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Energy required to break a chemical bond or released when a bond is formed.", "related_concepts": ["enthalpy change", "bond breaking (endothermic)", "bond formation (exothermic)", "Hess's Law"], "real_world_example": "The C-C bond energy is different from the C=C bond energy, reflecting different bond strengths."}}

{"explanation": "Bond formation is the process in a chemical reaction where new chemical bonds are created between atoms to form product molecules. This process always releases energy and is therefore exothermic.", "urdu_meaning": "بانڈ کا بننا - کیمیائی تعامل میں ایٹموں کے درمیان نئے کیمیائی بانڈز کا بننا", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Energy is released during bond formation when products are created from reactants.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Creation of new chemical bonds; always releases energy (exothermic).", "related_concepts": ["bond energy", "exothermic", "bond breaking", "chemical reaction", "enthalpy change"], "real_world_example": "In the formation of water from H₂ and O₂, new O-H bonds are formed, releasing energy."}}

{"explanation": "Breaking bonds is the essential first step in many chemical reactions, where energy is absorbed to overcome the attractive forces holding atoms together in reactant molecules.", "urdu_meaning": "بانڈ توڑنا - کیمیائی تعاملات میں توانائی جذب کر کے متعامل مالیکیولز میں بانڈز کو توڑنے کا عمل", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Breaking bonds in reactants is an endothermic step, requiring an input of energy often referred to as activation energy.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The endothermic process of cleaving chemical bonds in reactants.", "related_concepts": ["bond energy", "activation energy", "endothermic", "forming bonds", "chemical reaction"], "real_world_example": "To initiate the combustion of wood, energy (like from a match) is needed for breaking bonds in cellulose and oxygen."}}

{"explanation": "C=O bonds, or carbonyl groups, are strong double covalent bonds between a carbon atom and an oxygen atom, commonly found in organic compounds like aldehydes, ketones, carboxylic acids, and carbon dioxide.", "urdu_meaning": "C=O بانڈز (کاربن-آکسیجن ڈبل بانڈ) - کاربن اور آکسیجن ایٹم کے درمیان مضبوط ڈبل کوویلنٹ بانڈ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The formation of strong C=O bonds in carbon dioxide contributes significantly to the exothermicity of combustion reactions.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A double covalent bond between carbon and oxygen, characteristic of many organic functional groups and CO₂.", "related_concepts": ["carbonyl group", "carbon dioxide", "aldehydes", "ketones", "carboxylic acids", "esters", "bond energy"], "real_world_example": "Carbon dioxide (CO₂) has two C=O bonds. Acetone (a ketone) contains one C=O bond."}}

{"explanation": "Carbon is a chemical element with symbol C and atomic number 6, known for its ability to form a vast number of compounds due to its tetravalency. It is the basis of organic chemistry.", "urdu_meaning": "کاربن - کیمیائی عنصر (علامت C، ایٹمی نمبر 6)، نامیاتی کیمیا کی بنیاد", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "The breaking and forming of bonds involving carbon atoms is central to organic chemistry and biochemistry.", "properties": {"symbol": "C", "atomic_number": 6, "category": "nonmetal", "state_room_temp": "solid", "common_uses": ["Graphite (pencils, lubricants)", "Diamond (jewelry, cutting tools)", "Component of fuels (coal, oil, gas)", "Basis of all organic life"]}}

{"explanation": "Carbon dioxide is a colorless gas with the chemical formula CO₂, naturally present in Earth's atmosphere and produced by respiration, combustion, and decomposition of organic matter. It contains two strong C=O bonds.", "urdu_meaning": "کاربن ڈائی آکسائیڈ - ایک بے رنگ گیس (CO₂)، جس میں دو مضبوط C=O بانڈ ہوتے ہیں", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "The formation of carbon dioxide during combustion involves the creation of two C=O bonds per molecule, releasing significant energy.", "properties": {"formula": "CO₂", "molar_mass": "44.01 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Asphyxiant in high concentrations", "Greenhouse gas"]}}

{"explanation": "Chemical bonding refers to the attractive forces that hold atoms together to form molecules or compounds, resulting from the electrostatic attraction between opposite charges or the sharing of electrons.", "urdu_meaning": "کیمیائی بندھن - وہ قوتیں جو ایٹموں کو مالیکیول یا مرکب بنانے کے لیے جوڑ کر رکھتی ہیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Understanding chemical bonding is fundamental to predicting the structure, properties, and reactivity of substances, including the energy changes during reactions.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Attractive forces holding atoms together in molecules and compounds.", "related_concepts": ["ionic bond", "covalent bond", "metallic bond", "bond energy", "molecular structure", "electronegativity", "bond breaking", "bond formation"], "real_world_example": "The two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom in a water molecule are held together by covalent chemical bonding."}}

{"explanation": "Chemical reactions are processes involving the breaking of existing chemical bonds and the formation of new ones, resulting in the transformation of reactant substances into different product substances.", "urdu_meaning": "کیمیائی تعاملات - ایسے عمل جن میں موجودہ کیمیائی بانڈز ٹوٹتے اور نئے بنتے ہیں، جس سے متعاملات مصنوعات میں تبدیل ہوتے ہیں", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Energy changes are always associated with chemical reactions, as bonds are broken and formed.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Transformation of substances by breaking and forming chemical bonds.", "related_concepts": ["reactants", "products", "stoichiometry", "reaction rate", "activation energy", "enthalpy change", "bond breaking", "bond formation"], "real_world_example": "The digestion of food involves a series of complex chemical reactions in the body."}}

{"explanation": "Combustion is a high-temperature exothermic chemical process involving rapid reaction between a substance (fuel) and an oxidant, usually oxygen, where old bonds are broken and new, stronger bonds are formed, releasing heat and light.", "urdu_meaning": "احتراق - ایندھن اور آکسیڈنٹ کے درمیان تیز حرارت زا کیمیائی تعامل، جس میں پرانے بانڈ ٹوٹتے اور نئے مضبوط بانڈ بنتے ہیں", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "The combustion of propane in a gas grill involves breaking C-C and C-H bonds in propane and O=O bonds in oxygen, and forming C=O bonds in CO₂ and O-H bonds in H₂O.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Rapid oxidation reaction releasing heat and light due to net energy release from bond breaking and formation.", "related_concepts": ["exothermic reaction", "fuel", "oxidant", "flame", "activation energy", "hydrocarbons", "bond breaking", "bond formation"], "real_world_example": "A car engine utilizes the combustion of gasoline to generate power."}}

{"explanation": "The construction analogy explains enthalpy changes in reactions by comparing bond breaking to demolishing an old structure (requires energy) and bond formation to building a new one (releases energy). The net energy change depends on the balance between energy spent on demolition and energy gained from construction.", "urdu_meaning": "تعمیراتی مثال - تعاملات میں اینتھالپی تبدیلیوں کو سمجھانے کے لیے استعمال ہونے والی تشبیہ (پرانی عمارت توڑنا بمقابلہ نئی بنانا)", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Using the construction analogy, if the energy released building new 'bonds' (products) is greater than the energy spent demolishing old 'bonds' (reactants), the overall 'project' (reaction) is exothermic.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A model likening bond breaking (energy input) to demolition and bond formation (energy release) to construction.", "related_concepts": ["bond energy", "enthalpy change", "bond breaking", "bond formation", "exothermic", "endothermic"], "real_world_example": "If it costs more energy to break reactant bonds (demolition) than is released by forming product bonds (construction), the reaction is endothermic."}}

{"explanation": "Endothermic reactions are chemical reactions that absorb heat energy from their surroundings, meaning more energy is required to break bonds in reactants than is released when new bonds form in products (ΔH > 0).", "urdu_meaning": "حرارت گیر تعاملات - کیمیائی تعاملات جو اپنے ماحول سے حرارت جذب کرتے ہیں (بانڈ توڑنے کی توانائی > بانڈ بننے کی توانائی)", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Photosynthesis is an endothermic reaction where plants use light energy to synthesize glucose.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Chemical reactions where the net energy change involves absorption of heat from surroundings (ΔH is positive).", "related_concepts": ["endothermic", "exothermic reactions", "enthalpy change", "activation energy", "bond breaking > bond formation"], "real_world_example": "Dissolving potassium chloride in water is an endothermic process, making the solution feel cold."}}

{"explanation": "The principle of energy conservation states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only converted from one form to another or transferred between a system and its surroundings. In chemical reactions, this applies to the balance of energy in bond breaking and bond formation.", "urdu_meaning": "توانائی کا تحفظ - توانائی نہ تو پیدا کی جا سکتی ہے اور نہ ہی فنا، بلکہ بانڈ ٹوٹنے اور بننے میں توانائی کا توازن برقرار رہتا ہے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "In chemical reactions, energy conservation means that the total energy change, considering both bond breaking and bond formation, is accounted for as heat absorbed or released.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Total energy in an isolated system remains constant; it can only change forms.", "related_concepts": ["thermodynamics (first law)", "energy transfer", "enthalpy", "bond energy", "heat", "work"], "real_world_example": "When wood burns, the chemical potential energy stored in its bonds is converted into heat and light energy, but the total energy remains conserved."}}

{"explanation": "Enthalpy change (ΔH) is the heat energy exchanged between a chemical system and its surroundings at constant pressure, reflecting the net result of energy absorbed for bond breaking and energy released during bond formation.", "urdu_meaning": "اینتھالپی میں تبدیلی (ΔH) - بانڈ ٹوٹنے میں جذب شدہ اور بانڈ بننے میں خارج شدہ توانائی کا خالص نتیجہ", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The enthalpy change of a reaction can be estimated by subtracting the sum of bond energies of products from the sum of bond energies of reactants. (More accurately, ΔH ≈ Σ(bonds broken) - Σ(bonds formed)).", "properties": {"key_principle": "Net heat exchanged at constant pressure, determined by the balance of bond breaking and bond formation energies.", "related_concepts": ["enthalpy", "exothermic reaction", "endothermic reaction", "bond energy", "Hess's Law"], "real_world_example": "The negative enthalpy change for the combustion of methane indicates that more energy is released forming CO₂ and H₂O bonds than is absorbed breaking CH₄ and O₂ bonds."}}

{"explanation": "Exothermic reactions are chemical reactions that release energy to their surroundings, typically as heat, because more energy is released during the formation of new bonds in products than is absorbed to break bonds in reactants (ΔH < 0).", "urdu_meaning": "حرارت زا تعاملات - کیمیائی تعاملات جو اپنے ماحول میں حرارت خارج کرتے ہیں (بانڈ بننے کی توانائی > بانڈ توڑنے کی توانائی)", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The thermite reaction is a highly exothermic reaction where the energy released from forming strong aluminum-oxygen bonds is substantial.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Chemical reactions where the net energy change involves release of heat to surroundings (ΔH is negative).", "related_concepts": ["exothermic", "endothermic reactions", "enthalpy change", "combustion", "bond formation > bond breaking"], "real_world_example": "Neutralization of an acid by a base is a common exothermic reaction."}}

{"explanation": "Forming bonds is the exothermic process in a chemical reaction where atoms combine to create new chemical linkages, releasing energy as the system moves to a lower, more stable energy state.", "urdu_meaning": "بانڈ بنانا - کیمیائی تعامل میں ایٹموں کے ملاپ سے نئے کیمیائی بانڈز بننے کا حرارت زا عمل", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "A significant amount of energy is released when forming bonds in stable molecules like CO₂ and H₂O.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The exothermic process of creating chemical bonds in products.", "related_concepts": ["bond energy", "exothermic", "breaking bonds", "chemical reaction", "stability"], "real_world_example": "When hydrogen and chlorine atoms combine to form HCl molecules, energy is released as H-Cl bonds are formed."}}

{"explanation": "Freezing is a phase transition process in which a substance changes from a liquid state to a solid state when its temperature is lowered to its freezing point. It is an exothermic process as energy (enthalpy of fusion) is released, often involving formation of more ordered intermolecular forces.", "urdu_meaning": "انجماد - مائع مادے کا ٹھوس حالت میں تبدیل ہونے کا حرارت زا عمل، جس میں زیادہ منظم بین السالماتی قوتیں بنتی ہیں", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Water freezing into ice at 0°C is an exothermic process that releases heat to the surroundings.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Transition from liquid to solid phase, releasing heat (exothermic).", "related_concepts": ["melting", "freezing point", "enthalpy of fusion (released)", "phase diagram", "exothermic", "intermolecular forces"], "real_world_example": "Liquid water turning into ice cubes in a freezer."}}

{"explanation": "An H-H bond is a single covalent bond formed between two hydrogen atoms, as found in a hydrogen molecule (H₂). It requires a specific amount of energy (bond energy) to break.", "urdu_meaning": "H-H بانڈ (ہائیڈروجن-ہائیڈروجن سنگل بانڈ) - دو ہائیڈروجن ایٹموں کے درمیان واحد کوویلنٹ بانڈ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The bond energy of an H-H bond in H₂ is approximately 436 kJ/mol.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A single covalent bond between two hydrogen atoms.", "related_concepts": ["covalent bond", "bond energy", "hydrogen molecule (H₂)", "diatomic molecule"], "real_world_example": "In the reaction to form ammonia (N₂ + 3H₂ → 2NH₃), H-H bonds in hydrogen gas must be broken."}}

{"explanation": "An H-I bond is a polar single covalent bond formed between a hydrogen atom and an iodine atom, as found in a hydrogen iodide molecule (HI).", "urdu_meaning": "H-I بانڈ (ہائیڈروجن-آیوڈین سنگل بانڈ) - ہائیڈروجن اور آیوڈین ایٹم کے درمیان واحد قطبی کوویلنٹ بانڈ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The formation of an H-I bond releases energy, and its bond energy can be used in thermochemical calculations involving hydrogen iodide.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A single polar covalent bond between a hydrogen atom and an iodine atom.", "related_concepts": ["covalent bond", "polar covalent bond", "bond energy", "hydrogen iodide (HI)", "electronegativity"], "real_world_example": "In the decomposition of hydrogen iodide (2HI → H₂ + I₂), H-I bonds are broken."}}

{"explanation": "Hydrogen is a chemical element with symbol H and atomic number 1. Its atoms form H-H bonds in H₂ molecules, and H-X bonds (where X is another element) in various compounds, all with specific bond energies.", "urdu_meaning": "ہائیڈروجن - کیمیائی عنصر (علامت H)، جو مختلف بانڈز (جیسے H-H, O-H, C-H) بناتا ہے", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "The bonds involving hydrogen, such as O-H in water or C-H in methane, have characteristic bond energies relevant to many chemical reactions.", "properties": {"symbol": "H", "atomic_number": 1, "category": "nonmetal", "state_room_temp": "gas (as H₂)", "common_uses": ["Production of ammonia", "Hydrogenation of oils", "Fuel cells", "Rocket fuel (as liquid H₂)"]}}

{"explanation": "Hydrogen bonds are a special type of strong dipole-dipole attraction that exists between an electronegative atom (like oxygen, nitrogen, or fluorine) and a hydrogen atom bonded to another electronegative atom. They are intermolecular forces, not covalent bonds within a molecule.", "urdu_meaning": "ہائیڈروجن بانڈز - ایک خاص قسم کی مضبوط بین السالماتی کشش", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The high boiling point of water is due to the extensive network of hydrogen bonds between water molecules, which require energy to break during vaporization.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Strong intermolecular attraction involving H bonded to N, O, or F.", "related_concepts": ["intermolecular forces", "dipole-dipole attraction", "electronegativity", "water properties", "protein structure", "DNA structure", "bond energy (for breaking these IMFs, not covalent bonds)"], "real_world_example": "Hydrogen bonds hold the two strands of a DNA double helix together."}}

{"explanation": "Hydrogen iodide (HI) is a diatomic molecule containing an H-I covalent bond. The breaking of this bond is endothermic, while its formation is exothermic.", "urdu_meaning": "ہائیڈروجن آیوڈائیڈ (HI) - ایک ڈائی آٹومک مالیکیول جس میں H-I کوویلنٹ بانڈ ہوتا ہے", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "The enthalpy of formation of hydrogen iodide can be related to the bond energies of H-H, I-I, and H-I bonds.", "properties": {"formula": "HI", "molar_mass": "127.91 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Corrosive", "Irritant to respiratory system", "Forms strong acid with water"]}}

{"explanation": "An I-I bond is a single nonpolar covalent bond formed between two iodine atoms, as found in an iodine molecule (I₂).", "urdu_meaning": "I-I بانڈ (آیوڈین-آیوڈین سنگل بانڈ) - دو آیوڈین ایٹموں کے درمیان واحد غیر قطبی کوویلنٹ بانڈ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Energy is required to break the I-I bond during the dissociation of iodine molecules.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A single nonpolar covalent bond between two iodine atoms.", "related_concepts": ["covalent bond", "nonpolar covalent bond", "bond energy", "iodine molecule (I₂)", "diatomic molecule", "halogens"], "real_world_example": "In the formation of hydrogen iodide from hydrogen and iodine (H₂ + I₂ → 2HI), I-I bonds in iodine molecules must be broken."}}

{"explanation": "The magnetic analogy can illustrate chemical bonding, where attracting opposite poles of magnets represents bond formation (releasing potential energy and becoming stable), and pulling them apart represents bond breaking (requiring energy input).", "urdu_meaning": "مقناطیسی مثال - کیمیائی بانڈ بننے/ٹوٹنے کو سمجھانے کے لیے استعمال ہونے والی تشبیہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Using the magnetic analogy, forming a chemical bond is like allowing two attracting magnets to snap together, releasing energy, while breaking a bond is like prying them apart, requiring effort.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Model comparing bond formation to attracting magnets (energy release) and bond breaking to separating magnets (energy input).", "related_concepts": ["bond formation (exothermic)", "bond breaking (endothermic)", "potential energy", "stability"], "real_world_example": "Explaining that just as magnets in contact are more stable (lower energy) than separated magnets, atoms in a bond are in a lower energy state."}}

{"explanation": "Melting is a phase transition process in which a substance changes from a solid state to a liquid state when its temperature is raised to its melting point. It is an endothermic process as it requires energy input (enthalpy of fusion) to overcome intermolecular forces, not typically covalent bonds.", "urdu_meaning": "پگھلاؤ - ٹھوس مادے کا مائع حالت میں تبدیل ہونے کا حرارت گیر عمل، جس میں بین السالماتی قوتوں پر قابو پایا جاتا ہے", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "The melting of wax involves breaking weaker intermolecular forces, requiring less energy than breaking covalent bonds.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Transition from solid to liquid phase, absorbing heat (endothermic), primarily involves overcoming intermolecular forces.", "related_concepts": ["freezing", "melting point", "enthalpy of fusion", "phase diagram", "endothermic", "intermolecular forces"], "real_world_example": "Chocolate melting in your hand."}}

{"explanation": "N-O bonds are covalent bonds between nitrogen and oxygen atoms, which can be single (N-O), double (N=O), or even have characteristics of a triple bond in some resonance structures. Their specific bond energies vary.", "urdu_meaning": "N-O بانڈز (نائٹروجن-آکسیجن بانڈز) - نائٹروجن اور آکسیجن ایٹموں کے درمیان کوویلنٹ بانڈ، جن کی بانڈ توانائی مختلف ہوتی ہے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The strength and length of N-O bonds can vary significantly depending on the specific molecule, such as in NO, NO₂, or NO₃⁻.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Covalent linkages between nitrogen and oxygen atoms, exhibiting variable bond order and strength.", "related_concepts": ["covalent bond", "bond energy", "bond order", "nitrogen oxides (NOx)", "nitric oxide (NO)", "nitrogen dioxide (NO₂)", "nitrate ion (NO₃⁻)"], "real_world_example": "Nitric oxide (NO) contains an N=O double bond (with some radical character)."}}

{"explanation": "N≡N represents the very strong triple covalent bond between two nitrogen atoms in a nitrogen molecule (N₂). This strong bond makes diatomic nitrogen relatively unreactive and has a high bond energy.", "urdu_meaning": "N≡N (نائٹروجن-نائٹروجن ٹرپل بانڈ) - نائٹروجن مالیکیول (N₂) میں دو نائٹروجن ایٹموں کے درمیان انتہائی مضبوط ٹرپل کوویلنٹ بانڈ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The high bond energy of the N≡N triple bond must be overcome in processes like the Haber-Bosch synthesis of ammonia.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A triple covalent bond between two nitrogen atoms, known for its exceptional strength and stability.", "related_concepts": ["covalent bond", "triple bond", "bond energy", "nitrogen molecule (N₂)", "inertness", "Haber-Bosch process"], "real_world_example": "Nitrogen gas (N₂) in the atmosphere is largely unreactive due to the strong N≡N bond."}}

{"explanation": "The O=O bond is a double covalent bond between two oxygen atoms in an oxygen molecule (O₂). It is a relatively strong bond, and its breaking is an endothermic step in combustion and oxidation processes.", "urdu_meaning": "O=O بانڈ (آکسیجن-آکسیجن ڈبل بانڈ) - آکسیجن مالیکیول (O₂) میں دو آکسیجن ایٹموں کے درمیان ڈبل کوویلنٹ بانڈ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "During combustion, the O=O bond in oxygen molecules must be broken, which requires a significant amount of energy.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A double covalent bond between two oxygen atoms.", "related_concepts": ["covalent bond", "double bond", "bond energy", "oxygen molecule (O₂)", "combustion", "oxidation", "paramagnetism of O₂"], "real_world_example": "The oxygen we breathe (O₂) contains an O=O double bond."}}

{"explanation": "O=O bonds refer to the double covalent bonds found in diatomic oxygen molecules (O₂). The breaking of these bonds is an essential endothermic step in many oxidation and combustion reactions.", "urdu_meaning": "O=O بانڈز (آکسیجن-آکسیجن ڈبل بانڈز) - ڈائی آٹومک آکسیجن مالیکیولز (O₂) میں پائے جانے والے ڈبل کوویلنٹ بانڈ، جن کا ٹوٹنا حرارت گیر ہوتا ہے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The energy input required to break O=O bonds is a factor in the activation energy of combustion processes.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Double covalent bonds present in O₂ molecules.", "related_concepts": ["covalent bond", "double bond", "bond energy", "oxygen molecule (O₂)", "combustion", "oxidation"], "real_world_example": "Respiration involves processes that ultimately utilize oxygen, requiring the breaking of O=O bonds."}}

{"explanation": "Oxygen is a chemical element (symbol O) that commonly exists as O₂ molecules, containing an O=O double bond. This bond must be broken in reactions like combustion and respiration, an energy-requiring step.", "urdu_meaning": "آکسیجن - کیمیائی عنصر (O)، جو عام طور پر O₂ مالیکیولز (O=O بانڈ کے ساتھ) کی شکل میں پایا جاتا ہے", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "The breaking of the O=O bond in oxygen is a critical part of the energy balance in combustion reactions.", "properties": {"symbol": "O", "atomic_number": 8, "category": "nonmetal", "state_room_temp": "gas (as O₂)", "common_uses": ["Respiration", "Combustion", "Medical applications", "Steel production", "Water treatment (ozone O₃)"]}}

{"explanation": "Photosynthesis is an endothermic process used by plants, algae, and some bacteria to convert light energy into chemical energy, stored in glucose, by reacting carbon dioxide and water and releasing oxygen. This involves breaking C=O and O-H bonds and forming C-C, C-H, C-O, and O=O bonds.", "urdu_meaning": "ضیائی تالیف / فوٹو سنتھیسز - پودوں کا روشنی کی توانائی کو کیمیائی توانائی میں تبدیل کرنے کا حرارت گیر عمل، جس میں بانڈ ٹوٹتے اور بنتے ہیں", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Photosynthesis involves the breaking of C=O bonds in CO₂ and O-H bonds in H₂O, and the formation of C-C, C-H, C-O bonds in glucose and O=O bonds in oxygen.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Conversion of light energy into chemical energy (glucose) using CO₂ and H₂O; releases O₂. Endothermic process involving complex bond rearrangements.", "related_concepts": ["endothermic reaction", "chlorophyll", "glucose", "carbon dioxide", "water", "oxygen", "light energy", "biological energy", "bond breaking", "bond formation"], "real_world_example": "Green plants producing their own food using sunlight."}}

{"explanation": "Protein synthesis is the biological process by which cells build proteins, involving the formation of peptide bonds between amino acids. This process requires energy input (ATP) to drive the endergonic bond formation steps.", "urdu_meaning": "پروٹین کی تالیف - خلیوں کا پروٹین بنانے کا حیاتیاتی عمل، جس میں پیپٹائڈ بانڈ بنتے ہیں اور توانائی درکار ہوتی ہے", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "The formation of peptide bonds between amino acids during protein synthesis is an energy-consuming, endergonic step coupled to ATP hydrolysis.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Cellular process of creating proteins from amino acids, involving energy-requiring peptide bond formation.", "related_concepts": ["amino acids", "peptide bonds", "DNA", "RNA", "ribosomes", "transcription", "translation", "gene expression", "anabolism", "endergonic reaction"], "real_world_example": "Cells producing enzymes, structural proteins, or hormones."}}

{"explanation": "Cellular respiration is an exothermic biochemical process in which cells break down glucose and other food molecules (breaking C-C, C-H, O-H bonds) in the presence of oxygen (breaking O=O bonds) to release chemical energy by forming stronger bonds in CO₂ (C=O) and H₂O (O-H).", "urdu_meaning": "تنفس (خلیاتی تنفس) - خلیوں کا گلوکوز کو توڑ کر توانائی خارج کرنے کا حرارت زا عمل، جس میں بانڈ ٹوٹتے اور مضبوط نئے بانڈ بنتے ہیں", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Respiration involves breaking C-C, C-H, C-O bonds in glucose and O=O bonds in oxygen, and forming C=O bonds in CO₂ and O-H bonds in H₂O, releasing energy.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Breakdown of organic molecules to release energy (ATP) for cellular activities; exothermic process due to net formation of stronger bonds.", "related_concepts": ["exothermic reaction", "ATP", "glucose", "oxygen", "carbon dioxide", "water", "mitochondria", "metabolism", "biological energy", "bond breaking", "bond formation"], "real_world_example": "Human cells using energy from food to perform daily functions."}}

{"explanation": "Thermite reactions are highly exothermic redox reactions typically involving a metal powder (like aluminum) reacting with a metal oxide (like iron(III) oxide). The large heat release is due to the formation of very strong Al-O bonds being more exothermic than the energy required to break Fe-O bonds.", "urdu_meaning": "تھرمائٹ تعاملات - انتہائی حرارت زا ریڈوکس تعاملات، جس میں مضبوط نئے بانڈ بننے سے بہت زیادہ توانائی خارج ہوتی ہے", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "The large amount of heat released in thermite reactions is due to the formation of very strong aluminum-oxygen bonds.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Highly exothermic redox reaction between a metal and a metal oxide, releasing substantial heat due to favorable bond energy changes.", "related_concepts": ["exothermic reaction", "redox reaction", "aluminum", "iron oxide", "welding", "incendiary devices", "enthalpy change", "bond energy"], "real_world_example": "Welding railway tracks using the heat generated by the reaction between aluminum powder and iron(III) oxide."}}

{"explanation": "Water (H₂O) is a compound whose formation from H₂ and O₂ is highly exothermic due to the strong O-H bonds formed.
