Le Châtelier's principle describes how changes in conditions can favor the backward direction to relieve stress on an equilibrium system.", "urdu_meaning": "پیچھے کی سمتیں - قابل واپسی تعاملات میں مصنوعات کا واپس متعاملات میں تبدیل ہونا", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "If product concentration is increased in an equilibrium, the reaction will shift in the backward direction to consume some of the added product.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The path from products to reactants in a reversible chemical process.", "related_concepts": ["backward reaction", "reverse reaction", "Le Châtelier's principle", "chemical equilibrium", "reversible reaction"], "real_world_example": "Removing a product from the Haber process causes the equilibrium to shift in the forward direction, away from the backward direction."}}

{"explanation": "A catalyst speeds up both the forward and reverse reactions in a reversible system equally, allowing equilibrium to be reached faster but without altering the equilibrium position or the equilibrium constant (K).", "urdu_meaning": "عمل انگیز - تعامل کی شرح بڑھاتا ہے لیکن توازن کی حالت کو تبدیل نہیں کرتا", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "While a catalyst does not change the equilibrium yield of ammonia in the Haber process, it allows the reaction to reach equilibrium much more quickly at lower temperatures.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Substance that increases rate of attainment of equilibrium by lowering activation energy for both forward and reverse reactions, but does not shift equilibrium position.", "related_concepts": ["activation energy", "reaction rate", "chemical equilibrium", "Haber process", "enzymes"], "real_world_example": "Use of an iron-based catalyst in ammonia synthesis."}}

{"explanation": "Chemical equilibrium is a dynamic state where the rates of forward and reverse reactions are equal, and the net concentrations of reactants and products remain constant. Le Châtelier's principle describes how this state responds to external changes.", "urdu_meaning": "کیمیائی توازن - حرکی حالت جہاں آگے اور پیچھے کے تعاملات کی شرحیں برابر ہوں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Understanding chemical equilibrium is crucial for controlling the outcome of reversible reactions in industrial processes.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A state of balance in a reversible reaction where opposing rates are equal.", "related_concepts": ["dynamic equilibrium", "reversible reaction", "Le Châtelier's principle", "equilibrium constant", "equilibrium position"], "real_world_example": "The NO₂/N₂O₄ system reaches chemical equilibrium in a closed container."}}

{"explanation": "Color changes can visually indicate shifts in chemical equilibrium when one or more reactants or products are colored. Examples include the NO₂/N₂O₄ equilibrium or systems involving colored complex ions like FeSCN²⁺.", "urdu_meaning": "رنگ میں تبدیلیاں - کیمیائی توازن میں تبدیلی کی بصری نشاندہی", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "In the NO₂/N₂O₄ equilibrium, color changes from light brown to dark brown indicate a shift towards more NO₂ formation.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Visual indication of equilibrium shifts when colored species are involved.", "related_concepts": ["NO₂/N₂O₄ equilibrium", "FeSCN²⁺ equilibrium", "indicators", "Le Châtelier's principle", "chemical equilibrium"], "real_world_example": "The pink-to-blue color change of cobalt chloride paper with humidity."}}

{"explanation": "Common reversible reactions studied to illustrate equilibrium principles include the Haber process for ammonia synthesis, the NO₂/N₂O₄ equilibrium, the decomposition of PCl₅, and the hydration/dehydration of copper sulfate.", "urdu_meaning": "عام قابل واپسی تعاملات - توازن کے اصولوں کی وضاحت کے لیے استعمال ہونے والے عام تعاملات", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Many common reversible reactions are used in educational settings to demonstrate Le Châtelier's principle.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Frequently cited examples of reactions that reach a measurable equilibrium.", "related_concepts": ["reversible reaction", "chemical equilibrium", "Haber process", "NO₂/N₂O₄ equilibrium", "PCl₅ decomposition", "copper sulfate hydration"], "real_world_example": "The dissociation of weak acids or bases in water."}}

{"explanation": "Concentration changes of reactants or products in an equilibrium system will cause the equilibrium position to shift to counteract the change, according to Le Châtelier's principle, but will not change the equilibrium constant (K) at a constant temperature.", "urdu_meaning": "ارتکاز میں تبدیلیاں - توازن کی حالت پر اثر انداز ہوتی ہیں لیکن K کو تبدیل نہیں کرتیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "If the concentration of a reactant is increased, concentration changes will drive the equilibrium to the product side.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Alterations in the amounts of reactants or products per unit volume, causing shifts in equilibrium position.", "related_concepts": ["Le Châtelier's principle", "chemical equilibrium", "equilibrium position", "equilibrium constant (K)", "reaction quotient (Q)"], "real_world_example": "Adding more SCN⁻ to the Fe³⁺/SCN⁻ equilibrium deepens the red color of FeSCN²⁺."}}

{"explanation": "At equilibrium, the concentrations of all reactants and products remain constant over time, even though the forward and reverse reactions are still occurring at equal rates. These concentrations are related by the equilibrium constant.", "urdu_meaning": "ارتکاز (جمع) - توازن پر متعاملات اور مصنوعات کی مستقل مقداریں", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The equilibrium concentrations can be used to calculate the value of K_c for a reaction.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Macroscopically constant amounts of reactants and products per unit volume at equilibrium.", "related_concepts": ["concentration", "chemical equilibrium", "equilibrium constant (K_c)", "dynamic equilibrium"], "real_world_example": "Measuring the concentrations of all species in the Haber process at equilibrium."}}

{"explanation": "Copper sulfate hydration is the reversible reaction where anhydrous white copper(II) sulfate (CuSO₄) reacts with water to form blue hydrated copper(II) sulfate (e.g., CuSO₄·5H₂O). This process is often used to demonstrate equilibrium shifts with changes in water concentration or temperature.", "urdu_meaning": "کاپر سلفیٹ کی آبیدگی - کاپر سلفیٹ کا پانی کے ساتھ قابل واپسی تعامل", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "The equilibrium of copper sulfate hydration can be shifted towards the anhydrous form by heating, which is an endothermic process in the dehydration direction.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Reversible reaction: CuSO₄(s) + nH₂O(g/l) ⇌ CuSO₄·nH₂O(s), showing color change.", "related_concepts": ["hydrated copper sulfate", "anhydrous CuSO₄", "reversible reaction", "chemical equilibrium", "Le Châtelier's principle", "dehydration", "water of crystallization"], "real_world_example": "Using anhydrous copper sulfate to test for the presence of water."}}

{"explanation": "Dynamic equilibrium is a state where the forward and reverse reactions occur at the same rate, resulting in no observable change in the concentrations of reactants and products, although reactions are continuously happening at the molecular level.", "urdu_meaning": "حرکی توازن - وہ حالت جہاں آگے اور پیچھے کے تعاملات برابر شرح سے جاری رہتے ہیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "A system at dynamic equilibrium will respond to stresses, such as changes in concentration or temperature, by shifting its position.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A state of balance achieved when the rates of opposing processes become equal.", "related_concepts": ["chemical equilibrium", "reversible reaction", "reaction rates", "Le Châtelier's principle"], "real_world_example": "The NO₂/N₂O₄ system in a sealed tube at constant temperature."}}

{"explanation": "An endothermic reaction absorbs heat (ΔH > 0). According to Le Châtelier's principle, increasing the temperature of an equilibrium system will shift the equilibrium position in the direction of the endothermic reaction.", "urdu_meaning": "حرارت گیر - حرارت جذب کرنے والا تعامل؛ درجہ حرارت بڑھانے سے یہ سمت فیور ہوتی ہے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The decomposition of PCl₅ into PCl₃ and Cl₂ is an endothermic process, so higher temperatures favor the products.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A process that absorbs heat. In equilibrium, increasing temperature favors this direction.", "related_concepts": ["exothermic", "enthalpy change (ΔH)", "Le Châtelier's principle", "chemical equilibrium"], "real_world_example": "The forward reaction in the NO₂/N₂O₄ equilibrium (N₂O₄ ⇌ 2NO₂) is endothermic."}}

{"explanation": "Equilibrium is a state in a reversible reaction where the macroscopic properties (like concentrations, pressure, color) of the system remain constant because the rates of the forward and reverse reactions are equal.", "urdu_meaning": "توازن - قابل واپسی تعامل کی وہ حالت جہاں مخالف شرحیں برابر ہوں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Once a reversible reaction reaches equilibrium, the ratio of product concentrations to reactant concentrations (raised to their stoichiometric powers) is constant at a given temperature.", "properties": {"key_principle": "State of balance in a reversible system due to equal rates of opposing processes.", "related_concepts": ["chemical equilibrium", "dynamic equilibrium", "equilibrium position", "equilibrium constant", "reversible reaction"], "real_world_example": "The Haber process for ammonia synthesis operates at equilibrium."}}

{"explanation": "Equilibrium position refers to the relative concentrations of reactants and products at equilibrium. It can be shifted by changes in conditions (concentration, pressure, temperature) according to Le Châtelier's principle, without changing the equilibrium constant (except for temperature).", "urdu_meaning": "توازن کی حالت / پوزیشن - توازن پر متعاملات اور مصنوعات کی نسبتی مقداریں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Adding a catalyst does not change the equilibrium position; it only helps reach it faster.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The specific set of reactant and product concentrations that exist at equilibrium; can be shifted by external changes.", "related_concepts": ["chemical equilibrium", "Le Châtelier's principle", "equilibrium constant (K)", "concentration", "pressure", "temperature"], "real_world_example": "If K > 1, the equilibrium position lies towards the products."}}

{"explanation": "An exothermic reaction releases heat (ΔH < 0). According to Le Châtelier's principle, increasing the temperature of an equilibrium system will shift the equilibrium position in the direction that absorbs heat, i.e., away from the exothermic reaction.", "urdu_meaning": "حرارت زا - حرارت خارج کرنے والا تعامل؛ درجہ حرارت بڑھانے سے یہ سمت فیور نہیں ہوتی", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The synthesis of ammonia in the Haber process is exothermic, so lower temperatures favor a higher equilibrium yield of ammonia.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A process that releases heat. In equilibrium, increasing temperature disfavors this direction.", "related_concepts": ["endothermic", "enthalpy change (ΔH)", "Le Châtelier's principle", "chemical equilibrium"], "real_world_example": "The forward reaction in the 2NO₂(g) ⇌ N₂O₄(g) equilibrium is exothermic."}}

{"explanation": "The forward direction in a reversible reaction refers to the conversion of reactants into products as typically written from left to right. Le Châtelier's principle describes how changes in conditions can favor the forward direction to relieve stress.", "urdu_meaning": "آگے کی سمت - قابل واپسی تعامل میں متعاملات کا مصنوعات میں تبدیل ہونا", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Increasing reactant concentration or removing product will shift the equilibrium in the forward direction.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The path from reactants to products as conventionally written in a reversible chemical process.", "related_concepts": ["forward reaction", "Le Châtelier's principle", "chemical equilibrium", "reversible reaction", "product side"], "real_world_example": "In the Haber process, conditions are chosen to favor the forward direction to maximize ammonia yield."}}

{"explanation": "Forward reactions are the processes in reversible systems where reactants combine or transform to form products. At equilibrium, the rate of forward reactions equals the rate of reverse reactions.", "urdu_meaning": "آگے کی جانب تعاملات - قابل واپسی نظام میں متعاملات کا مصنوعات میں تبدیل ہونے کا عمل", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The speed of forward reactions generally decreases as reactant concentrations fall during the approach to equilibrium.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The conversion of reactants to products in a reversible system.", "related_concepts": ["forward direction", "reverse reactions", "reaction rate", "chemical equilibrium", "dynamic equilibrium"], "real_world_example": "The ionization of acetic acid to form acetate and H⁺ ions is a forward reaction."}}

{"explanation": "Gas molecules are particles in the gaseous state. In equilibria involving gases, the number of gas molecules on the reactant and product sides determines how pressure changes affect the equilibrium position (Le Châtelier's principle).", "urdu_meaning": "گیس کے سالمات - گیسی حالت میں ذرات؛ ان کی تعداد توازن پر دباؤ کے اثر کو متعین کرتی ہے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "In the PCl₅ decomposition (PCl₅(g) ⇌ PCl₃(g) + Cl₂(g)), there are more gas molecules on the product side, so increasing pressure shifts the equilibrium to the left.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Molecules in the gaseous state; their molar amounts influence pressure effects on equilibrium.", "related_concepts": ["partial pressure", "Le Châtelier's principle (effect of pressure)", "ideal gas law", "chemical equilibrium (gaseous)"], "real_world_example": "The N₂O₄(g) ⇌ 2NO₂(g) equilibrium involves a change in the number of gas molecules."}}

{"explanation": "The Haber process synthesizes ammonia from nitrogen and hydrogen (N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g)). It is a classic industrial application of Le Châtelier's principle to manipulate a reversible reaction for optimal product yield by controlling temperature, pressure, and catalyst use.", "urdu_meaning": "ہیبر پراسس - امونیا کی صنعتی تیاری، جو لی شاٹیلیئر کے اصول کا اطلاق ہے", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "In the Haber process, high pressure is used to shift the equilibrium towards ammonia because there are fewer moles of gas on the product side.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Industrial synthesis of NH₃ from N₂ and H₂, optimizing equilibrium yield using Le Châtelier's principle and catalysis.", "related_concepts": ["ammonia", "chemical equilibrium", "Le Châtelier's principle", "catalyst", "pressure changes", "temperature changes"], "real_world_example": "Manufacturing fertilizers essential for global food production."}}

{"explanation": "Hydrogen (H₂) is a reactant in the Haber process for ammonia synthesis. Its concentration (partial pressure) is a factor that can be adjusted to shift the N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g) equilibrium according to Le Châtelier's principle.", "urdu_meaning": "ہائیڈروجن - ہیبر پراسس میں ایک متعامل، جس کا ارتکاز توازن پر اثرانداز ہوتا ہے", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "Increasing the partial pressure of hydrogen in the Haber process reactor helps to drive the equilibrium towards the formation of ammonia.", "properties": {"symbol": "H", "atomic_number": 1, "category": "nonmetal", "state_room_temp": "gas (as H₂)", "common_uses": ["Reactant in Haber process", "Fuel", "Hydrogenation"]}}

{"explanation": "An irreversible process or reaction proceeds effectively in one direction only, going to completion or near completion, and does not establish a significant equilibrium where reactants are reformed from products under the same conditions.", "urdu_meaning": "ناقابل واپسی - ایسا عمل یا تعامل جو زیادہ تر ایک ہی سمت میں تکمیل تک پہنچے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Combustion of a fuel is generally considered an irreversible reaction, unlike the dissociation of a weak acid which is reversible.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Proceeding essentially to completion in one direction without significant reverse reaction.", "related_concepts": ["reversible", "irreversible reaction", "completion", "chemical equilibrium (not established or K is very large)"], "real_world_example": "The reaction between a strong acid and a strong base."}}

{"explanation": "Le Châtelier's principle predicts how a system at dynamic equilibrium responds to external stresses (changes in concentration, pressure, or temperature). The system adjusts by shifting the equilibrium position to counteract the applied stress.", "urdu_meaning": "لی شاٹیلیئر کا اصول - توازن میں نظام پر تبدیلی کے اثر کی پیش گوئی کرنے والا اصول", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Applying Le Châtelier's principle helps in optimizing conditions for industrial reactions like the Haber process.", "properties": {"key_principle": "If a change is imposed on a system at equilibrium, the equilibrium will shift to counteract the change.", "related_concepts": ["chemical equilibrium", "dynamic equilibrium", "concentration changes", "pressure changes", "temperature changes", "equilibrium position"], "real_world_example": "Adding heat to an endothermic reaction at equilibrium will shift it to favor more products."}}

{"explanation": "Le Châtelier's principle effects refer to the observable shifts in equilibrium position when conditions like concentration, pressure (for gases), or temperature are changed. These effects are crucial for controlling reversible reactions.", "urdu_meaning": "لی شاٹیلیئر کے اصول کے اثرات - حالات میں تبدیلی سے توازن کی حالت میں ہونے والی تبدیلیاں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The color change in the NO₂/N₂O₄ equilibrium upon heating is one of the visible Le Châtelier's principle effects.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The resulting shifts in equilibrium due to changes in concentration, pressure, or temperature.", "related_concepts": ["Le Châtelier's principle", "equilibrium shift", "concentration changes", "pressure changes", "temperature changes", "chemical equilibrium"], "real_world_example": "In the Haber process, increasing pressure (a Le Châtelier's principle effect) increases ammonia yield."}}

{"explanation": "The NO₂/N₂O₄ equilibrium (N₂O₄(g) ⇌ 2NO₂(g) or 2NO₂(g) ⇌ N₂O₄(g)) is a classic reversible reaction involving colorless dinitrogen tetroxide (N₂O₄) and brown nitrogen dioxide (NO₂). It is often used to demonstrate Le Châtelier's principle due to visible color changes with temperature and pressure.", "urdu_meaning": "NO₂/N₂O₄ توازن - N₂O₄ اور NO₂ کے درمیان قابل واپسی تعامل", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Heating the NO₂/N₂O₄ equilibrium mixture shifts it towards the formation of more brown NO₂, as the forward reaction (N₂O₄ ⇌ 2NO₂) is endothermic.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Reversible interconversion of N₂O₄ (colorless) and NO₂ (brown), demonstrating equilibrium shifts visually.", "related_concepts": ["dinitrogen tetroxide (N₂O₄)", "nitrogen dioxide (NO₂)", "chemical equilibrium", "Le Châtelier's principle", "color changes", "pressure changes", "temperature changes"], "real_world_example": "Observing the color change of a sealed tube of this gas mixture when placed in hot or cold water."}}

{"explanation": "PCl₅ decomposition refers to the reversible reaction where phosphorus pentachloride gas breaks down into phosphorus trichloride gas and chlorine gas: PCl₅(g) ⇌ PCl₃(g) + Cl₂(g). This equilibrium is affected by temperature and pressure.", "urdu_meaning": "PCl₅ کی تحلیل - فاسفورس پینٹا کلورائیڈ کا PCl₃ اور Cl₂ میں قابل واپسی طور پر ٹوٹنا", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Increasing the temperature shifts the PCl₅ decomposition equilibrium to the right, favoring the formation of PCl₃ and Cl₂.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Reversible breakdown of PCl₅(g) into PCl₃(g) and Cl₂(g).", "related_concepts": ["phosphorus pentachloride (PCl₅)", "phosphorus trichloride (PCl₃)", "chlorine (Cl₂)", "chemical equilibrium", "Le Châtelier's principle", "pressure changes", "temperature changes"], "real_world_example": "Studying this system to understand gaseous equilibria and partial pressures."}}

{"explanation": "Pressure changes affect the position of a chemical equilibrium involving gases if there is a change in the total number of moles of gas between reactants and products. Increasing pressure favors the side with fewer gas moles, as per Le Châtelier's principle.", "urdu_meaning": "دباؤ میں تبدیلیاں - گیسی توازن پر اثر انداز ہوتی ہیں اگر گیس کے مولز کی تعداد تبدیل ہو", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "For the Haber process (N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g)), pressure changes are significant because 4 moles of gaseous reactants form 2 moles of gaseous product.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Alterations in pressure that can shift gaseous equilibria if Δn(gas) ≠ 0.", "related_concepts": ["Le Châtelier's principle", "chemical equilibrium (gaseous)", "partial pressure", "gas molecules", "equilibrium position"], "real_world_example": "Increasing pressure in the PCl₅ decomposition shifts equilibrium to the left (towards PCl₅)."}}

{"explanation": "A product is a substance formed as a result of a chemical reaction. In reversible reactions, products can also react to reform reactants until equilibrium is reached.", "urdu_meaning": "حاصل / مصنوع - کیمیائی تعامل کے نتیجے میں بننے والا مادہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "In the reaction A + B ⇌ C + D, C and D are the products.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Substance(s) formed during a chemical reaction.", "related_concepts": ["reactant", "chemical reaction", "chemical equilibrium", "product side", "yield"], "real_world_example": "Ammonia is the product in the Haber process."}}

{"explanation": "The product side of a chemical equation represents the substances formed during the reaction, conventionally written on the right-hand side. Le Châtelier's principle describes how changes can shift the equilibrium towards or away from the product side.", "urdu_meaning": "مصنوعات کی جانب - کیمیائی مساوات کا وہ حصہ جو بننے والے مادوں کو ظاہر کرتا ہے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "If a reaction is exothermic, increasing temperature will shift the equilibrium away from the product side.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The right-hand side of a chemical equation, representing the products.", "related_concepts": ["reactant side", "chemical equation", "chemical equilibrium", "Le Châtelier's principle", "forward direction"], "real_world_example": "In N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g), 2NH₃(g) is on the product side."}}

{"explanation": "The rate of backward reaction is the speed at which products are converted back into reactants in a reversible chemical reaction. At equilibrium, this rate is equal to the rate of the forward reaction.", "urdu_meaning": "پیچھے کی جانب تعامل کی شرح - مصنوعات کے واپس متعاملات میں تبدیل ہونے کی رفتار", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "Initially, the rate of backward reaction is zero (if starting with pure reactants) but increases as product concentration builds up, until it matches the rate of forward reaction at equilibrium.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The speed of the reaction converting products to reactants.", "related_concepts": ["rate of forward reaction", "reaction rate", "chemical kinetics", "dynamic equilibrium", "chemical equilibrium", "backward reaction"], "real_world_example": "In a saturated sugar solution, the rate at which dissolved sugar crystallizes out is the rate of backward reaction for dissolution."}}

{"explanation": "The rate of forward reaction is the speed at which reactants are converted into products in a chemical reaction. In a reversible reaction, this rate decreases as reactant concentrations fall, until it equals the rate of the backward reaction at equilibrium.", "urdu_meaning": "آگے کی جانب تعامل کی شرح - متعاملات کے مصنوعات میں تبدیل ہونے کی رفتار", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The rate of forward reaction is typically highest at the beginning of the reaction when reactant concentrations are at their maximum.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The speed of the reaction converting reactants to products.", "related_concepts": ["rate of backward reaction", "reaction rate", "chemical kinetics", "dynamic equilibrium", "chemical equilibrium", "forward reaction"], "real_world_example": "The initial rate at which an Alka-Seltzer tablet dissolves in water."}}

{"explanation": "A reactant is a starting substance in a chemical reaction that is consumed to form products. In reversible reactions, reactants are continuously reformed from products at equilibrium.", "urdu_meaning": "متعامل - کیمیائی تعامل میں حصہ لینے والا ابتدائی مادہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Nitrogen and hydrogen are the reactants in the Haber process for synthesizing ammonia.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Substance(s) consumed during a chemical reaction.", "related_concepts": ["product", "chemical reaction", "chemical equilibrium", "reactant side", "concentration"], "real_world_example": "Glucose is a reactant in cellular respiration."}}

{"explanation": "The reactant side of a chemical equation represents the starting substances in a reaction, conventionally written on the left-hand side. Changes in conditions can shift an equilibrium towards or away from the reactant side.", "urdu_meaning": "متعاملات کی جانب - کیمیائی مساوات کا وہ حصہ جو ابتدائی مادوں کو ظاہر کرتا ہے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Increasing the concentration of a product will shift the equilibrium towards the reactant side.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The left-hand side of a chemical equation, representing the reactants.", "related_concepts": ["product side", "chemical equation", "chemical equilibrium", "Le Châtelier's principle", "backward directions"], "real_world_example": "In N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g), N₂(g) and 3H₂(g) are on the reactant side."}}

{"explanation": "Reverse reactions are the processes in reversible systems where products convert back into reactants. The interplay between forward and reverse reactions leads to dynamic equilibrium.", "urdu_meaning": "معکوس تعاملات - قابل واپسی نظام میں مصنوعات کا واپس متعاملات میں تبدیل ہونے کا عمل", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "At equilibrium, the rates of forward reactions and reverse reactions are equal.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The conversion of products back to reactants in a reversible chemical system.", "related_concepts": ["backward reaction", "forward reactions", "reversible reaction", "dynamic equilibrium", "chemical equilibrium"], "real_world_example": "The recombination of H⁺ and A⁻ ions to form undissociated HA in a weak acid solution."}}

{"explanation": "A process or reaction is reversible if it can proceed in both the forward and backward directions, potentially reaching a state of dynamic equilibrium where both processes occur at equal rates.", "urdu_meaning": "قابل واپسی - ایسا عمل یا تعامل جو دونوں سمتوں میں ہو سکے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The binding of oxygen to hemoglobin is a reversible process, crucial for oxygen transport.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Capable of proceeding in both directions (forward and reverse).", "related_concepts": ["irreversible", "reversible reaction", "dynamic equilibrium", "chemical equilibrium", "phase transition"], "real_world_example": "The melting of ice and freezing of water is a reversible physical process."}}

{"explanation": "Reversible reactions are chemical reactions where the conversion of reactants to products and products back to reactants occurs simultaneously, leading to a state of equilibrium rather than complete consumption of reactants.", "urdu_meaning": "قابل واپسی تعاملات - کیمیائی تعاملات جو دونوں سمتوں میں ہو سکتے ہیں اور توازن تک پہنچتے ہیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Understanding Le Châtelier's principle is key to controlling the outcomes of reversible reactions in industrial settings.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Reactions that do not go to completion because products can reform reactants, leading to equilibrium.", "related_concepts": ["reversible", "chemical equilibrium", "dynamic equilibrium", "Le Châtelier's principle", "Haber process", "NO₂/N₂O₄ equilibrium"], "real_world_example": "The esterification of an acid with an alcohol to form an ester and water is a classic reversible reaction."}}

{"explanation": "Temperature changes are unique in that they alter not only the position of a chemical equilibrium (as per Le Châtelier's principle) but also the value of the equilibrium constant (K). Increasing temperature favors the endothermic direction.", "urdu_meaning": "درجہ حرارت میں تبدیلیاں - توازن کی حالت اور توازنی مستقل (K) دونوں پر اثر انداز ہوتی ہیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "For an exothermic reaction at equilibrium, temperature changes such as an increase will shift the equilibrium to the left and decrease K.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Alterations in temperature that shift equilibrium position and change the equilibrium constant (K).", "related_concepts": ["Le Châtelier's principle", "equilibrium constant (K)", "van 't Hoff equation", "endothermic reaction", "exothermic reaction", "chemical equilibrium"], "real_world_example": "Heating the N₂O₄/NO₂ equilibrium mixture increases the brown color (more NO₂) because the forward reaction (N₂O₄ ⇌ 2NO₂) is endothermic."}}

{"explanation": "The water-gas shift reaction (CO(g) + H₂O(g) ⇌ CO₂(g) + H₂(g)) is an important industrial reversible reaction used to increase the hydrogen content of synthesis gas or to remove carbon monoxide. Its equilibrium is affected by temperature.", "urdu_meaning": "واٹر گیس شفٹ - کاربن مونو آکسائیڈ اور پانی سے کاربن ڈائی آکسائیڈ اور ہائیڈروجن بنانے کا قابل واپسی تعامل", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "The water-gas shift reaction is typically exothermic in the forward direction shown, so lower temperatures favor higher H₂ and CO₂ yields at equilibrium.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Reversible reaction between CO and H₂O to produce CO₂ and H₂; equilibrium considerations are vital for its industrial application.", "related_concepts": ["water-gas shift reaction", "synthesis gas", "hydrogen production", "chemical equilibrium", "Le Châtelier's principle", "catalysis"], "real_world_example": "Used in ammonia plants to produce pure hydrogen and in integrated gasification combined cycle (IGCC) power plants."}}

{"explanation": "Acid dissociation constants (Kₐ) are equilibrium constants that measure the strength of an acid in solution, indicating the extent to which the acid dissociates into its conjugate base and a proton (H⁺). A larger Kₐ value indicates a stronger acid.", "urdu_meaning": "تیزاب کی تحلیل کا مستقل (Kₐ) - تیزاب کی طاقت کا پیمانہ", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The pKₐ, derived from the acid dissociation constant Kₐ, is often used to compare the strengths of different weak acids.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Equilibrium constant (Kₐ) for the dissociation of an acid, quantifying acid strength.", "related_concepts": ["Kₐ", "pKₐ", "weak acid", "strong acid", "conjugate base", "pH", "buffer solution", "chemical equilibrium"], "real_world_example": "Acetic acid has a Kₐ of 1.8 x 10⁻⁵, indicating it is a weak acid."}}

{"explanation": "Acid-base chemistry is a branch of chemistry that deals with the properties and reactions of acids and bases, including concepts like pH, proton transfer, neutralization, and buffer solutions, many of which involve chemical equilibria.", "urdu_meaning": "تیزاب اساس کیمیا - تیزابوں اور اساسوں کی خصوصیات اور تعاملات کا مطالعہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Understanding acid-base chemistry is crucial for analyzing buffer systems like the carbonic acid-bicarbonate system in blood.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Study of acids, bases, their reactions, and equilibria (e.g., proton transfer, pH, buffers).", "related_concepts": ["acids", "bases", "pH", "pOH", "Kₐ", "Kᵦ", "neutralization", "buffer solution", "proton transfer", "chemical equilibrium"], "real_world_example": "Titration of vinegar with sodium hydroxide to determine acetic acid concentration."}}

{"explanation": "Acids are chemical substances that, in aqueous solution, can donate protons (Brønsted-Lowry definition) or accept electron pairs (Lewis definition), typically having a pH less than 7. Weak acids establish dissociation equilibria in water.", "urdu_meaning": "تیزاب - ایسے کیمیائی مادے جو پروٹون دے سکتے ہیں یا الیکٹران جوڑے قبول کر سکتے ہیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Weak acids, like acetic acid, only partially dissociate in water, establishing an equilibrium with their ions.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Substances that donate H⁺ ions (protons) or accept electron pairs; weak acids exist in equilibrium with their ions in solution.", "related_concepts": ["bases", "pH", "Brønsted-Lowry acid", "Lewis acid", "strong acid", "weak acid", "acid dissociation constant (Kₐ)", "conjugate base"], "real_world_example": "Hydrochloric acid (HCl) in stomachช่วยย่อยอาหาร, or citric acid in lemons."}}

{"explanation": "Activation energy (Ea) is the minimum energy barrier that reactants must overcome for a chemical reaction to occur. Catalysts lower this energy, affecting reaction rates but not the equilibrium position.", "urdu_meaning": "فعال سازی توانائی - کیمیائی تعامل شروع کرنے کے لیے درکار کم از کم توانائی", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "While a reaction may be thermodynamically favorable, a high activation energy can make it proceed very slowly without a catalyst or heating.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Minimum energy required to initiate a chemical reaction; affects reaction rate, not equilibrium constant.", "related_concepts": ["chemical kinetics", "reaction rate", "catalyst", "transition state", "Arrhenius equation", "equilibrium (rate of attainment)"], "real_world_example": "The spark from a lighter provides the activation energy to ignite natural gas."}}

{"explanation": "Analytical chemistry is the science of obtaining, processing, and communicating information about the composition and structure of matter. It often involves applying principles of chemical equilibrium, such as in titrations or solubility calculations.", "urdu_meaning": "تجزیاتی کیمیا - مادے کی ترکیب اور ساخت کے بارے میں معلومات حاصل کرنے کا علم", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "In analytical chemistry, solubility product constants (Ksp) are used to determine if a precipitate will form under certain conditions.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Branch of chemistry focused on identifying and quantifying chemical substances and their properties, often utilizing equilibrium concepts.", "related_concepts": ["qualitative analysis", "quantitative analysis", "spectroscopy", "chromatography", "titration", "Ksp", "Kₐ"], "real_world_example": "Determining the concentration of pollutants in a water sample."}}

{"explanation": "Blood pH is a measure of the acidity or alkalinity of blood, which is tightly regulated around 7.35-7.45 in humans by buffer systems, primarily the carbonic acid-bicarbonate system. {"explanation": "Calcium carbonate (CaCO₃) is a chemical compound found in rocks (limestone, marble) and shells. {"explanation": "Calcium oxide (CaO), or quicklime, is a white crystalline solid produced by the thermal decomposition of calcium carbonate (CaCO₃). This decomposition is a reversible reaction, establishing an equilibrium: CaCO₃(s) ⇌ CaO(s) + CO₂(g).", "urdu_meaning": "کیلشیم آکسائیڈ / ان بجھا چونا - کیلشیم کاربونیٹ کی حرارتی تحلیل سے بننے والا سفید ٹھوس", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "In the production of cement, CaO is formed by heating limestone, a process that involves shifting the decomposition equilibrium of CaCO₃.", "properties": {"formula": "CaO", "molar_mass": "56.0774 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "solid", "hazards": ["Corrosive", "Causes severe irritation and burns", "Reacts exothermically with water"]}}

{"explanation": "Carbon dioxide (CO₂) is a gas involved in numerous important equilibria, including its dissolution in water to form carbonic acid (H₂CO₃), its role in the carbonic acid-bicarbonate buffer system, and its impact on ocean acidification and climate change.", "urdu_meaning": "کاربن ڈائی آکسائیڈ - ایک گیس جو کئی اہم توازنات میں شامل ہے، جیسے کہ سمندری تیزابیت", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "Increased atmospheric carbon dioxide levels lead to more CO₂ dissolving in oceans, contributing to ocean acidification by shifting carbonate equilibria.", "properties": {"formula": "CO₂", "molar_mass": "44.01 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Asphyxiant in high concentrations", "Greenhouse gas"]}}

{"explanation": "Carbonic acid (H₂CO₃) is a weak dibasic acid formed when carbon dioxide dissolves in water (CO₂(aq) + H₂O(l) ⇌ H₂CO₃(aq)). It is a key component of the carbonic acid-bicarbonate buffer system in blood and natural waters.", "urdu_meaning": "کاربنک ایسڈ - ایک کمزور تیزاب جو کاربن ڈائی آکسائیڈ کے پانی میں حل ہونے سے بنتا ہے", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "Carbonic acid establishes equilibria by dissociating in two steps to form bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) and carbonate (CO₃²⁻) ions.", "properties": {"formula": "H₂CO₃", "molar_mass": "62.03 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "exists primarily in aqueous solution (unstable as pure substance)", "hazards": ["Weak acid", "Solutions can be mildly corrosive"]}}

{"explanation": "The carbonic acid-bicarbonate buffer system (H₂CO₃/HCO₃⁻) is the primary physiological buffer that maintains blood pH within a narrow range. It relies on the equilibrium between carbonic acid (H₂CO₃) and bicarbonate ions (HCO₃⁻).", "urdu_meaning": "کاربنک ایسڈ-بائی کاربونیٹ بفر سسٹم - خون میں پی ایچ کو مستحکم رکھنے والا اہم بفر نظام", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The carbonic acid-bicarbonate buffer system can neutralize excess acid or base in the blood by shifting its equilibrium.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Major blood pH buffer involving the equilibrium H₂CO₃ ⇌ H⁺ + HCO₃⁻ and CO₂ + H₂O ⇌ H₂CO₃.", "related_concepts": ["buffer solution", "carbonic acid (H₂CO₃)", "bicarbonate ion (HCO₃⁻)", "blood pH", "homeostasis", "Le Châtelier's principle", "acid-base equilibrium"], "real_world_example": "Maintaining human blood pH around 7.4 despite metabolic production of acids/bases."}}

{"explanation": "Catalysts accelerate chemical reactions by lowering activation energy, enabling equilibrium to be reached faster but without changing the equilibrium constant (K) or the equilibrium position. They affect kinetics, not thermodynamics of the equilibrium state.", "urdu_meaning": "عمل انگیز (جمع) - کیمیائی تعاملات کی شرح بڑھانے والے مادے جو توازن کی حالت کو تبدیل نہیں کرتے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "In the Contact process for sulfuric acid production, catalysts are used to speed up the attainment of equilibrium in the oxidation of SO₂ to SO₃.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Substances that increase reaction rates (forward and reverse equally) without being consumed and without affecting K.", "related_concepts": ["activation energy", "reaction rate", "chemical kinetics", "chemical equilibrium", "enzymes", "Haber process", "Contact process"], "real_world_example": "Vanadium(V) oxide used as a catalyst in the Contact process."}}

{"explanation": "Climate change refers to long-term shifts in temperatures and weather patterns, largely driven by increased greenhouse gas concentrations like CO₂. This increase in atmospheric CO₂ affects global chemical equilibria, such as ocean acidification.", "urdu_meaning": "موسمیاتی تبدیلی - درجہ حرارت اور موسم کے نمونوں میں طویل مدتی تبدیلیاں، جو CO₂ جیسے گرین ہاؤس گیسوں سے منسلک ہیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Climate change is linked to rising atmospheric CO₂, which disturbs the natural carbon cycle equilibria and contributes to ocean acidification.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Long-term alteration of global weather patterns, significantly impacted by greenhouse gases affecting various environmental equilibria.", "related_concepts": ["carbon dioxide (CO₂)", "greenhouse effect", "ocean acidification", "global warming", "carbon cycle", "environmental science"], "real_world_example": "Rising global average temperatures and increased frequency of extreme weather events."}}

{"explanation": "Chlorine (Cl₂) is a reactive diatomic halogen gas. It is involved in various equilibria, such as its reaction with PCl₃ to form PCl₅ (PCl₃(g) + Cl₂(g) ⇌ PCl₅(g)).", "urdu_meaning": "کلورین - ایک تعاملی دو ایٹمی ہیلوجن گیس", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "The equilibrium involving PCl₃, Cl₂, and PCl₅ can be shifted by changing the partial pressure of Cl₂ gas.", "properties": {"formula": "Cl₂", "molar_mass": "70.906 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Highly toxic", "Corrosive", "Strong oxidizer", "Respiratory irritant"]}}

{"explanation": "Concentrations of reactants and products are critical for defining the equilibrium constant (K) and determining the direction an equilibrium will shift if disturbed (Le Châtelier's principle). {"explanation": "The Contact process is the primary industrial method for producing sulfuric acid. {"explanation": "Endothermic reactions absorb heat from their surroundings (positive ΔH). {"explanation": "Enthalpy (H) is a thermodynamic property representing the total heat content of a system. {"explanation": "Equilibria (plural of equilibrium) refer to multiple states of balance in various reversible physical or chemical processes where opposing rates are equal. {"explanation": "Equilibrium is a dynamic state in a reversible process where the rate of the forward process equals the rate of the reverse process, leading to no net change in macroscopic properties. It is characterized by an equilibrium constant (K) at a given temperature.", "urdu_meaning": "توازن - حرکی حالت جہاں مخالف عمل کی شرحیں برابر ہوں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The equilibrium constant K provides a quantitative measure of the position of equilibrium.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A state of balance in a reversible system where forward and reverse rates are equal.", "related_concepts": ["chemical equilibrium", "dynamic equilibrium", "phase equilibrium", "equilibrium constant (K)", "Le Châtelier's principle", "reversible reaction"], "real_world_example": "The Haber process operates by manipulating conditions to optimize the yield at equilibrium."}}

{"explanation": "The equilibrium constant (K) is a value that expresses the ratio of product concentrations (or partial pressures) to reactant concentrations at equilibrium, each raised to the power of its stoichiometric coefficient. It indicates the extent of a reaction at a given temperature.", "urdu_meaning": "توازنی مستقل / ایکویلیبریم کانسٹنٹ (K) - توازن پر مصنوعات اور متعاملات کے ارتکاز کا تناسب", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "A large equilibrium constant (K >> 1) indicates that the reaction favors product formation at equilibrium.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A ratio (K_c, K_p, K_a, K_sp, etc.) indicating the relative amounts of products and reactants at equilibrium; temperature dependent.", "related_concepts": ["K_c", "K_p", "K_a", "K_b", "K_sp", "chemical equilibrium", "equilibrium expression", "Gibbs free energy (ΔG° = -RTlnK)"], "real_world_example": "The K_c for N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g) at 400°C is about 0.5."}}

term: equilibrium constant in terms of pressure
enrichment_data: {"explanation": "The equilibrium constant in terms of pressure (K_p) is used for gas-phase reactions, defined by the ratio of partial pressures of products to reactants at equilibrium, each raised to its stoichiometric coefficient. K_p is related to K_c by K_p = K_c(RT)^Δn.", "urdu_meaning": "دباؤ کی اصطلاح میں توازنی مستقل (K_p) - گیسی تعاملات کے لیے توازنی مستقل", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "For the reaction N₂O₄(g) ⇌ 2NO₂(g), the equilibrium constant in terms of pressure, K_p, is given by (P_NO₂)² / P_N₂O₄.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Equilibrium constant (K_p) for gas-phase reactions, expressed using partial pressures of gases.", "related_concepts": ["K_p", "K_c", "partial pressure", "gas-phase reactions", "chemical equilibrium", "Δn (change in moles of gas)"], "real_world_example": "Calculating K_p for the Haber process using the partial pressures of N₂, H₂, and NH₃ at equilibrium."}}

{"explanation": "The equilibrium expression is the mathematical formulation that relates the concentrations or partial pressures of products and reactants at equilibrium to the equilibrium constant (K). For aA + bB ⇌ cC + dD, K_c = ([C]^c[D]^d) / ([A]^a[B]^b).", "urdu_meaning": "توازنی مساوات / ایکویلیبریم ایکسپریشن - توازنی مستقل (K) کے لیے ریاضیاتی فارمولا", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Writing the correct equilibrium expression is the first step in calculating the equilibrium constant for a reaction.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Mathematical relationship defining the equilibrium constant (K) in terms of reactant and product concentrations/pressures.", "related_concepts": ["equilibrium constant (K_c, K_p)", "law of mass action", "chemical equilibrium", "stoichiometric coefficients", "concentrations", "partial pressures"], "real_world_example": "For H₂(g) + I₂(g) ⇌ 2HI(g), the equilibrium expression for K_c is [HI]² / ([H₂][I₂])."}}

{"explanation": "The equilibrium position describes the relative amounts of reactants and products present when a reversible reaction reaches equilibrium. It can be shifted by changes in concentration, pressure, or temperature, as predicted by Le Châtelier's principle.", "urdu_meaning": "توازن کی حالت / پوزیشن - توازن پر متعاملات اور مصنوعات کی نسبتی مقداریں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Adding more reactant to a system at equilibrium will shift the equilibrium position to the right, favoring products, but will not change K.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The specific set of conditions (concentrations, partial pressures) at which equilibrium is established; can be altered by external stresses.", "related_concepts": ["chemical equilibrium", "Le Châtelier's principle", "equilibrium constant (K)", "concentration", "pressure", "temperature"], "real_world_example": "If K is small, the equilibrium position lies towards the reactants."}}

{"explanation": "Exothermic reactions release heat (negative ΔH). For such reactions at equilibrium, an increase in temperature shifts the equilibrium position to favor reactants (the endothermic direction) and decreases the value of the equilibrium constant K.", "urdu_meaning": "حرارت زا تعاملات - حرارت خارج کرنے والے تعاملات؛ درجہ حرارت بڑھنے سے K کم ہوتا ہے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The Haber synthesis of ammonia is an exothermic reaction, so increasing temperature will decrease the equilibrium yield of ammonia.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Reactions that release heat (ΔH < 0); increasing T shifts equilibrium to reactants and decreases K.", "related_concepts": ["endothermic reactions", "enthalpy (ΔH)", "Le Châtelier's principle", "equilibrium constant (K)", "van 't Hoff equation"], "real_world_example": "The forward reaction 2NO₂(g) ⇌ N₂O₄(g) is exothermic."}}

{"explanation": "Gibbs free energy (G) is a thermodynamic potential that measures the maximum reversible work obtainable from a system at constant temperature and pressure. The change in Gibbs free energy (ΔG) determines the spontaneity of a reaction and is related to the equilibrium constant by ΔG° = -RTlnK.", "urdu_meaning": "گبز کی آزاد توانائی - ایک تھرمو ڈائنامک مقدار جو تعامل کی بے ساختگی اور توازن کی حالت کا تعین کرتی ہے", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "A negative value of ΔG indicates a spontaneous reaction, while ΔG = 0 at equilibrium.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Thermodynamic quantity (G = H - TS) whose change (ΔG) indicates spontaneity and relates to equilibrium constant (K).", "related_concepts": ["spontaneity", "chemical equilibrium", "equilibrium constant (K)", "standard Gibbs free energy change (ΔG°)", "enthalpy (ΔH)", "entropy (ΔS)", "thermodynamics"], "real_world_example": "Calculating ΔG° for a reaction to predict if it will favor products under standard conditions."}}

{"explanation": "The Haber process (or Haber-Bosch process) is an industrial method for synthesizing ammonia (NH₃) from nitrogen (N₂) and hydrogen (H₂) (N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g)). {"explanation": "Water (H₂O) is a ubiquitous solvent and reactant involved in many chemical equilibria, including acid-base dissociation (e.g., as a reactant with CO₂ to form H₂CO₃, or as a product of neutralization), solubility equilibria, and its own autoionization (2H₂O(l) ⇌ H₃O⁺(aq) + OH⁻(aq)).", "urdu_meaning": "H₂O (پانی) - ایک عام سالوینٹ اور کئی کیمیائی توازنات میں شامل متعامل یا حاصل", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "The autoionization of H₂O establishes an equilibrium that defines the ion product constant for water, Kw.", "properties": {"formula": "H₂O", "molar_mass": "18.015 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "liquid", "hazards": ["Generally safe"]}}

{"explanation": "Iron(III) ions (Fe³⁺) are cations that can participate in various chemical equilibria, notably forming a colored complex with thiocyanate ions (SCN⁻) which is used to study equilibrium shifts: Fe³⁺(aq) + SCN⁻(aq) ⇌ FeSCN²⁺(aq).", "urdu_meaning": "آئرن (III) آئنز - کیٹائنز جو تھائیوسائینیٹ آئنز کے ساتھ رنگین کمپلیکس بناتے ہیں", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "The addition of more iron(III) ions to an equilibrium mixture containing thiocyanate will increase the concentration of the red FeSCN²⁺ complex.", "properties": {"formula": "Fe³⁺", "molar_mass": "55.845 g/mol (for Fe atom)", "state_room_temp": "in aqueous solution (as hydrated ion, e.g., [Fe(H₂O)₆]³⁺)", "hazards": ["Acidic in solution", "Can be corrosive", "Iron salts can be irritants"]}}

{"explanation": "Kₐ is the acid dissociation constant, an equilibrium constant that quantifies the strength of a weak acid in solution. {"explanation": "Kₚ is the equilibrium constant expressed in terms of the partial pressures of gaseous reactants and products. It is used for equilibria involving gas-phase reactions.", "urdu_meaning": "Kₚ (دباؤ کی اصطلاح میں توازنی مستقل) - گیسی تعاملات کے لیے توازنی مستقل", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "For the Haber process N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g), Kₚ = (P_NH₃)² / ((P_N₂)(P_H₂)³).", "properties": {"key_principle": "Equilibrium constant for gas-phase reactions defined using partial pressures.", "related_concepts": ["equilibrium constant in terms of pressure", "K_c", "partial pressure", "gas-phase reactions", "chemical equilibrium", "ideal gas law"], "real_world_example": "Calculating Kₚ for the decomposition of PCl₅ at a specific temperature."}}

{"explanation": "Kₛₚ is the solubility product constant, an equilibrium constant that describes the equilibrium between a sparingly soluble ionic solid and its ions in a saturated solution. A smaller Kₛₚ value indicates lower solubility.", "urdu_meaning": "Kₛₚ (حل پذیری حاصل ضرب مستقل) - کم حل پذیر آئنی ٹھوس کی حل پذیری کا پیمانہ", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The Kₛₚ for AgCl is 1.8 x 10⁻¹⁰ at 25°C, indicating its very low solubility in water.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Equilibrium constant for the dissolution of a sparingly soluble ionic solid (e.g., MX(s) ⇌ M⁺(aq) + X⁻(aq)).", "related_concepts": ["solubility product constants", "solubility", "sparingly soluble salts", "precipitation reactions", "common ion effect", "chemical equilibrium"], "real_world_example": "Using Kₛₚ values to predict whether a precipitate will form when two solutions are mixed."}}

{"explanation": "Le Châtelier's principle states that if a change (stress) is applied to a system at dynamic equilibrium, the system will adjust itself to counteract the stress and re-establish equilibrium. This applies to changes in concentration, pressure (for gases), and temperature.", "urdu_meaning": "لی شاٹیلیئر کا اصول - توازن میں نظام پر تبدیلی کے اثر کی پیش گوئی کرنے والا اصول", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "According to Le Châtelier's principle, removing a product from an equilibrium mixture will shift the reaction to produce more of that product.", "properties": {"key_principle": "If a stress (change in T, P, or concentration) is applied to a system at equilibrium, the system shifts to relieve the stress.", "related_concepts": ["chemical equilibrium", "dynamic equilibrium", "equilibrium position", "concentration", "pressure", "temperature", "equilibrium constant (K changes with T only)"], "real_world_example": "In the Haber process, increasing pressure shifts equilibrium to favor ammonia, which has fewer gas moles."}}

{"explanation": "Liquids are a state of matter with a definite volume but no fixed shape. In equilibrium expressions for heterogeneous equilibria, the concentrations of pure liquids (and solids) are considered constant and are usually incorporated into the equilibrium constant, so they do not appear in the expression.", "urdu_meaning": "مائعات - مادے کی ایک حالت؛ خالص مائعات کا ارتکاز توازنی مساوات میں مستقل سمجھا جاتا ہے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "In the equilibrium expression for the autoionization of water, H₂O(l) is a pure liquid, so its concentration is not explicitly included in K_w.", "properties": {"key_principle": "State of matter with definite volume, no fixed shape; pure liquids have constant activity/concentration in equilibrium expressions.", "related_concepts": ["solids", "gases", "heterogeneous equilibrium", "activity", "equilibrium expression", "phase"], "real_world_example": "Water (H₂O(l)) as a solvent or reactant in its pure liquid state."}}

{"explanation": "Molar concentrations (molarity, mol/L) are commonly used to express the amounts of reactants and products in solution for calculating the equilibrium constant K_c and for applying Le Châtelier's principle to shifts in equilibrium due to concentration changes.", "urdu_meaning": "مولر ارتکاز - محلول میں مادوں کی مقدار (مول فی لیٹر) جو K_c کے لیے استعمال ہوتی ہے", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The equilibrium constant K_c is calculated using the molar concentrations of all gaseous and aqueous species at equilibrium.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Concentration expressed as moles of solute per liter of solution (mol/L); used in K_c expressions.", "related_concepts": ["concentration", "K_c", "equilibrium constant", "equilibrium expression", "solution stoichiometry", "molarity"], "real_world_example": "A 1.0 M solution of NaCl contains 1.0 mole of NaCl per liter of solution."}}

{"explanation": "NH₃ (ammonia) is a compound whose industrial synthesis via the Haber process (N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g)) is a classic example of applying equilibrium principles (like Le Châtelier's principle and K_p) to optimize yield.", "urdu_meaning": "NH₃ (امونیا) - ایک اہم صنعتی کیمیکل جس کی ترکیب توازن کے اصولوں پر مبنی ہے", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "The equilibrium constant K_p for the formation of NH₃ decreases with increasing temperature because the reaction is exothermic.", "properties": {"formula": "NH₃", "molar_mass": "17.031 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Toxic", "Corrosive", "Irritant"]}}

{"explanation": "NO₂ (nitrogen dioxide) is a brown gas that exists in equilibrium with colorless N₂O₄ (dinitrogen tetroxide): 2NO₂(g) ⇌ N₂O₄(g). This equilibrium is readily affected by temperature and pressure, making it a good system for demonstrating K_p and Le Châtelier's principle.", "urdu_meaning": "NO₂ (نائٹروجن ڈائی آکسائیڈ) - بھوری گیس جو N₂O₄ کے ساتھ توازن میں ہوتی ہے", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "The partial pressure of NO₂ at equilibrium is used in the K_p expression for the 2NO₂(g) ⇌ N₂O₄(g) system.", "properties": {"formula": "NO₂", "molar_mass": "46.0055 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Highly toxic", "Corrosive", "Air pollutant"]}}

{"explanation": "N₂O₄ (dinitrogen tetroxide) is a colorless gas that is in equilibrium with brown NO₂ (nitrogen dioxide): N₂O₄(g) ⇌ 2NO₂(g). The equilibrium constant K_p can be calculated from the partial pressures of N₂O₄ and NO₂ at equilibrium.", "urdu_meaning": "N₂O₄ (ڈائی نائٹروجن ٹیٹرا آکسائیڈ) - بے رنگ گیس جو NO₂ کے ساتھ توازن میں ہوتی ہے", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "For the N₂O₄(g) ⇌ 2NO₂(g) equilibrium, K_p = (P_NO₂)² / P_N₂O₄.", "properties": {"formula": "N₂O₄", "molar_mass": "92.011 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas (in equilibrium mixture)", "hazards": ["Highly toxic", "Corrosive", "Strong oxidizer"]}}

{"explanation": "Ocean acidification is the ongoing decrease in the pH of Earth's oceans, caused by the uptake of anthropogenic carbon dioxide (CO₂) from the atmosphere. This process involves shifts in the carbonate-bicarbonate-carbonic acid equilibria in seawater, impacting marine life.", "urdu_meaning": "سمندری تیزابیت - فضا سے CO₂ جذب ہونے کی وجہ سے سمندروں کی pH میں کمی", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Ocean acidification makes it more difficult for organisms like corals and shellfish to build their calcium carbonate shells and skeletons due to unfavorable shifts in carbonate equilibria.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Decrease in ocean pH due to absorption of atmospheric CO₂, disturbing marine carbonate equilibria (CO₂ + H₂O ⇌ H₂CO₃ ⇌ H⁺ + HCO₃⁻ ⇌ 2H⁺ + CO₃²⁻).", "related_concepts": ["carbon dioxide (CO₂)", "pH scale", "carbonic acid (H₂CO₃)", "bicarbonate ion (HCO₃⁻)", "carbonate ion (CO₃²⁻)", "calcium carbonate (CaCO₃)", "coral reefs", "climate change", "chemical equilibrium"], "real_world_example": "Threats to marine calcifying organisms like oysters and pteropods."}}

{"explanation": "OH⁻ is the hydroxide ion, a key species in acid-base chemistry and water autoionization (2H₂O(l) ⇌ H₃O⁺(aq) + OH⁻(aq) or H₂O(l) ⇌ H⁺(aq) + OH⁻(aq)). Its concentration determines the basicity of a solution and is related to pH by K_w.", "urdu_meaning": "OH⁻ (ہائیڈروکسائیڈ آئن) - تیزاب اساس کیمیا اور پانی کی خود آئنائزیشن میں اہم آئن", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "In pure water at 25°C, the concentration of OH⁻ ions at equilibrium is 1.0 x 10⁻⁷ M, due to water autoionization.", "properties": {"formula": "OH⁻", "molar_mass": "17.008 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "in aqueous solution", "hazards": ["Strong base solutions are corrosive and can cause burns."]}}

{"explanation": "Oxygen (O₂) is a diatomic gas that participates in various equilibria, such as its reversible binding to hemoglobin in blood (Hb + O₂ ⇌ HbO₂) and its role as a reactant in the Contact process (2SO₂(g) + O₂(g) ⇌ 2SO₃(g)), where its partial pressure is a factor in K_p.", "urdu_meaning": "آکسیجن - ایک گیس جو ہیموگلوبن کے ساتھ توازن اور کانٹیکٹ پراسس میں شامل ہے", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "The equilibrium constant K_p for the oxidation of SO₂ in the Contact process depends on the partial pressures of O₂, SO₂, and SO₃.", "properties": {"symbol": "O", "atomic_number": 8, "category": "nonmetal", "state_room_temp": "gas (as O₂)", "common_uses": ["Respiration", "Combustion", "Industrial oxidation"]}}

{"explanation": "Partial pressures are the pressures exerted by individual gases in a mixture. For gas-phase equilibria, the equilibrium constant K_p is expressed in terms of the partial pressures of reactants and products.", "urdu_meaning": "جزوی دباؤ - گیسوں کے آمیزے میں انفرادی گیسوں کا دباؤ؛ K_p کے لیے استعمال ہوتا ہے", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The K_p for the reaction N₂O₄(g) ⇌ 2NO₂(g) is calculated using the partial pressures of N₂O₄ and NO₂ at equilibrium.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Pressure exerted by each component gas in a mixture; used in K_p expressions for gaseous equilibria.", "related_concepts": ["K_p", "Dalton's Law of Partial Pressures", "gas-phase reactions", "chemical equilibrium", "total pressure"], "real_world_example": "In air at sea level, the partial pressure of nitrogen is about 0.78 atm."}}

{"explanation": "Phosphorus trichloride (PCl₃) is a compound that can react with chlorine (Cl₂) to form phosphorus pentachloride (PCl₅) in a reversible gas-phase reaction: PCl₃(g) + Cl₂(g) ⇌ PCl₅(g). Its partial pressure is part of the K_p expression.", "urdu_meaning": "PCl₃ (فاسفورس ٹرائی کلورائیڈ) - PCl₅ کے ساتھ توازن میں شامل مرکب", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "At equilibrium, the partial pressure of PCl₃ contributes to the value of K_p for the PCl₃/PCl₅/Cl₂ system.", "properties": {"formula": "PCl₃", "molar_mass": "137.33 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "liquid (fumes, can be gas)", "hazards": ["Highly toxic", "Corrosive", "Reacts violently with water"]}}

{"explanation": "Phosphorus pentachloride (PCl₅) is a compound that undergoes thermal decomposition into phosphorus trichloride (PCl₃) and chlorine (Cl₂) in a reversible gas-phase equilibrium: PCl₅(g) ⇌ PCl₃(g) + Cl₂(g). K_p can be determined from partial pressures.", "urdu_meaning": "PCl₅ (فاسفورس پینٹا کلورائیڈ) - PCl₃ اور Cl₂ میں قابل واپسی طور پر تحلیل ہونے والا مرکب", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "The equilibrium for the decomposition of PCl₅ is shifted to the right by increasing temperature, as the reaction is endothermic.", "properties": {"formula": "PCl₅", "molar_mass": "208.24 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "solid (sublimes, can be gas)", "hazards": ["Highly toxic", "Corrosive", "Reacts violently with water"]}}

{"explanation": "The pH scale is a logarithmic scale (0 to 14 at 25°C) used to specify the acidity or basicity of an aqueous solution. It is related to the concentration of H⁺ (or H₃O⁺) ions, which is often determined by acid-base equilibria and the water autoionization equilibrium (K_w).", "urdu_meaning": "پی ایچ سکیل - آبی محلول کی تیزابیت یا اساسیت کی پیمائش کا پیمانہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The pH scale helps quantify how shifts in acid-base equilibria, like in buffer solutions or due to CO₂ dissolution, affect acidity.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Logarithmic measure of H⁺ ion concentration (pH = -log[H⁺]), indicating acidity/alkalinity.", "related_concepts": ["pOH", "acid", "base", "neutral solution", "K_w (water autoionization constant)", "buffer solution", "indicators", "acid dissociation constant (Kₐ)"], "real_world_example": "Pure water has a pH of 7 at 25°C."}}

{"explanation": "Precipitation reactions occur when two soluble ionic compounds in solution react to form an insoluble solid product called a precipitate. These reactions involve solubility equilibria, described by the solubility product constant (Ksp).", "urdu_meaning": "رسوبی تعاملات - دو حل پذیر آئنی مرکبات کے تعامل سے ناقابل حل ٹھوس کا بننا", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "If the ion product (Qsp) exceeds the Ksp for a sparingly soluble salt, precipitation will occur until equilibrium is re-established.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Formation of an insoluble solid (precipitate) from solution, governed by solubility product (Ksp) equilibria.", "related_concepts": ["precipitate", "solubility", "solubility product constant (Ksp)", "sparingly soluble salts", "ionic product (Qsp)", "common ion effect"], "real_world_example": "Mixing solutions of silver nitrate and sodium chloride to precipitate silver chloride (AgCl)."}}

{"explanation": "Pressure significantly affects gas-phase equilibria where the number of moles of gaseous reactants differs from products (Δn_gas ≠ 0). According to Le Châtelier's principle, increasing pressure shifts the equilibrium to the side with fewer gas moles. K_p is the equilibrium constant in terms of partial pressures.", "urdu_meaning": "دباؤ - گیسی توازنات پر اثر انداز ہونے والا عامل؛ K_p اس سے متعلق ہے", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "In the Haber process, high pressure is applied to shift the equilibrium towards ammonia, as this reduces the total number of gas molecules.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Force per unit area; for gas-phase equilibria, changes in pressure can shift the equilibrium position if Δn_gas ≠ 0.", "related_concepts": ["partial pressures", "K_p", "Le Châtelier's principle", "gas-phase reactions", "chemical equilibrium"], "real_world_example": "Using a pressure cooker increases the boiling point of water."}}

{"explanation": "Product concentrations are the amounts of products per unit volume at a given time, especially at equilibrium. They are essential components of the equilibrium expression used to calculate the equilibrium constant (K).", "urdu_meaning": "مصنوعات کا ارتکاز - توازنی مساوات میں شامل مصنوعات کی مقداریں", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "At equilibrium, product concentrations remain constant because the rate of their formation equals the rate of their conversion back to reactants.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Concentrations of substances formed in a reaction; used in the numerator of the equilibrium expression.", "related_concepts": ["reactant concentrations", "equilibrium constant (K_c, K_p)", "equilibrium expression", "Le Châtelier's principle", "chemical equilibrium"], "real_world_example": "Measuring the concentration of NH₃ at equilibrium in the Haber process."}}

{"explanation": "A quantitative measure in chemistry involves numerical values obtained by measurement, such as concentrations, pressures, or temperature, used to describe systems and calculate constants. Equilibrium constants (K_a, K_p, K_sp) are quantitative measures of equilibrium position.", "urdu_meaning": "مقداری پیمائش - کیمیا میں عددی اقدار جو نظاموں کی وضاحت اور مستقلات کا حساب لگانے کے لیے استعمال ہوتی ہیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The equilibrium constant K provides a quantitative measure of how far a reaction proceeds towards products at equilibrium.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Numerical assessment of chemical properties or phenomena, e.g., equilibrium constants providing a numerical value for equilibrium position.", "related_concepts": ["equilibrium constant", "concentration", "pressure", "temperature", "analytical chemistry", "stoichiometry"], "real_world_example": "Using titration to find the exact concentration of an acid (a quantitative measure)."}}

{"explanation": "Quantitative understanding in chemical equilibrium involves using numerical data (concentrations, pressures) and mathematical relationships (equilibrium expressions, K values, ΔG°) to precisely describe and predict the behavior of reversible systems.", "urdu_meaning": "مقداری فہم - قابل واپسی نظاموں کے رویے کی عددی اور ریاضیاتی تفہیم", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Calculating the equilibrium constant K_c from experimental concentrations provides a quantitative understanding of the reaction's extent.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Precise, numerical comprehension of equilibrium systems using data and mathematical models (e.g., K, ΔG°).", "related_concepts": ["equilibrium constant", "Gibbs free energy", "Le Châtelier's principle", "stoichiometry", "thermodynamics", "chemical kinetics"], "real_world_example": "Predicting the exact pH of a buffer solution using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation."}}

{"explanation": "Reactant concentrations are the amounts of reactants per unit volume at a given time, especially at equilibrium. They are crucial components of the equilibrium expression for calculating the equilibrium constant (K).", "urdu_meaning": "متعاملات کا ارتکاز - توازنی مساوات میں شامل متعاملات کی مقداریں", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The equilibrium constant K_c is inversely related to reactant concentrations raised to their stoichiometric powers in the equilibrium expression.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Concentrations of starting materials in a reaction; used in the denominator of the equilibrium expression.", "related_concepts": ["product concentrations", "equilibrium constant (K_c, K_p)", "equilibrium expression", "Le Châtelier's principle", "chemical equilibrium"], "real_world_example": "Monitoring the decrease in reactant concentrations as a reaction approaches equilibrium."}}

{"explanation": "Reactants are the initial substances that undergo chemical change in a reaction. In reversible equilibria, reactants are continuously converted to products while products also revert to reactants, their concentrations being key to defining K.", "urdu_meaning": "متعاملات - کیمیائی تعامل میں حصہ لینے والے ابتدائی مادے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The equilibrium constant expression shows the ratio of product concentrations to reactant concentrations at equilibrium.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Starting substances in a chemical reaction; their concentrations are part of the equilibrium constant expression.", "related_concepts": ["products", "chemical reaction", "chemical equilibrium", "equilibrium expression", "stoichiometry"], "real_world_example": "N₂ and H₂ are reactants in the synthesis of ammonia."}}

{"explanation": "A reaction (chemical reaction) is a process that involves rearrangement of molecular or ionic structure, as opposed to a change in physical form. Reversible reactions can reach a state of equilibrium, described by an equilibrium constant.", "urdu_meaning": "تعامل (کیمیائی تعامل) - مادے کی سالماتی یا آئنی ساخت میں تبدیلی کا عمل", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "The equilibrium constant K gives a quantitative measure of the extent of a reversible reaction at a specific temperature.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Transformation of reactants into products; if reversible, can attain equilibrium characterized by K.", "related_concepts": ["chemical reaction", "reversible reaction", "irreversible reaction", "chemical equilibrium", "equilibrium constant", "reactants", "products"], "real_world_example": "The reaction between an acid and a base to form salt and water."}}

{"explanation": "Reaction enthalpy (ΔH) is the change in enthalpy during a chemical reaction, indicating whether it is exothermic (releases heat, negative ΔH) or endothermic (absorbs heat, positive ΔH). It dictates how temperature affects the equilibrium constant (K) via the van 't Hoff equation.", "urdu_meaning": "تعامل کی اینتھالپی (ΔH) - کیمیائی تعامل کے دوران اینتھالپی میں تبدیلی", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "Knowing the reaction enthalpy allows prediction of how the equilibrium constant will change with temperature.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Heat absorbed or released by a reaction at constant pressure (ΔH); determines temperature dependence of K.", "related_concepts": ["enthalpy", "ΔH", "exothermic reaction", "endothermic reaction", "equilibrium constant (K)", "van 't Hoff equation", "Le Châtelier's principle"], "real_world_example": "The reaction enthalpy for ammonia synthesis is negative, meaning it's exothermic."}}

{"explanation": "Solids are a state of matter with definite shape and volume. In equilibrium expressions for heterogeneous equilibria, the concentrations (or activities) of pure solids are considered constant and are typically incorporated into the equilibrium constant, so they do not appear explicitly.", "urdu_meaning": "ٹھوس مادے - مادے کی ایک حالت؛ خالص ٹھوس کا ارتکاز توازنی مساوات میں مستقل سمجھا جاتا ہے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "In the equilibrium expression for CaCO₃(s) ⇌ CaO(s) + CO₂(g), the solids CaCO₃ and CaO are not included, so K_p = P_CO₂.", "properties": {"key_principle": "State of matter with fixed shape and volume; pure solids have constant activity/concentration in equilibrium expressions.", "related_concepts": ["liquids", "gases", "heterogeneous equilibrium", "activity", "equilibrium expression", "phase"], "real_world_example": "Calcium carbonate (CaCO₃(s)) in its solid form."}}

{"explanation": "Solubility is the maximum amount of a solute that can dissolve in a given amount of solvent at a specific temperature to form a saturated solution. For sparingly soluble salts, solubility is directly related to the solubility product constant (Ksp).", "urdu_meaning": "حل پذیری - کسی محلل میں حل ہونے والے مادے کی زیادہ سے زیادہ مقدار", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The solubility of AgCl in water is very low, as indicated by its small Ksp value.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Maximum concentration of a solute that can dissolve in a solvent at a given temperature; related to Ksp for ionic solids.", "related_concepts": ["solubility product constant (Ksp)", "saturated solution", "dissolution", "sparingly soluble salts", "common ion effect"], "real_world_example": "The solubility of sugar in water increases with temperature."}}

{"explanation": "Solubility product constants (Ksp) are equilibrium constants for the dissolution of sparingly soluble ionic solids into their constituent ions in a saturated solution. They provide a quantitative measure of a salt's solubility.", "urdu_meaning": "حل پذیری حاصل ضرب مستقل (Ksp) - کم حل پذیر آئنی ٹھوس کی حل پذیری کا مقداری پیمانہ", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "Using solubility product constants, one can predict whether a precipitate will form when solutions are mixed.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Equilibrium constant (Ksp) for the dissolution of a sparingly soluble ionic solid (e.g., AgCl(s) ⇌ Ag⁺(aq) + Cl⁻(aq)).", "related_concepts": ["Ksp", "solubility", "sparingly soluble salts", "precipitation reactions", "common ion effect", "saturated solution", "chemical equilibrium"], "real_world_example": "The Ksp of BaSO₄ is 1.1 x 10⁻¹⁰, making it very insoluble."}}

{"explanation": "Sparingly soluble salts are ionic compounds that dissolve to only a very small extent in a given solvent (usually water), establishing a dissolution equilibrium characterized by a small solubility product constant (Ksp).", "urdu_meaning": "کم حل پذیر نمکیات - آئنی مرکبات جو پانی میں بہت کم حل ہوتے ہیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The equilibrium for the dissolution of sparingly soluble salts like silver chloride (AgCl) is described by its Ksp value.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Ionic solids with very low solubility, whose dissolution is an equilibrium process described by Ksp.", "related_concepts": ["solubility", "solubility product constant (Ksp)", "precipitation reactions", "saturated solution", "common ion effect"], "real_world_example": "AgCl, BaSO₄, CaCO₃ are examples of sparingly soluble salts."}}

{"explanation": "Spontaneity refers to the inherent tendency of a process to occur under a given set of conditions without continuous external intervention. It is predicted by the sign of the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG); a negative ΔG indicates spontaneity. ΔG° is related to the equilibrium constant K.", "urdu_meaning": "بے ساختگی / خود بخود پن - کسی عمل کا دیے گئے حالات میں بغیر بیرونی مداخلت کے ہونے کا رجحان", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "A reaction can be thermodynamically spontaneous (negative ΔG) but kinetically very slow if it has a high activation energy.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Tendency of a process to occur naturally; determined by ΔG (negative for spontaneous). ΔG° = -RTlnK links spontaneity to equilibrium position.", "related_concepts": ["Gibbs free energy (ΔG, ΔG°)", "enthalpy (ΔH)", "entropy (ΔS)", "thermodynamics", "chemical equilibrium", "equilibrium constant (K)", "activation energy"], "real_world_example": "Iron rusting is a spontaneous process, though it can be slow."}}

{"explanation": "Stoichiometric coefficients are the numbers appearing before the chemical formulas of reactants and products in a balanced chemical equation. They are used as exponents for the concentrations or partial pressures in the equilibrium expression.", "urdu_meaning": "اسٹوکیومیٹرک عددی سر - متوازن کیمیائی مساوات میں فارمولوں سے پہلے آنے والے اعداد", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "In the equilibrium expression for N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g), the stoichiometric coefficients are 1 for N₂, 3 for H₂, and 2 for NH₃.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Numbers in a balanced chemical equation indicating molar ratios; used as exponents in equilibrium constant expressions.", "related_concepts": ["balanced chemical equation", "equilibrium expression", "equilibrium constant", "stoichiometry", "mole ratio"], "real_world_example": "In 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O, the stoichiometric coefficient for H₂ is 2."}}

{"explanation": "Sulfuric acid (H₂SO₄) is a strong mineral acid and a major industrial chemical produced primarily by the Contact process. This process involves several equilibrium reactions, notably the catalytic oxidation of SO₂ to SO₃.", "urdu_meaning": "سلفیورک ایسڈ - ایک مضبوط تیزاب اور اہم صنعتی کیمیکل، جو کانٹیکٹ پراسس سے بنتا ہے", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "The efficient production of sulfuric acid relies on optimizing the equilibrium conditions in the Contact process.", "properties": {"formula": "H₂SO₄", "molar_mass": "98.079 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "liquid (concentrated form)", "hazards": ["Highly corrosive", "Causes severe burns", "Strong dehydrating agent", "Reacts violently with water (dilution is exothermic)"]}}

{"explanation": "Temperature is a critical factor affecting chemical equilibrium as it is the only variable that changes the value of the equilibrium constant (K). {"explanation": "δG° (Delta G naught), or standard Gibbs free energy change, is the change in Gibbs free energy when a reaction is carried out under standard conditions (1 atm or 1 bar, 298 K, 1 M concentrations). {"explanation": "The bicarbonate buffer system (or carbonic acid-bicarbonate buffer system) is a crucial physiological buffer in blood, maintaining pH homeostasis by managing the equilibrium between carbonic acid (H₂CO₃), bicarbonate ions (HCO₃⁻), and dissolved CO₂.", "urdu_meaning": "بائی کاربونیٹ بفر سسٹم - خون میں pH کو مستحکم رکھنے والا حیاتیاتی بفر نظام", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The bicarbonate buffer system in blood quickly neutralizes excess acids or bases by shifting its chemical equilibria, preventing drastic pH changes.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Major physiological pH buffer: CO₂(aq) + H₂O(l) ⇌ H₂CO₃(aq) ⇌ H⁺(aq) + HCO₃⁻(aq).", "related_concepts": ["carbonic acid-bicarbonate buffer system", "buffer solution", "blood pH", "homeostasis", "carbonic acid", "bicarbonate ion", "Le Châtelier's principle", "biological systems"], "real_world_example": "Maintaining human blood pH within the narrow range of 7.35-7.45."}}
