{"explanation": "Ionic bonds are a type of chemical linkage formed from the electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged ions in a chemical compound, typically formed between a metal and a nonmetal.", "urdu_meaning": "آئنی بندھن - مخالف چارج والے آئنوں کے درمیان برقی سکونی کشش", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Sodium chloride (NaCl) is a classic example of a compound formed by ionic bonds between Na⁺ and Cl⁻ ions.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Electrostatic attraction between cations (positive ions) and anions (negative ions) formed by electron transfer.", "related_concepts": ["chemical bonding", "ions", "cations", "anions", "electron transfer", "electronegativity difference", "crystal lattice", "salts"], "real_world_example": "Table salt (NaCl), magnesium oxide (MgO)."}}

{"explanation": "Iron (Fe) is a chemical element with atomic number 26, a common transition metal that is crucial in many biological processes and is the main component of steel.", "urdu_meaning": "لوہا - ایک کیمیائی عنصر، عبوری دھات", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "The rusting of iron is an oxidation process that forms iron oxides.", "properties": {"symbol": "Fe", "atomic_number": 26, "category": "metal (transition)", "state_room_temp": "solid", "common_uses": ["Steel production", "Construction materials", "Hemoglobin in blood", "Catalyst", "Magnets"]}}

{"explanation": "The lanthanides are a series of 15 metallic chemical elements with atomic numbers from 57 (lanthanum) to 71 (lutetium) in the periodic table, characterized by the filling of the 4f electron subshell.", "urdu_meaning": "لینتھنائڈز - جوہری عدد 57 سے 71 تک کے 15 دھاتی عناصر", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Lanthanides are often referred to as rare earth elements, though many are not particularly rare.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A series of f-block elements (usually La to Lu, or Ce to Lu) where the 4f subshell is progressively filled.", "related_concepts": ["periodic table", "f-block", "actinides", "rare earth elements", "electron configuration", "inner transition metals"], "real_world_example": "Neodymium (Nd) used in strong magnets, Europium (Eu) used in phosphors for displays."}}

{"explanation": "Magnesium (Mg) is a chemical element with atomic number 12, an alkaline earth metal that is lightweight, silvery-white, and essential for many biological functions including chlorophyll.", "urdu_meaning": "میگنیشیم - ایک کیمیائی عنصر، قلوی ارضی دھات", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "Magnesium is used in lightweight alloys for aircraft and car parts, and in fireworks for its bright white flame.", "properties": {"symbol": "Mg", "atomic_number": 12, "category": "metal (alkaline earth)", "state_room_temp": "solid", "common_uses": ["Lightweight alloys", "Flares and pyrotechnics", "Dietary supplement", "Antacids", "Deoxidizer"]}}

{"explanation": "Material science is an interdisciplinary field involving the properties of matter and its applications to various areas of science and engineering, focusing on the design and discovery of new materials.", "urdu_meaning": "مادی سائنس / علم المواد - مادے کی خصوصیات اور اس کے اطلاق کا علم", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The development of new semiconductors and superconductors is a key area of research in material science.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Understanding the relationship between the structure, properties, processing, and performance of materials.", "related_concepts": ["chemistry", "physics", "engineering", "polymers", "ceramics", "metals", "composites", "nanomaterials", "semiconductors", "superconductors"], "real_world_example": "Developing stronger and lighter alloys for aerospace, creating more efficient solar cells, designing biocompatible materials for medical implants."}}

{"explanation": "Metallic character refers to the set of chemical properties associated with metals, including the tendency to lose electrons (form cations), low ionization energy, and formation of basic oxides.", "urdu_meaning": "دھاتی خاصیت - دھاتوں سے وابستہ کیمیائی خصوصیات کا مجموعہ", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "Metallic character generally increases down a group and decreases across a period in the periodic table.", "properties": {"describes": "The extent to which an element exhibits properties typical of metals.", "related_concepts": ["metals", "nonmetals", "metalloids", "periodic trends", "ionization energy", "electronegativity", "electron affinity", "basic oxides"], "example_of_use": "Cesium has a very high metallic character, readily losing its single valence electron.", "measurement_type": "Qualitative assessment based on position in periodic table and observed properties."}}

{"explanation": "The modern periodic table arranges chemical elements by increasing atomic number, organizing them into groups and periods that reflect recurring patterns in their electron configurations and chemical properties.", "urdu_meaning": "جدید دوری جدول - عناصر کی جوہری عدد، الیکٹرانی تشکیل اور کیمیائی خصوصیات کی بنیاد پر ترتیب", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The structure of the modern periodic table allows for the prediction of properties of undiscovered elements.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Systematic arrangement of chemical elements based on atomic number and electron configuration, revealing periodic trends.", "related_concepts": ["atomic number", "electron configuration", "periodicity", "groups", "periods", "blocks (s,p,d,f)", "chemical elements"], "real_world_example": "A fundamental tool in chemistry for organizing elemental information and understanding relationships between elements."}}

{"explanation": "Multiple oxidation states refer to the ability of an element, particularly transition metals, to exist in several different oxidation states (charge states) in its compounds due to the involvement of d-electrons in bonding.", "urdu_meaning": "متعدد تکسیدی حالتیں - ایک عنصر کا مختلف مرکبات میں مختلف چارجز کا حامل ہونا", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "Iron exhibits multiple oxidation states, such as +2 in FeO and +3 in Fe₂O₃.", "properties": {"describes": "The capacity of an element to form compounds with different oxidation numbers.", "related_concepts": ["oxidation state", "transition metals", "d-electrons", "redox reactions", "complex formation", "catalysis"], "example_of_use": "Manganese can exist in various oxidation states from +2 to +7, leading to diverse chemistry.", "measurement_type": "Determined from the stoichiometry of compounds or electrochemical methods."}}

{"explanation": "A noble gas is an element from Group 18 of the periodic table, characterized by a full valence electron shell, making it very stable and largely unreactive.", "urdu_meaning": "نبیل گیس - دوری جدول کے گروپ 18 کا غیر عامل عنصر", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Neon, a noble gas, is used in advertising signs for its bright reddish-orange glow when electricity is passed through it.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Chemically inert gaseous elements with complete valence electron shells (ns²np⁶, except He which is 1s²).", "related_concepts": ["periodic table", "Group 18", "electron configuration", "valence electrons", "octet rule", "chemical inertness", "argon", "helium", "neon"], "real_world_example": "Helium in balloons, Argon for inert atmospheres."}}

{"explanation": "The p-block is the region of the periodic table that includes elements from Groups 13 to 18, whose atoms have their highest energy electrons in p-orbitals.", "urdu_meaning": "پی-بلاک - دوری جدول کا وہ حصہ جہاں عناصر کے بیرونی الیکٹران پی-مدار میں ہوتے ہیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The p-block contains a diverse range of elements, including metals, nonmetals, and metalloids.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Section of the periodic table (Groups 13-18) where the p subshells are being filled with electrons.", "related_concepts": ["periodic table", "electron configuration", "p-orbitals", "p-subshells", "metals", "nonmetals", "metalloids", "halogens", "noble gases"], "real_world_example": "Carbon (C), Nitrogen (N), Oxygen (O), Fluorine (F), and Neon (Ne) are all p-block elements."}}

{"explanation": "P-block elements are those elements in Groups 13-18 of the periodic table where the outermost electrons occupy p-orbitals, and they include metals, metalloids, and nonmetals.", "urdu_meaning": "پی-بلاک عناصر - دوری جدول کے گروہ 13 سے 18 تک کے عناصر", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The p-block elements exhibit a wide variety of chemical and physical properties, from reactive halogens to inert noble gases.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Elements whose valence electrons are in the p subshell.", "related_concepts": ["p-block", "periodic table", "electron configuration", "p-orbitals", "metals", "nonmetals", "metalloids", "halogens", "noble gases", "octet rule"], "real_world_example": "Aluminum (Al), Silicon (Si), Phosphorus (P), Sulfur (S), Chlorine (Cl), Argon (Ar)."}}

{"explanation": "Partially filled d-subshells refer to d-orbitals in transition metal atoms or ions that contain fewer than the maximum possible ten electrons, contributing to their characteristic properties like variable oxidation states and color.", "urdu_meaning": "جزوی طور پر بھرے ہوئے ڈی-سب شیلز - ڈی-مدار جن میں دس سے کم الیکٹران ہوں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The presence of partially filled d-subshells in transition metals allows for d-d electronic transitions, often resulting in colored compounds.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A d subshell containing between one and nine electrons.", "related_concepts": ["d-subshells", "transition metals", "electron configuration", "d-block elements", "colored compounds", "paramagnetism", "multiple oxidation states", "catalysis"], "real_world_example": "The iron(II) ion, Fe²⁺, has a partially filled d-subshell (3d⁶)."}}

{"explanation": "Periods are the horizontal rows in the periodic table, with elements in the same period having the same number of outermost electron shells (principal energy levels).", "urdu_meaning": "ادوار - دوری جدول میں افقی قطاریں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Moving across periods from left to right, the atomic number increases, and properties like electronegativity generally increase.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Horizontal rows in the periodic table indicating the highest principal energy level occupied by electrons.", "related_concepts": ["periodic table", "groups", "electron shells", "atomic number", "periodicity", "electron configuration"], "real_world_example": "Period 3 contains elements from sodium (Na) to argon (Ar), all of which have three electron shells."}}

{"explanation": "Physical properties are characteristics of a substance that can be observed or measured without changing its chemical identity, such as color, melting point, boiling point, density, and conductivity.", "urdu_meaning": "طبیعی خصوصیات - مادے کی وہ خصوصیات جو کیمیائی شناخت تبدیل کیے بغیر معلوم کی جا سکیں", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The high melting point and electrical conductivity of copper are important physical properties that make it useful for wiring.", "properties": {"describes": "Observable characteristics of a substance that do not involve a change in its chemical composition.", "related_concepts": ["chemical properties", "melting point", "boiling point", "density", "color", "hardness", "conductivity", "state of matter"], "example_of_use": "Measuring the density of a liquid to help identify it is assessing one of its physical properties.", "measurement_type": "Direct measurement using instruments (thermometer, balance, ruler, etc.) or observation."}}

{"explanation": "Principal energy levels, also known as electron shells, are discrete energy states that electrons can occupy within an atom, denoted by the principal quantum number (n).", "urdu_meaning": "بنیادی توانائی کی سطحیں - الیکٹران شیلز", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Electrons in higher principal energy levels are generally further from the nucleus and have more energy.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Quantized energy states for electrons in an atom, corresponding to electron shells.", "related_concepts": ["electron shells", "principal quantum number (n)", "atomic structure", "electron configuration", "Bohr model", "quantum mechanics"], "real_world_example": "The first principal energy level (n=1 or K shell) can hold up to 2 electrons; the second (n=2 or L shell) can hold up to 8 electrons."}}

{"explanation": "The principal quantum number (n) is one of the four quantum numbers assigned to each electron in an atom to describe its state, indicating the electron's main energy level or shell.", "urdu_meaning": "بنیادی کوانٹم نمبر - الیکٹران کی بنیادی توانائی کی سطح یا شیل کی نشاندہی کرنے والا عدد", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "An electron with a principal quantum number of n=1 is in the lowest energy shell, closest to the nucleus.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A quantum number (n = 1, 2, 3, ...) that defines the main energy level (shell) of an electron in an atom.", "related_concepts": ["quantum numbers", "electron shells", "principal energy levels", "atomic orbitals", "electron configuration", "atomic structure"], "real_world_example": "For the valence electron of sodium (3s¹), the principal quantum number n is 3."}}

{"explanation": "Radium (Ra) is a chemical element with atomic number 88, a highly radioactive alkaline earth metal that glows faintly in the dark due to its radioactivity.", "urdu_meaning": "ریڈیم - ایک کیمیائی عنصر، انتہائی تابکار قلوی ارضی دھات", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "Radium was formerly used in self-luminous paints for watch dials, but its use has been discontinued due to health concerns.", "properties": {"symbol": "Ra", "atomic_number": 88, "category": "metal (alkaline earth)", "state_room_temp": "solid", "common_uses": ["Historical use in radiotherapy (largely replaced)", "Historical use in luminous paints", "Neutron sources (when mixed with beryllium)"]}}

{"explanation": "Relativistic effects in chemistry become significant for heavy elements, where electrons move at speeds comparable to the speed of light, influencing properties like electron configuration, bond lengths, and colors.", "urdu_meaning": "اضافیاتی اثرات - بھاری عناصر میں الیکٹرانوں کی تیز رفتاری سے پیدا ہونے والے کیمیائی اثرات", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The yellow color of gold and the liquidity of mercury at room temperature are partly due to relativistic effects.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Deviations from non-relativistic quantum mechanics for heavy atoms due to electrons approaching the speed of light near massive nuclei.", "related_concepts": ["heavy elements", "lanthanide contraction", "electron configuration", "atomic properties", "quantum mechanics", "special relativity"], "real_world_example": "The inert pair effect in heavier p-block elements, the color of gold."}}

{"explanation": "The s-block is the region of the periodic table that includes elements in Groups 1 (alkali metals) and 2 (alkaline earth metals), plus helium, whose atoms have their highest energy electrons in s-orbitals.", "urdu_meaning": "ایس-بلاک - دوری جدول کا وہ حصہ جہاں عناصر کے بیرونی الیکٹران ایس-مدار میں ہوتے ہیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Elements in the s-block are generally highly reactive metals, with helium being a notable exception as a noble gas.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Section of the periodic table (Groups 1 & 2, and Helium) where the s subshell is being filled with valence electrons.", "related_concepts": ["periodic table", "alkali metals", "alkaline earth metals", "helium", "electron configuration", "s-orbitals", "s-subshells", "valence electrons"], "real_world_example": "Sodium (Na) and Calcium (Ca) are s-block elements."}}

{"explanation": "S-block elements are those elements in Groups 1 and 2 of the periodic table (and helium) where the outermost electrons are in an s-orbital.", "urdu_meaning": "ایس-بلاک عناصر - دوری جدول کے گروہ 1 اور 2 کے عناصر (اور ہیلیم)", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The s-block elements are typically soft metals with low melting points and high reactivity (except helium).", "properties": {"key_principle": "Elements whose valence electrons occupy the s subshell.", "related_concepts": ["s-block", "periodic table", "alkali metals", "alkaline earth metals", "helium", "electron configuration", "s-orbitals", "valence electrons"], "real_world_example": "Lithium (Li), Magnesium (Mg), Helium (He)."}}

{"explanation": "Semiconductors are materials with electrical conductivity between that of a conductor (like copper) and an insulator (like glass), whose conductivity can be controlled by adding impurities (doping) or by external stimuli.", "urdu_meaning": "نیم موصل - وہ مواد جن کی برقی موصلیت موصل اور غیر موصل کے درمیان ہوتی ہے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Silicon and germanium are common p-block elements used as semiconductors in electronic devices.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Materials with intermediate electrical conductivity that can be modified, crucial for electronics.", "related_concepts": ["conductivity", "conductors", "insulators", "doping", "band theory", "transistors", "diodes", "silicon", "germanium"], "real_world_example": "Silicon used in computer chips, gallium arsenide in high-speed electronics."}}

{"explanation": "Silver (Ag) is a chemical element with atomic number 47, a soft, white, lustrous transition metal known for its very high electrical and thermal conductivity, and its use in jewelry, currency, and photography.", "urdu_meaning": "چاندی - ایک کیمیائی عنصر، قیمتی عبوری دھات", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "Silver halides are light-sensitive compounds used in traditional photographic films.", "properties": {"symbol": "Ag", "atomic_number": 47, "category": "metal (transition)", "state_room_temp": "solid", "common_uses": ["Jewelry", "Coins", "Tableware", "Electronics (conductors, contacts)", "Photography (silver halides)", "Antimicrobial agent", "Mirrors"]}}

{"explanation": "Sodium (Na), an alkali metal in Group 1 of the periodic table with atomic number 11, is a soft, silvery-white, highly reactive metal essential for life.", "urdu_meaning": "سوڈیم - ایک کیمیائی عنصر، الکلی دھات", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "Sodium ions play a crucial role in nerve function and fluid balance in animals.", "properties": {"symbol": "Na", "atomic_number": 11, "category": "metal (alkali)", "state_room_temp": "solid", "common_uses": ["Sodium chloride (table salt)", "Sodium vapor lamps (street lighting)", "Coolant in nuclear reactors", "Manufacture of chemicals (e.g., NaOH)", "Soap production"]}}

{"explanation": "Strontium (Sr) is a chemical element with atomic number 38, an alkaline earth metal that is soft, silvery-white, and highly reactive, known for imparting a crimson color to flames.", "urdu_meaning": "اسٹرانشیم - ایک کیمیائی عنصر، قلوی ارضی دھات", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "Strontium compounds are used in fireworks to produce a brilliant red color.", "properties": {"symbol": "Sr", "atomic_number": 38, "category": "metal (alkaline earth)", "state_room_temp": "solid", "common_uses": ["Fireworks (red color)", "Cathode ray tubes (older televisions)", "Ferrite magnets", "Toothpaste for sensitive teeth", "Medical imaging (radioactive isotopes)"]}}

{"explanation": "Superconductors are materials that exhibit zero electrical resistance and expel magnetic fields (Meissner effect) when cooled below a certain critical temperature.", "urdu_meaning": "فوق موصل - وہ مواد جو ایک خاص درجہ حرارت سے نیچے صفر برقی مزاحمت ظاہر کرتے ہیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Many transition metal alloys and ceramic compounds can become superconductors at very low temperatures.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Materials that conduct electricity with no resistance below a critical temperature (Tc).", "related_concepts": ["electrical resistance", "conductivity", "Meissner effect", "critical temperature", "BCS theory", "high-temperature superconductors", "MRI magnets"], "real_world_example": "Niobium-titanium alloys used in MRI machine magnets; YBCO (yttrium barium copper oxide) high-temperature superconductors."}}

{"explanation": "Transition elements (or transition metals) are elements in the d-block of the periodic table (Groups 3-12), characterized by having partially filled d subshells in their atoms or common ions.", "urdu_meaning": "عبوری عناصر - دوری جدول کے ڈی-بلاک کے عناصر", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Transition elements often form colored compounds and exhibit multiple oxidation states.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Elements found in Groups 3-12, generally possessing partially filled d-orbitals.", "related_concepts": ["d-block", "transition metals", "electron configuration", "d-orbitals", "multiple oxidation states", "colored compounds", "complex formation", "catalysis"], "real_world_example": "Iron, copper, gold, manganese, and chromium are examples of transition elements."}}

{"explanation": "Transition metals are a large group of elements in the d-block of the periodic table, known for properties such as forming colored ions, having variable oxidation states, and acting as good catalysts.", "urdu_meaning": "عبوری دھاتیں - دوری جدول کے ڈی-بلاک کی دھاتیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The catalytic activity of many transition metals stems from their ability to form temporary bonds with reactants using their d-electrons.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Metallic elements in the d-block (Groups 3-12) characterized by partially filled d subshells.", "related_concepts": ["d-block", "transition elements", "electron configuration", "d-orbitals", "multiple oxidation states", "colored compounds", "complex formation", "catalysis", "magnetic properties"], "real_world_example": "Examples include iron (Fe) in hemoglobin, platinum (Pt) in catalytic converters, and titanium (Ti) in strong, lightweight alloys."}}

{"explanation": "A valence electron is an electron in the outermost shell (valence shell) of an atom that is involved in forming chemical bonds with other atoms.", "urdu_meaning": "ویلنس الیکٹران - بیرونی شیل کا الیکٹران جو کیمیائی بندھن میں حصہ لیتا ہے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The number of valence electrons determines an element's chemical reactivity and bonding capacity.", "properties": {"key_principle": "An electron in the outermost occupied electron shell of an atom.", "related_concepts": ["valence shell", "electron configuration", "chemical bonding", "octet rule", "Lewis structures", "periodicity"], "real_world_example": "A carbon atom has four valence electrons."}}

{"explanation": "Valence electron configurations describe the arrangement of electrons specifically in the outermost (valence) shell of an atom, which dictates its chemical behavior and bonding patterns.", "urdu_meaning": "ویلنس الیکٹران تشکیلات - بیرونی شیل میں الیکٹرانوں کی ترتیب", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Elements in the same group of the periodic table share similar valence electron configurations, leading to their similar chemical properties.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The specific arrangement (distribution among orbitals) of electrons in the outermost electron shell.", "related_concepts": ["valence electrons", "electron configuration", "outermost shell", "chemical bonding", "periodicity", "groups", "orbitals"], "real_world_example": "All alkali metals (Group 1) have a valence electron configuration of ns¹, such as sodium (3s¹)."}}

{"explanation": "Valence electrons are the electrons residing in the outermost electron shell of an atom, which are primarily responsible for the atom's chemical properties and its participation in chemical bonding.", "urdu_meaning": "ویلنس الیکٹران - بیرونی شیل میں موجود الیکٹران", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Elements with the same number of valence electrons often exhibit similar chemical behavior.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Electrons in the highest occupied principal energy level of an atom that determine chemical reactivity.", "related_concepts": ["electron shells", "outermost shell", "electron configuration", "chemical bonding", "octet rule", "Lewis dot structures", "periodicity"], "real_world_example": "Oxygen has 6 valence electrons, while sodium has 1 valence electron."}}

{"explanation": "Vertical columns in the periodic table are known as groups or families, and elements within the same vertical column share similar chemical properties due to having similar valence electron configurations.", "urdu_meaning": "عمودی قطاریں - دوری جدول میں گروپس یا خاندان", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Elements in the first vertical column of the periodic table are the alkali metals.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Columns in the periodic table grouping elements with similar outer electron configurations and thus similar chemical behavior.", "related_concepts": ["groups", "families", "periodic table", "valence electrons", "chemical properties", "periodicity"], "real_world_example": "The vertical column labeled Group 18 contains the noble gases."}}

{"explanation": "Acid-base chemistry is a branch of chemistry that studies the properties and reactions of acids and bases, including concepts like pH, neutralization, and buffer systems.", "urdu_meaning": "تیزاب-اساس کیمیا - تیزاب اور اساس کی خصوصیات اور تعاملات کا علم", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The Brønsted-Lowry theory is a fundamental concept in acid-base chemistry, defining acids as proton donors and bases as proton acceptors.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Study of chemical species that donate or accept protons (Brønsted-Lowry) or electron pairs (Lewis), or produce H⁺ or OH⁻ ions in water (Arrhenius).", "related_concepts": ["acids", "bases", "pH", "pOH", "neutralization", "buffers", "titration", "indicators", "Brønsted-Lowry theory", "Lewis theory"], "real_world_example": "Determining the acidity of vinegar, the action of antacids, or maintaining blood pH."}}

{"explanation": "Acidic nature refers to the tendency of a substance to act as an acid, typically by donating protons, accepting electrons, or producing H⁺ ions in solution, resulting in a pH below 7.", "urdu_meaning": "تیزابی خاصیت - کسی مادے کا تیزاب کے طور پر عمل کرنے کا رجحان", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "Non-metal oxides often exhibit an acidic nature when dissolved in water, forming oxyacids.", "properties": {"describes": "The tendency of a substance to behave as an acid.", "related_concepts": ["acidity", "pH", "acids", "proton donor", "electron acceptor", "non-metal oxides"], "example_of_use": "The acidic nature of CO₂ in water leads to the formation of carbonic acid.", "measurement_type": "pH measurement, reaction with bases, indicator tests."}}

{"explanation": "Alkali metals are the elements in Group 1 of the periodic table (excluding hydrogen), characterized by their single valence electron, high reactivity, and formation of +1 cations.", "urdu_meaning": "الکلی دھاتیں - دوری جدول کے گروپ 1 کے عناصر", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Alkali metals react vigorously with water to produce hydrogen gas and alkaline solutions.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Group 1 elements (Li, Na, K, Rb, Cs, Fr) with ns¹ valence electron configuration, making them soft, highly reactive metals.", "related_concepts": ["Group 1", "periodic table", "s-block", "valence electrons", "reactivity", "metallic properties", "ions"], "real_world_example": "Sodium (Na) used in streetlights, Lithium (Li) in batteries, Potassium (K) as a nutrient."}}

{"explanation": "Alkalis are strong bases that are soluble in water, typically hydroxides of alkali metals or alkaline earth metals, producing solutions with a pH greater than 7.", "urdu_meaning": "الکلی / قلویات - پانی میں حل پذیر مضبوط اساس", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Sodium hydroxide and potassium hydroxide are common strong alkalies used in laboratories and industry.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Water-soluble bases, often metal hydroxides, that yield high concentrations of OH⁻ ions in solution.", "related_concepts": ["bases", "alkaline solutions", "pH", "hydroxide ion", "neutralization", "alkali metals", "alkaline earth metals"], "real_world_example": "Lye (NaOH) used in soap making; solutions of ammonia in water."}}

{"explanation": "Alkaline solutions are aqueous solutions having a pH greater than 7, indicating a higher concentration of hydroxide ions (OH⁻) than hydrogen ions (H⁺), and are also known as basic solutions.", "urdu_meaning": "اساسی محلول / قلوی محلول - پی ایچ 7 سے زیادہ والے آبی محلول", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The reaction of alkali metals with water produces strongly alkaline solutions.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Aqueous solutions with pH > 7, containing a predominance of OH⁻ ions over H⁺ ions.", "related_concepts": ["pH", "bases", "alkalies", "hydroxide ion", "acidity", "neutrality"], "real_world_example": "Soapy water, household ammonia cleaner, solutions of sodium hydroxide."}}

{"explanation": "Anions are negatively charged ions formed when an atom or molecule gains one or more electrons.", "urdu_meaning": "این آئن - منفی چارج والے آئن", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Halogens readily form anions with a -1 charge, such as the chloride ion (Cl⁻).", "properties": {"key_principle": "Atoms or molecules that have gained electrons, resulting in a net negative charge.", "related_concepts": ["ions", "cations", "electrons", "ionic bonding", "electronegativity", "non-metals"], "real_world_example": "Chloride (Cl⁻), Oxide (O²⁻), Sulfate (SO₄²⁻)."}}

{"explanation": "Atomic size refers to the physical dimension of an atom, typically measured by its atomic radius, and shows periodic trends across the periodic table.", "urdu_meaning": "جوہری جسامت - جوہر کا حجم یا رداس", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "Atomic size generally increases down a group in the periodic table due to the addition of electron shells.", "properties": {"describes": "The dimensions of an atom, often represented by its radius.", "related_concepts": ["atomic radius", "periodic trends", "electron shells", "effective nuclear charge", "shielding effect"], "example_of_use": "The larger atomic size of cesium compared to lithium affects its ionization energy.", "measurement_type": "Picometers (pm) or Angstroms (Å), derived from various experimental or theoretical methods."}}

{"explanation": "Barium (Ba) is a soft, silvery alkaline earth metal in Group 2 of the periodic table, highly reactive and forming +2 ions.", "urdu_meaning": "بیریم - ایک کیمیائی عنصر، قلوی ارضی دھات", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "Barium compounds, like barium sulfate, are used in medical imaging as contrast agents.", "properties": {"symbol": "Ba", "atomic_number": 56, "category": "metal (alkaline earth)", "state_room_temp": "solid", "common_uses": ["Radiocontrast agent (BaSO₄)", "Fireworks (green color)", "Getter in vacuum tubes", "Oil and gas drilling fluids (BaSO₄)"]}}

{"explanation": "Basic nature refers to the tendency of a substance to act as a base, typically by accepting protons, donating electrons, or producing OH⁻ ions in solution, resulting in a pH above 7.", "urdu_meaning": "اساسی خاصیت - کسی مادے کا اساس کے طور پر عمل کرنے کا رجحان", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "Metal oxides, especially those of alkali and alkaline earth metals, generally exhibit a basic nature.", "properties": {"describes": "The tendency of a substance to behave as a base.", "related_concepts": ["basicity", "pH", "bases", "proton acceptor", "electron donor", "metal oxides", "alkalies"], "example_of_use": "The basic nature of ammonia allows it to neutralize acids.", "measurement_type": "pH measurement, reaction with acids, indicator tests."}}

{"explanation": "Basic oxides are chemical compounds, typically formed from metals (especially alkali and alkaline earth metals), that react with water to form bases (hydroxides) or neutralize acids to form salts and water.", "urdu_meaning": "اساسی آکسائیڈ - دھاتی آکسائیڈ جو تیزاب کو بے اثر کرتے ہیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Calcium oxide (CaO), a basic oxide, reacts with acidic soil to neutralize it.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Oxides that form alkaline solutions with water or react as bases with acids.", "related_concepts": ["oxides", "metal oxides", "bases", "alkalies", "acid-base reactions", "neutralization", "acidic oxides"], "real_world_example": "Sodium oxide (Na₂O) reacting with water to form sodium hydroxide; Magnesium oxide (MgO) used as an antacid."}}

{"explanation": "Bromine (Br) is a halogen element in Group 17, existing as a reddish-brown volatile liquid at room temperature, and is highly reactive.", "urdu_meaning": "برومین - ایک کیمیائی عنصر، ہیلوجن", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "Bromine is used in flame retardants, water purification, and as a reagent in organic synthesis.", "properties": {"symbol": "Br", "atomic_number": 35, "category": "nonmetal (halogen)", "state_room_temp": "liquid", "common_uses": ["Flame retardants", "Pesticides", "Water treatment", "Pharmaceuticals", "Dyes"]}}

{"explanation": "Calcium (Ca) is an alkaline earth metal in Group 2, essential for living organisms, particularly for bone and teeth structure, and muscle function.", "urdu_meaning": "کیلشیم - ایک کیمیائی عنصر، قلوی ارضی دھات", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "Calcium reacts with water to form calcium hydroxide and hydrogen gas.", "properties": {"symbol": "Ca", "atomic_number": 20, "category": "metal (alkaline earth)", "state_room_temp": "solid", "common_uses": ["Cement and mortar (as CaO, CaCO₃)", "Dietary supplement", "Alloys", "Reducing agent", "Production of other metals"]}}

{"explanation": "Calcium hydroxide, Ca(OH)₂, also known as slaked lime, is an inorganic compound formed when calcium oxide reacts with water; it is a white powder or colorless crystal and a common base.", "urdu_meaning": "کیلشیم ہائیڈروآکسائیڈ - بجھا ہوا چونا", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "A suspension of calcium hydroxide in water, called limewater, is used to test for carbon dioxide.", "properties": {"formula": "Ca(OH)₂", "molar_mass": "74.093 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "solid", "hazards": ["Skin irritant", "Eye damage risk", "Harmful if inhaled (dust)"]}}

{"explanation": "Cations are positively charged ions formed when an atom or molecule loses one or more electrons.", "urdu_meaning": "کیٹ آئن - مثبت چارج والے آئن", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Alkali metals readily form cations with a +1 charge, such as the sodium ion (Na⁺).", "properties": {"key_principle": "Atoms or molecules that have lost electrons, resulting in a net positive charge.", "related_concepts": ["ions", "anions", "electrons", "ionic bonding", "electropositivity", "metals"], "real_world_example": "Sodium ion (Na⁺), Calcium ion (Ca²⁺), Ammonium ion (NH₄⁺)."}}

{"explanation": "Cesium (Cs) is an alkali metal in Group 1, known for being extremely reactive, soft, and silvery-gold, and is the most electropositive of all stable elements.", "urdu_meaning": "سیزیم - ایک کیمیائی عنصر، الکلی دھات", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "Cesium is used in atomic clocks due to the precise frequency of its atomic oscillations.", "properties": {"symbol": "Cs", "atomic_number": 55, "category": "metal (alkali)", "state_room_temp": "solid (melts near room temp, 28.4 °C)", "common_uses": ["Atomic clocks", "Photoelectric cells", "Catalyst promoter", "Drilling fluids"]}}

{"explanation": "Chemical behavior describes how a substance reacts or changes chemically in different environments or with other substances, largely determined by its electronic structure.", "urdu_meaning": "کیمیائی رویہ - کسی مادے کا مختلف حالات میں کیمیائی طور پر ردعمل ظاہر کرنا", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The chemical behavior of elements in the same group of the periodic table is often similar due to their analogous valence electron configurations.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The characteristic ways a substance interacts chemically, including its reactivity, types of bonds formed, and reaction products.", "related_concepts": ["chemical properties", "reactivity", "electronic structure", "valence electrons", "periodic trends", "bonding"], "real_world_example": "The inert chemical behavior of noble gases; the reactive chemical behavior of alkali metals with water."}}

{"explanation": "Chemical properties are characteristics of a substance that determine how it will react with other substances or change from one substance to another.", "urdu_meaning": "کیمیائی خصوصیات - مادے کی کیمیائی تبدیلی کی صلاحیتیں", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The tendency of halogens to gain electrons is a key aspect of their chemical properties.", "properties": {"describes": "A substance's potential to undergo chemical change or reaction based on its composition.", "related_concepts": ["reactivity", "flammability", "oxidation state", "acidity", "basicity", "heat of reaction", "electronegativity", "ionization energy"], "example_of_use": "Studying the chemical properties of alkali metals reveals their high reactivity with water.", "measurement_type": "Observation of reactions, calorimetry, electrochemical cells, spectroscopy."}}

{"explanation": "Chlorine (Cl) is a highly reactive halogen element in Group 17, existing as a greenish-yellow gas at room temperature, and is a strong oxidizing agent.", "urdu_meaning": "کلورین - ایک کیمیائی عنصر، ہیلوجن", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "Chlorine is widely used as a disinfectant for water supplies and in the production of bleach.", "properties": {"symbol": "Cl", "atomic_number": 17, "category": "nonmetal (halogen)", "state_room_temp": "gas", "common_uses": ["Water disinfection", "Bleach manufacturing", "PVC production", "Solvents", "Pharmaceuticals"]}}

{"explanation": "Colors in chemistry often refer to the characteristic appearance of chemical compounds due to their selective absorption and reflection of visible light, which is related to their electronic structure.", "urdu_meaning": "رنگ - کیمیائی مرکبات کی ظاہری شکل", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "Many transition metal compounds exhibit vibrant colors due to d-d electron transitions.", "properties": {"describes": "The visual perception of light reflected or emitted by a substance.", "related_concepts": ["spectroscopy", "electron transitions", "chromophore", "pigments", "dyes", "transition metal compounds", "conjugated systems"], "example_of_use": "The deep purple color of potassium permanganate is a distinctive property.", "measurement_type": "Visual observation, spectrophotometry."}}

{"explanation": "Compounds are substances formed when two or more different chemical elements are chemically bonded together in a fixed ratio.", "urdu_meaning": "مرکبات - دو یا زیادہ عناصر کے کیمیائی ملاپ سے بننے والے مادے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Water (H₂O) and sodium chloride (NaCl) are common examples of chemical compounds.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Substances made of atoms of different elements joined by chemical bonds in definite proportions.", "related_concepts": ["chemical bonding", "elements", "molecules", "ionic compounds", "covalent compounds", "chemical formula", "stoichiometry"], "real_world_example": "Carbon dioxide (CO₂), sulfuric acid (H₂SO₄), glucose (C₆H₁₂O₆)."}}

{"explanation": "An electron is a stable subatomic particle with a negative electric charge, found orbiting the nucleus of an atom and involved in chemical bonding.", "urdu_meaning": "الیکٹران - منفی چارج والا جوہری ذرہ", "term_type": "other", "example_sentence": "The transfer or sharing of an electron between atoms leads to the formation of chemical bonds.", "properties": {"description": "A fundamental, negatively charged subatomic particle.", "contextual_relevance": "Crucial for atomic structure, chemical bonding, electricity, and many other physical and chemical phenomena. Its arrangement dictates an atom's properties."}}

{"explanation": "Electronegative describes the tendency of an atom to attract electrons towards itself when forming a chemical bond.", "urdu_meaning": "برقی منفی - الیکٹرانوں کو اپنی طرف کھینچنے والا", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "Fluorine is the most electronegative element, strongly attracting electrons in bonds.", "properties": {"describes": "The ability of an atom to attract shared electrons in a covalent bond.", "related_concepts": ["electronegativity", "chemical bonding", "polarity", "non-metals", "halogens", "periodic trends"], "example_of_use": "Oxygen is more electronegative than hydrogen, making the O-H bond in water polar.", "measurement_type": "Measured by electronegativity scales (e.g., Pauling, Mulliken)."}}

{"explanation": "Electronic arrangement, or electronic configuration, describes how electrons are distributed among the various atomic orbitals (shells and subshells) of an atom.", "urdu_meaning": "الیکٹرانی ترتیب - ایٹم میں الیکٹرانوں کی تقسیم", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The electronic arrangement of an atom determines its chemical properties and how it will bond with other atoms.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The distribution of electrons of an atom or molecule in atomic or molecular orbitals.", "related_concepts": ["electronic configuration", "electron shells", "orbitals", "Aufbau principle", "Hund's rule", "valence electrons"], "real_world_example": "The electronic arrangement of Neon is 1s²2s²2p⁶."}}

{"explanation": "Electronic configurations specify the distribution of electrons within the energy levels and sublevels of an atom, dictating its chemical behavior.", "urdu_meaning": "الیکٹرانی تشکیلات - ایٹموں میں الیکٹرانوں کی ترتیب", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Elements in the same group of the periodic table have similar valence electronic configurations.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The detailed description of how electrons are arranged in an atom's orbitals.", "related_concepts": ["electron shells", "atomic orbitals (s, p, d, f)", "Aufbau principle", "Hund's rule", "Pauli exclusion principle", "valence electrons", "periodicity"], "real_world_example": "The electronic configuration for sodium (Na) is 1s²2s²2p⁶3s¹."}}

{"explanation": "Electronic structure refers to the arrangement of electrons in an atom, molecule, or solid, including their energy levels, orbitals, and how they influence chemical and physical properties.", "urdu_meaning": "الیکٹرانی ساخت - ایٹم یا مالیکیول میں الیکٹرانوں کی مکمل ترتیب اور توانائی کی سطحیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Understanding the electronic structure of materials is crucial for designing new technologies like semiconductors.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The description of electron energies and spatial distributions in a chemical system.", "related_concepts": ["electronic configuration", "atomic orbitals", "molecular orbitals", "band theory", "quantum mechanics", "chemical bonding"], "real_world_example": "The electronic structure of benzene explains its aromaticity and stability."}}

{"explanation": "Electrons are negatively charged subatomic particles that orbit the nucleus of an atom and are primarily responsible for chemical bonding and electrical phenomena.", "urdu_meaning": "الیکٹران (جمع) - منفی چارج والے جوہری ذرات", "term_type": "other", "example_sentence": "The number and arrangement of electrons in an atom determine its chemical properties.", "properties": {"description": "Plural of electron, referring to multiple negatively charged subatomic particles.", "contextual_relevance": "Their behavior and distribution are central to all of chemistry, from atomic structure to reactions."}}

{"explanation": "Electropositive describes the tendency of an atom to lose electrons and form positive ions (cations) during chemical reactions.", "urdu_meaning": "برقی مثبت - الیکٹران کھونے اور مثبت آئن بنانے کا رجحان", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "Alkali metals are highly electropositive elements, readily losing their single valence electron.", "properties": {"describes": "The tendency of an element to lose electrons and form positive ions.", "related_concepts": ["electropositivity", "metals", "alkali metals", "alkaline earth metals", "ionization energy", "cations", "periodic trends"], "example_of_use": "Cesium is the most electropositive stable element.", "measurement_type": "Qualitative assessment based on ionization energy and position in periodic table."}}

{"explanation": "Elements are fundamental pure substances consisting of only one type of atom, distinguished by their atomic number (number of protons).", "urdu_meaning": "عناصر - ایک ہی قسم کے ایٹموں پر مشتمل خالص مادے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The periodic table organizes all known chemical elements according to their properties.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A pure substance made up of atoms that all have the same number of protons in their nuclei.", "related_concepts": ["atom", "atomic number", "periodic table", "compounds", "isotopes"], "real_world_example": "Hydrogen (H), Oxygen (O), Iron (Fe), Gold (Au)."}}

{"explanation": "Fluorine (F) is the most electronegative and reactive halogen element (Group 17), existing as a pale yellow-green diatomic gas.", "urdu_meaning": "فلورین - ایک کیمیائی عنصر، سب سے زیادہ برقی منفی ہیلوجن", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "Fluorine's high reactivity makes it useful in producing specialized polymers like Teflon and in uranium enrichment.", "properties": {"symbol": "F", "atomic_number": 9, "category": "nonmetal (halogen)", "state_room_temp": "gas", "common_uses": ["Production of fluorocarbons (e.g., refrigerants, Teflon)", "Toothpaste (as fluoride salts)", "Uranium processing", "Rocket propellant oxidizer"]}}

{"explanation": "Francium (Fr) is an extremely rare and highly radioactive alkali metal in Group 1, the second most electropositive element after cesium (among those with known chemistry).", "urdu_meaning": "فرانسیم - ایک کیمیائی عنصر، انتہائی تابکار الکلی دھات", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "Due to its extreme instability and rarity, francium has no significant commercial applications and is primarily studied in research laboratories.", "properties": {"symbol": "Fr", "atomic_number": 87, "category": "metal (alkali)", "state_room_temp": "solid (predicted, but rarely observed due to radioactivity)", "common_uses": ["Scientific research (due to rarity and radioactivity)"]}}

{"explanation": "Group 1 of the periodic table contains the alkali metals (Li, Na, K, Rb, Cs, Fr), which are highly reactive metals with one valence electron.", "urdu_meaning": "گروپ 1 - دوری جدول کا پہلا گروہ (الکلی دھاتیں)", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Elements in Group 1 readily lose their single valence electron to form +1 cations.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The first vertical column in the periodic table (excluding hydrogen for chemical group properties) housing the alkali metals.", "related_concepts": ["alkali metals", "periodic table", "s-block", "valence electrons (ns¹)", "reactivity", "electropositivity"], "real_world_example": "Sodium (Na) and potassium (K) are well-known members of Group 1."}}

{"explanation": "Group 1 elements, also known as the alkali metals, are characterized by having a single electron in their outermost s-orbital (ns¹ configuration), leading to high reactivity.", "urdu_meaning": "گروپ 1 عناصر - الکلی دھاتیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The chemical properties of Group 1 elements, such as their vigorous reaction with water, are due to their tendency to lose one electron.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Elements in the first column of the periodic table (Li, Na, K, Rb, Cs, Fr) possessing one valence electron.", "related_concepts": ["alkali metals", "Group 1", "periodic table", "s-block", "valence electron configuration (ns¹)", "reactivity", "electropositive character"], "real_world_example": "Lithium in batteries, sodium in table salt."}}

{"explanation": "Group 13 of the periodic table, also known as the boron group, includes elements like boron, aluminum, gallium, indium, and thallium, typically having three valence electrons (ns²np¹).", "urdu_meaning": "گروپ 13 - دوری جدول کا تیرہواں گروہ (بورون گروپ)", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Aluminum, a common Group 13 element, is a lightweight and corrosion-resistant metal.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The thirteenth vertical column in the periodic table containing elements with three valence electrons (ns²np¹).", "related_concepts": ["periodic table", "p-block", "boron group", "valence electrons", "metals", "metalloids (boron)"], "real_world_example": "Boron (B) used in borosilicate glass, Aluminum (Al) in construction and packaging."}}

{"explanation": "Group 16 of the periodic table, also known as the chalcogens, includes elements like oxygen, sulfur, selenium, tellurium, and polonium, typically having six valence electrons (ns²np⁴).", "urdu_meaning": "گروپ 16 - دوری جدول کا سولہواں گروہ (چیلکوجنز)", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Oxygen and sulfur are important Group 16 elements with diverse roles in chemistry and biology.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The sixteenth vertical column in the periodic table containing elements with six valence electrons (ns²np⁴).", "related_concepts": ["periodic table", "p-block", "chalcogens", "valence electrons", "non-metals", "metalloids"], "real_world_example": "Oxygen (O) essential for respiration, Sulfur (S) used in sulfuric acid production."}}

{"explanation": "Group 17 of the periodic table contains the halogens (F, Cl, Br, I, At, Ts), which are highly reactive nonmetals with seven valence electrons (ns²np⁵).", "urdu_meaning": "گروپ 17 - دوری جدول کا سترھواں گروہ (ہیلوجنز)", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Halogens in Group 17 readily form -1 ions by gaining one electron to achieve a stable octet.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The seventeenth vertical column in the periodic table housing the halogens.", "related_concepts": ["halogens", "periodic table", "p-block", "valence electrons (ns²np⁵)", "reactivity", "electronegativity", "non-metals"], "real_world_example": "Fluorine (F), Chlorine (Cl), Bromine (Br), Iodine (I)."}}

{"explanation": "Group 17 elements, known as halogens, are characterized by having seven valence electrons and are highly reactive nonmetals that readily form salts with metals.", "urdu_meaning": "گروپ 17 عناصر - ہیلوجنز", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The high electronegativity of Group 17 elements contributes to their strong oxidizing power.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Elements in the seventeenth column of the periodic table (F, Cl, Br, I, At, Ts) possessing seven valence electrons.", "related_concepts": ["halogens", "Group 17", "periodic table", "p-block", "valence electron configuration (ns²np⁵)", "reactivity", "electronegative character"], "real_world_example": "Chlorine used for disinfection, iodine as an antiseptic."}}

{"explanation": "Group 2 of the periodic table contains the alkaline earth metals (Be, Mg, Ca, Sr, Ba, Ra), which are reactive metals with two valence electrons.", "urdu_meaning": "گروپ 2 - دوری جدول کا دوسرا گروہ (قلوی ارضی دھاتیں)", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Elements in Group 2 typically form +2 cations and their oxides are basic.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The second vertical column in the periodic table housing the alkaline earth metals.", "related_concepts": ["alkaline earth metals", "periodic table", "s-block", "valence electrons (ns²)", "reactivity"], "real_world_example": "Magnesium (Mg) in alloys, Calcium (Ca) in bones."}}

{"explanation": "Half-life (t½) is the time required for a quantity (often of a radioactive substance) to reduce to half of its initial value through decay or elimination.", "urdu_meaning": "نصف حیات - تابکار مادے کی نصف مقدار کے خاتمے کا وقت", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The half-life of Carbon-14 is approximately 5730 years, making it useful for radiometric dating.", "properties": {"describes": "The time taken for half of a radioactive isotope's nuclei to decay, or for the concentration of a substance to halve.", "related_concepts": ["radioactive decay", "radioactivity", "decay constant", "radiometric dating", "nuclear chemistry", "pharmacokinetics"], "example_of_use": "Knowing the half-life of a radioisotope helps determine how long it will remain significantly radioactive.", "measurement_type": "Units of time (seconds, minutes, hours, years)."}}

{"explanation": "Halogens are the reactive nonmetallic elements in Group 17 of the periodic table (fluorine, chlorine, bromine, iodine, astatine, and tennessine), characterized by having seven valence electrons.", "urdu_meaning": "ہیلوجنز - دوری جدول کے گروپ 17 کے عناصر", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Halogens readily react with metals to form salts, such as sodium chloride (NaCl).", "properties": {"key_principle": "Group 17 elements, ns²np⁵ valence electron configuration, highly reactive nonmetals that form -1 ions.", "related_concepts": ["Group 17", "periodic table", "p-block", "nonmetals", "valence electrons", "electronegativity", "oxidizing agents"], "real_world_example": "Chlorine (Cl) in bleach, Iodine (I) in antiseptics, Fluorine (F) in Teflon."}}

{"explanation": "Hydrogen (H) is the lightest chemical element with atomic number 1. It can exhibit properties of both Group 1 (forming H⁺) and Group 17 (forming H⁻, hydride ion) but is unique.", "urdu_meaning": "ہائیڈروجن - ایک کیمیائی عنصر", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "Hydrogen reacts with oxygen to form water, releasing a significant amount of energy.", "properties": {"symbol": "H", "atomic_number": 1, "category": "nonmetal (unique position, can act like alkali metal or halogen)", "state_room_temp": "gas (as H₂)", "common_uses": ["Ammonia production", "Hydrogenation of oils", "Fuel cells", "Rocket fuel", "Welding"]}}

{"explanation": "Hydrogen gas (H₂) is a colorless, odorless, highly flammable diatomic molecule, the most abundant chemical substance in the universe.", "urdu_meaning": "ہائیڈروجن گیس - H₂ مالیکیول", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "Alkali metals react with water to produce hydrogen gas and a metal hydroxide.", "properties": {"formula": "H₂", "molar_mass": "2.016 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Extremely flammable", "Explosive mixtures with air"]}}

{"explanation": "Hydroxide is a diatomic anion with chemical formula OH⁻, consisting of an oxygen and a hydrogen atom held together by a covalent bond, and carrying a negative electric charge. It is an important component of bases.", "urdu_meaning": "ہائیڈروآکسائیڈ - OH⁻ آئن", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Alkali metal hydroxides, like sodium hydroxide (NaOH), are strong bases because they completely dissociate to produce hydroxide ions in water.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The OH⁻ anion, characteristic of bases and alkaline solutions.", "related_concepts": ["bases", "alkalies", "pH", "neutralization", "metal hydroxides"], "real_world_example": "Sodium hydroxide (NaOH), Potassium hydroxide (KOH), Calcium hydroxide (Ca(OH)₂)."}}

{"explanation": "Iodine (I) is a halogen element in Group 17, existing as a lustrous, purple-black crystalline solid at room temperature, which sublimes to form a violet gas.", "urdu_meaning": "آیوڈین - ایک کیمیائی عنصر، ہیلوجن", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "Iodine is used as an antiseptic (tincture of iodine) and is an essential nutrient for thyroid hormone production.", "properties": {"symbol": "I", "atomic_number": 53, "category": "nonmetal (halogen)", "state_room_temp": "solid", "common_uses": ["Antiseptics", "Dietary supplement (iodized salt)", "Catalyst", "Polarizing filters", "Photography (historically)"]}}

{"explanation": "Ion charge is the net electric charge of an ion, which results from an atom or molecule losing (positive charge, cation) or gaining (negative charge, anion) electrons.", "urdu_meaning": "آئن کا چارج - آئن پر موجود برقی چارج", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The ion charge of a sodium ion is +1, while the ion charge of a chloride ion is -1.", "properties": {"describes": "The net electrical charge of an ion.", "related_concepts": ["ions", "cations", "anions", "oxidation state", "electron transfer", "ionic bonding"], "example_of_use": "The ion charge determines the stoichiometry in ionic compounds, like Mg²⁺ and Cl⁻ forming MgCl₂.", "measurement_type": "Integer value representing multiples of the elementary charge (e.g., +1, -2)."}}

{"explanation": "Ionic bonding is a type of chemical bond formed through an electrostatic attraction between two oppositely charged ions, typically a metal cation and a nonmetal anion.", "urdu_meaning": "آئنی بندھن - مخالف چارج والے آئنوں کے درمیان کشش", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "The strong ionic bonding in sodium chloride results in its high melting point.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Attraction between oppositely charged ions formed by the complete transfer of one or more electrons from one atom to another.", "related_concepts": ["ions", "cations", "anions", "electron transfer", "electrostatic force", "crystal lattice", "salts", "electronegativity difference"], "real_world_example": "Formation of NaCl from Na and Cl atoms; formation of MgO from Mg and O atoms."}}

{"explanation": "Ionic charge refers to the electrical charge an atom or group of atoms acquires when it loses or gains electrons, becoming an ion.", "urdu_meaning": "آئنی چارج - آئن پر برقی چارج", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "Alkali metals typically form ions with an ionic charge of +1.", "properties": {"describes": "The net positive or negative charge on an ion.", "related_concepts": ["ion", "cation", "anion", "oxidation state", "electron transfer"], "example_of_use": "The ionic charge of oxide is -2 (O²⁻).", "measurement_type": "Expressed as a multiple of the elementary charge (e.g., +1, -2, +3)."}}

{"explanation": "Ionic compounds are chemical compounds composed of ions held together by electrostatic forces termed ionic bonding, typically formed between metals and nonmetals.", "urdu_meaning": "آئنی مرکبات - آئنوں کے درمیان آئنی بندھن سے بننے والے مرکبات", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Many ionic compounds, like salts, are crystalline solids at room temperature and conduct electricity when molten or dissolved.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Compounds formed by the electrostatic attraction of cations and anions, usually arranged in a crystal lattice structure.", "related_concepts": ["ionic bonding", "ions", "cations", "anions", "salts", "crystal lattice", "electrolytes", "metals", "nonmetals"], "real_world_example": "Sodium chloride (NaCl), magnesium oxide (MgO), copper(II) sulfate (CuSO₄)."}}

{"explanation": "Ionization energy is the energy required to remove an electron from a gaseous atom or ion, reflecting how strongly an atom holds onto its electrons.", "urdu_meaning": "آئنائزیشن توانائی - ایٹم سے الیکٹران نکالنے کے لیے درکار توانائی", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "Alkali metals have low first ionization energy values, making it relatively easy for them to lose an electron.", "properties": {"describes": "The minimum energy needed to remove an electron from a neutral atom in its gaseous state.", "related_concepts": ["periodic trends", "atomic size", "effective nuclear charge", "electron affinity", "electronegativity", "cation formation"], "example_of_use": "The high ionization energy of noble gases contributes to their inertness.", "measurement_type": "Kilojoules per mole (kJ/mol) or electronvolts (eV)."}}

{"explanation": "Ions are atoms or molecules that have gained or lost one or more electrons, resulting in a net positive (cation) or negative (anion) electrical charge.", "urdu_meaning": "آئن - چارج شدہ ایٹم یا مالیکیول", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The formation of ions is crucial for ionic bonding and many chemical reactions.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Charged chemical species formed by the gain or loss of electrons.", "related_concepts": ["cations", "anions", "electron transfer", "ionic bonding", "oxidation state", "electrolytes"], "real_world_example": "Na⁺ (sodium ion), Cl⁻ (chloride ion), SO₄²⁻ (sulfate ion)."}}

{"explanation": "Lithium (Li) is the lightest alkali metal (Group 1), known for its high reactivity, low density, and use in rechargeable batteries.", "urdu_meaning": "لیتھیم - ایک کیمیائی عنصر، الکلی دھات", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "Lithium-ion batteries are widely used in portable electronic devices due to their high energy density.", "properties": {"symbol": "Li", "atomic_number": 3, "category": "metal (alkali)", "state_room_temp": "solid", "common_uses": ["Rechargeable batteries", "Alloys (with aluminum, magnesium)", "Greases", "Mood-stabilizing drugs", "Glass and ceramics"]}}

{"explanation": "Magnesium (Mg) is an alkaline earth metal (Group 2), a lightweight, silvery-white, and fairly reactive element essential for biological processes like photosynthesis.", "urdu_meaning": "میگنیشیم - ایک کیمیائی عنصر، قلوی ارضی دھات", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "Magnesium burns with a brilliant white light and is used in flares and fireworks.", "properties": {"symbol": "Mg", "atomic_number": 12, "category": "metal (alkaline earth)", "state_room_temp": "solid", "common_uses": ["Lightweight alloys (aerospace, automotive)", "Flares and fireworks", "Dietary supplement", "Antacids (as Mg(OH)₂)", "Deoxidizer for metals"]}}

{"explanation": "Magnesium hydroxide, Mg(OH)₂, is an inorganic compound, a white solid with low solubility in water, commonly used as an antacid and laxative (Milk of Magnesia).", "urdu_meaning": "میگنیشیم ہائیڈروآکسائیڈ", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "Magnesium hydroxide neutralizes stomach acid, providing relief from heartburn.", "properties": {"formula": "Mg(OH)₂", "molar_mass": "58.3197 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "solid", "hazards": ["Generally low toxicity", "Can act as a laxative in larger doses"]}}

{"explanation": "A metal is a type of chemical element that is typically shiny, malleable, ductile, and a good conductor of heat and electricity, tending to lose electrons to form positive ions.", "urdu_meaning": "دھات - چمکدار، لچکدار اور حرارت و بجلی کا اچھا موصل عنصر", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Alkali metals and alkaline earth metals are highly reactive examples of a metal.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Elements characterized by metallic bonding, high conductivity, malleability, ductility, and a tendency to form cations.", "related_concepts": ["metallic bonding", "conductivity", "malleability", "ductility", "luster", "cations", "periodic table (left side and center)", "non-metal", "metalloid"], "real_world_example": "Iron, copper, gold, aluminum, sodium."}}

{"explanation": "Metal oxides are chemical compounds containing at least one oxygen atom and one metal element. Oxides of alkali and alkaline earth metals are typically basic.", "urdu_meaning": "دھاتی آکسائیڈ - دھات اور آکسیجن کے مرکبات", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The reaction of alkali metals with oxygen forms metal oxides like sodium oxide (Na₂O).", "properties": {"key_principle": "Compounds formed between metals and oxygen.", "related_concepts": ["oxides", "metals", "oxygen", "basic oxides", "amphoteric oxides", "acid-base chemistry", "corrosion"], "real_world_example": "Iron(III) oxide (rust, Fe₂O₃), Calcium oxide (quicklime, CaO), Aluminum oxide (Al₂O₃)."}}

{"explanation": "Negative ions, also known as anions, are atoms or molecules that have gained one or more electrons, resulting in a net negative charge.", "urdu_meaning": "منفی آئن - این آئن", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Halogens readily form negative ions with a charge of -1 by gaining an electron.", "properties": {"key_principle": "An atom or group of atoms that has more electrons than protons, giving it a net negative electrical charge.", "related_concepts": ["anions", "ions", "electrons", "cations", "ionic bonding", "electronegativity"], "real_world_example": "Chloride ion (Cl⁻), sulfide ion (S²⁻), nitrate ion (NO₃⁻)."}}

{"explanation": "Neutron capture cross-section is a measure of the probability that an atomic nucleus will capture an incident neutron, an important parameter in nuclear chemistry and reactor physics.", "urdu_meaning": "نیوٹران گرفتاری کراس سیکشن - نیوٹران جذب کرنے کے امکان کی پیمائش", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "Elements with high neutron capture cross-sections are used as control rods in nuclear reactors.", "properties": {"describes": "The effective area presented by a nucleus for neutron capture.", "related_concepts": ["neutron", "nucleus", "nuclear reaction", "neutron activation", "nuclear reactor", "isotope production", "nuclear chemistry"], "example_of_use": "Boron-10 has a large neutron capture cross-section, making it useful for neutron shielding.", "measurement_type": "Barns (1 barn = 10⁻²⁸ m²)."}}

{"explanation": "Noble gases are the elements in Group 18 of the periodic table, characterized by their very low chemical reactivity due to having full valence electron shells.", "urdu_meaning": "نبیل گیسیں - دوری جدول کے گروپ 18 کے غیر عامل عناصر", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Noble gases like helium and argon are often used to create inert atmospheres for chemical reactions.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Group 18 elements with stable ns²np⁶ (or 1s² for He) electron configurations, resulting in chemical inertness.", "related_concepts": ["Group 18", "periodic table", "p-block (except He)", "valence electrons", "octet rule", "inertness", "monoatomic gases"], "real_world_example": "Helium (He) in balloons, Neon (Ne) in signs, Argon (Ar) in light bulbs."}}

{"explanation": "A non-metal is a chemical element that generally lacks metallic properties, is typically a poor conductor of heat and electricity, and tends to gain electrons to form negative ions or share electrons in covalent bonds.", "urdu_meaning": "غیر دھات - دھاتی خصوصیات نہ رکھنے والا عنصر", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Halogens like chlorine and fluorine are highly reactive examples of a non-metal.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Elements typically found on the right side of the periodic table, characterized by high electronegativity, and forming acidic oxides.", "related_concepts": ["non-metals (plural)", "periodic table (right side)", "electronegativity", "ionization energy", "covalent bonding", "anions", "acidic oxides", "metal", "metalloid"], "real_world_example": "Oxygen, nitrogen, carbon, sulfur, chlorine."}}

{"explanation": "Non-metal oxides are chemical compounds containing at least one oxygen atom and one non-metal element. They are typically acidic in nature, reacting with water to form acids or with bases to form salts.", "urdu_meaning": "غیر دھاتی آکسائیڈ - غیر دھات اور آکسیجن کے مرکبات", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Carbon dioxide (CO₂) is a non-metal oxide that dissolves in water to form carbonic acid.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Compounds formed between non-metals and oxygen, generally exhibiting acidic properties.", "related_concepts": ["oxides", "non-metals", "oxygen", "acidic oxides", "acid anhydrides", "acid-base chemistry"], "real_world_example": "Sulfur dioxide (SO₂), Nitrogen dioxide (NO₂), Carbon dioxide (CO₂), Phosphorus pentoxide (P₂O₅)."}}

{"explanation": "Non-metals are a class of chemical elements that are generally poor conductors of heat and electricity, are not malleable or ductile, and tend to gain or share electrons in chemical reactions.", "urdu_meaning": "غیر دھاتیں - دھاتی خصوصیات نہ رکھنے والے عناصر", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The halogens and noble gases are prominent groups of non-metals in the periodic table.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Elements usually found on the upper right side of the periodic table, which typically form anions or covalent bonds.", "related_concepts": ["periodic table", "p-block", "electronegativity", "ionization energy", "covalent bonding", "acidic oxides", "halogens", "noble gases"], "real_world_example": "Oxygen (O), Carbon (C), Sulfur (S), Chlorine (Cl), Neon (Ne)."}}

{"explanation": "The ns² configuration refers to a valence electron arrangement where the outermost s-orbital contains two electrons, characteristic of alkaline earth metals (Group 2).", "urdu_meaning": "این ایس² تشکیل - بیرونی ایس-مدار میں دو الیکٹران والی ترتیب", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Elements with an ns² configuration, like magnesium and calcium, tend to lose these two electrons to form +2 ions.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Valence electron configuration where the s-subshell of the outermost principal energy level (n) is completely filled with two electrons.", "related_concepts": ["electron configuration", "valence electrons", "s-orbital", "alkaline earth metals", "Group 2", "ions"], "real_world_example": "Beryllium (2s²), Magnesium (3s²), Calcium (4s²)."}}

{"explanation": "The ns²np⁵ configuration refers to a valence electron arrangement with two electrons in the outermost s-orbital and five electrons in the outermost p-orbitals, characteristic of halogens (Group 17).", "urdu_meaning": "این ایس² این پی⁵ تشکیل - بیرونی ایس-مدار میں دو اور پی-مدار میں پانچ الیکٹران والی ترتیب", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Elements with an ns²np⁵ configuration, such as fluorine and chlorine, readily gain one electron to achieve a stable octet.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Valence electron configuration where the s-subshell is filled and the p-subshell of the outermost principal energy level (n) contains five electrons.", "related_concepts": ["electron configuration", "valence electrons", "s-orbital", "p-orbitals", "halogens", "Group 17", "octet rule", "anions"], "real_world_example": "Fluorine (2s²2p⁵), Chlorine (3s²3p⁵)."}}

{"explanation": "The ns¹ configuration refers to a valence electron arrangement where the outermost s-orbital contains one electron, characteristic of alkali metals (Group 1).", "urdu_meaning": "این ایس¹ تشکیل - بیرونی ایس-مدار میں ایک الیکٹران والی ترتیب", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Elements with an ns¹ configuration, like sodium and potassium, are highly reactive and tend to lose this electron to form +1 ions.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Valence electron configuration where the s-subshell of the outermost principal energy level (n) contains a single electron.", "related_concepts": ["electron configuration", "valence electrons", "s-orbital", "alkali metals", "Group 1", "ions", "reactivity"], "real_world_example": "Lithium (2s¹), Sodium (3s¹), Potassium (4s¹)."}}

{"explanation": "Nuclear chemistry is the subfield of chemistry dealing with radioactivity, nuclear processes (like fission and fusion), and nuclear properties.", "urdu_meaning": "نیوکلیائی کیمیا - تابکاری، نیوکلیائی عوامل اور خصوصیات کا علم", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The study of radioactive decay and the production of radioisotopes falls under nuclear chemistry.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Study of reactions involving changes in atomic nuclei, including radioactivity, nuclear fission, and fusion.", "related_concepts": ["radioactivity", "radioactive decay", "isotopes", "half-life", "nuclear fission", "nuclear fusion", "transmutation", "radiometric dating"], "real_world_example": "Nuclear power generation, medical imaging using radioisotopes, carbon dating."}}

{"explanation": "Nuclear properties are characteristics of an atomic nucleus, such as its size, stability (radioactivity), spin, magnetic moment, and neutron capture cross-section.", "urdu_meaning": "نیوکلیائی خصوصیات - جوہری مرکزے کی خصوصیات", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The nuclear properties of an isotope determine its stability and mode of radioactive decay.", "properties": {"describes": "Characteristics pertaining to the atomic nucleus.", "related_concepts": ["nucleus", "radioactivity", "half-life", "isotopes", "nuclear spin", "binding energy", "neutron capture cross-sections"], "example_of_use": "The high binding energy per nucleon for iron-56 is one of its key nuclear properties related to stability.", "measurement_type": "Varies (e.g., half-life in time units, cross-section in barns)."}}

{"explanation": "The outer shell, also known as the valence shell, is the outermost electron shell of an atom that contains electrons involved in chemical bonding.", "urdu_meaning": "بیرونی شیل - ایٹم کا سب سے باہر والا الیکٹران مدار", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The number of electrons in the outer shell determines an element's group in the periodic table and its chemical reactivity.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The highest principal energy level of an atom that is occupied by electrons.", "related_concepts": ["valence shell", "valence electrons", "electron configuration", "chemical bonding", "octet rule", "periodicity"], "real_world_example": "For alkali metals, the outer shell contains one electron (ns¹)."}}

{"explanation": "The outermost shell is the highest principal energy level in an atom that is occupied by electrons, and these electrons (valence electrons) determine the atom's chemical behavior.", "urdu_meaning": "بیرونی ترین شیل - ایٹم کا سب سے باہر والا الیکٹران شیل", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Halogens have seven electrons in their outermost shell, making them highly reactive.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The electron shell furthest from the nucleus that contains electrons.", "related_concepts": ["valence shell", "valence electrons", "electron configuration", "chemical properties", "periodicity", "octet rule"], "real_world_example": "In a sodium atom (electron configuration 1s²2s²2p⁶3s¹), the 3rd shell (n=3) is the outermost shell."}}

{"explanation": "An oxide is a chemical compound that contains at least one oxygen atom and one other element in its chemical formula. Oxides can be acidic, basic, amphoteric, or neutral.", "urdu_meaning": "آکسائیڈ - آکسیجن اور کسی دوسرے عنصر کا مرکب", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Metal oxides like calcium oxide are typically basic, while non-metal oxides like carbon dioxide are acidic.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A chemical compound containing at least one oxygen atom and one other element.", "related_concepts": ["oxygen", "metal oxides", "non-metal oxides", "acidic oxides", "basic oxides", "amphoteric oxides", "neutral oxides", "oxidation"], "real_world_example": "Water (H₂O), Carbon dioxide (CO₂), Iron(III) oxide (Fe₂O₃), Sulfur dioxide (SO₂)."}}

{"explanation": "Oxides are a broad class of chemical compounds that contain at least one oxygen atom combined with another element. Their properties (acidic, basic, etc.) depend on the element bonded to oxygen.", "urdu_meaning": "آکسائیڈز (جمع) - آکسیجن کے مرکبات", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The reactions of elements with oxygen produce various oxides with differing chemical behaviors.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Compounds formed by the chemical combination of oxygen with other elements.", "related_concepts": ["oxide", "metal oxides", "non-metal oxides", "acidic oxides", "basic oxides", "amphoteric oxides", "oxidation"], "real_world_example": "Rust (iron oxides), quicklime (calcium oxide), carbon dioxide, sulfur dioxide."}}

{"explanation": "Period 6 of the periodic table is the sixth horizontal row, containing elements from cesium (Cs, atomic number 55) to radon (Rn, atomic number 86), and includes the lanthanide series.
column4: ""urdu_meaning"": ""دور 6 - دوری جدول کی چھٹی افقی قطار""
column6: ""example_sentence"": ""Elements in Period 6 have electrons in up to six principal energy shells and exhibit diverse properties
column8: ""properties"": {""key_principle"": ""The sixth horizontal row in the periodic table where elements have their outermost electrons in the sixth principal energy level
column9: and also includes the filling of 4f orbitals (lanthanides).""

enrichment_data: {"explanation": "The periodic table is a tabular arrangement of chemical elements, ordered by their atomic number, electron configurations, and recurring chemical properties, providing a framework for understanding elemental relationships.", "urdu_meaning": "دوری جدول - کیمیائی عناصر کی منظم ترتیب", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The periodic table is an indispensable tool for chemists to predict and explain the properties and reactions of elements.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A systematic organization of elements based on increasing atomic number, revealing periodic trends in their properties.", "related_concepts": ["elements", "atomic number", "electron configuration", "groups", "periods", "blocks (s, p, d, f)", "periodicity", "periodic trends"], "real_world_example": "Used to classify elements like alkali metals, halogens, noble gases, and transition metals."}}

{"explanation": "Periodic trends are specific patterns in the properties of chemical elements that are revealed in the periodic table, such as trends in atomic radius, ionization energy, and electronegativity.", "urdu_meaning": "دوری رجحانات - دوری جدول میں عناصر کی خصوصیات میں باقاعدہ تبدیلیاں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Understanding periodic trends allows chemists to predict the behavior of elements based on their position in the table.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Observable patterns in elemental properties (e.g., atomic size, ionization energy, electronegativity) across periods and down groups of the periodic table.", "related_concepts": ["periodicity", "periodic table", "atomic radius", "ionization energy", "electronegativity", "electron affinity", "metallic character", "effective nuclear charge", "shielding effect"], "real_world_example": "Atomic radius generally decreases across a period and increases down a group."}}

{"explanation": "Physical state refers to one of the distinct forms that matter takes on (solid, liquid, gas, plasma) at a given temperature and pressure, determined by the arrangement and energy of its particles.", "urdu_meaning": "طبیعی حالت - مادے کی ٹھوس، مائع یا گیس حالت", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "At room temperature, chlorine is in a gaseous physical state, while bromine is a liquid and iodine is a solid.", "properties": {"describes": "The form of matter (solid, liquid, gas, plasma) under specific conditions.", "related_concepts": ["states of matter", "solid", "liquid", "gas", "plasma", "phase transitions", "temperature", "pressure"], "example_of_use": "The physical state of water changes from solid (ice) to liquid to gas (steam) with increasing temperature.", "measurement_type": "Observation, determination of melting/boiling points."}}
