Non-metals and noble gases are not ductile.", "urdu_meaning": "تار پذیری - مواد کی پتلی تاروں میں کھینچے جانے کی صلاحیت", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The ductility of transition elements like copper makes them ideal for electrical wiring.", "properties": {"describes": "The capacity of a material to be stretched into a wire without breaking.", "related_concepts": ["physical properties", "metals", "alkali metals", "transition elements", "malleability", "metallic bonding"], "example_of_use": "Gold's high ductility allows it to be drawn into very fine threads.", "measurement_type": "Percentage elongation."}}

{"explanation": "Electrical conductivity is a measure of a material's ability to conduct electricity. Metals (alkali metals, transition elements) are good conductors, graphite (a non-metal) is a moderate conductor, while other non-metals and noble gases are insulators.", "urdu_meaning": "برقی موصلیت - بجلی گزرنے کی صلاحیت", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The high electrical conductivity of metals is due to their mobile electrons in the metallic bond.", "properties": {"describes": "The ability of a substance to allow the flow of electric current.", "related_concepts": ["conductivity", "metals", "non-metals", "alkali metals", "transition elements", "graphite", "noble gases", "mobile electrons", "metallic bonding"], "example_of_use": "Copper wires are used for electrical transmission due to their high electrical conductivity.", "measurement_type": "Siemens per meter (S/m)."}}

{"explanation": "Electronic configurations describe electron arrangements and are key to understanding the properties of different groups: alkali metals (ns¹), halogens (ns²np⁵), noble gases (ns²np⁶ or 1s²), transition elements (partially filled d-orbitals), and non-metals like graphite (carbon: [He]2s²2p²).", "urdu_meaning": "الیکٹرانی تشکیلات - ایٹموں میں الیکٹرانوں کی ترتیب", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The distinct electronic configurations of alkali metals, halogens, noble gases, and transition elements lead to their characteristic chemical behaviors.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The distribution of electrons in atomic orbitals, dictating chemical properties.", "related_concepts": ["valence electron", "alkali metals", "halogens", "noble gases", "transition elements", "d-block elements", "graphite", "reactivity", "stability"], "real_world_example": "Sodium: [Ne]3s¹; Chlorine: [Ne]3s²3p⁵; Argon: [Ne]3s²3p⁶; Iron: [Ar]3d⁶4s²."}}

{"explanation": "Graphite is an allotrope of carbon (a non-metal) with a layered structure where carbon atoms are covalently bonded in hexagonal sheets. It conducts electricity due to delocalized pi electrons and is used as a lubricant.", "urdu_meaning": "گریفائٹ - کاربن کی ایک شکل، بجلی کا موصل اور چکنا کرنے والا", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "Unlike diamond, graphite is soft and a good electrical conductor due to its unique layered structure and mobile electrons.", "properties": {"formula": "C", "molar_mass": "12.01 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "solid", "hazards": ["Non-toxic", "Dust can be an irritant"]}}

{"explanation": "Group 1 of the periodic table contains the alkali metals, highly reactive elements with one valence electron (ns¹ configuration).", "urdu_meaning": "گروپ 1 - دوری جدول کا پہلا گروہ (الکلی دھاتیں)", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Elements in Group 1, such as sodium and potassium, readily lose their single valence electron to form +1 cations.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The first column of the periodic table (excluding H for group properties), comprising alkali metals.", "related_concepts": ["alkali metals", "periodic table", "s-block", "valence electron", "reactivity", "metals"], "real_world_example": "Lithium, sodium, potassium."}}

{"explanation": "Group 17 elements, known as halogens, are highly reactive non-metals with seven valence electrons (ns²np⁵ configuration), strong oxidizing agents, and exist as diatomic molecules.", "urdu_meaning": "گروپ 17 عناصر - ہیلوجنز", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The reactivity of Group 17 elements decreases down the group from fluorine to iodine.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Elements in the 17th column of the periodic table, characterized by high electronegativity and reactivity.", "related_concepts": ["halogens", "periodic table", "p-block", "non-metals", "valence electron", "diatomic molecules", "oxidizing agents", "reactivity"], "real_world_example": "Fluorine, chlorine, bromine, iodine."}}

{"explanation": "Group 18 of the periodic table contains the noble gases, which are characterized by completely filled outer electron shells, making them very stable and chemically inert.", "urdu_meaning": "گروپ 18 - دوری جدول کا اٹھارہواں گروہ (نبیل گیسیں)", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Elements in Group 18, like helium and neon, are monoatomic gases at room temperature due to their inertness.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The rightmost column of the periodic table, comprising the noble gases.", "related_concepts": ["noble gases", "periodic table", "p-block (except He)", "completely filled outer electron shells", "inertness", "stability", "monoatomic gases"], "real_world_example": "Helium, neon, argon."}}

{"explanation": "The Haber process (or Haber-Bosch process) is an industrial method for synthesizing ammonia from nitrogen and hydrogen, using an iron-based (transition element) catalyst.", "urdu_meaning": "ہیبر پراسیس - امونیا بنانے کا صنعتی عمل", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "The iron catalyst in the Haber process is crucial for achieving a practical rate of ammonia production.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Catalytic synthesis of NH₃ from N₂ and H₂ at high temperature and pressure.", "related_concepts": ["ammonia production", "catalysis", "iron", "transition elements", "industrial chemistry"], "real_world_example": "Primary method for industrial ammonia synthesis for fertilizers."}}

{"explanation": "Halogens (Group 17 elements) are reactive non-metals that exist as diatomic molecules (e.g., Cl₂, Br₂), are strong oxidizing agents, and readily form salts with metals.", "urdu_meaning": "ہیلوجنز - دوری جدول کے گروپ 17 کے عناصر", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The oxidizing power of halogens decreases down the group, with fluorine being the strongest.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Group 17 non-metals with seven valence electrons, known for high reactivity and forming X⁻ ions or single covalent bonds.", "related_concepts": ["group 17 elements", "non-metals", "diatomic molecules", "oxidizing agents", "reactivity", "valence electron"], "real_world_example": "Chlorine (Cl₂), Bromine (Br₂), Iodine (I₂)."}}

{"explanation": "Hydrogenation reactions involve adding hydrogen to unsaturated compounds, often catalyzed by transition elements like nickel, platinum, or palladium.", "urdu_meaning": "ہائیڈروجنیشن تعاملات - ہائیڈروجن کے اضافے والے کیمیائی عمل", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Nickel, a transition element, is a common catalyst for hydrogenation reactions in the food industry to convert oils to fats.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Chemical reactions where hydrogen is added to a molecule, typically across a multiple bond.", "related_concepts": ["catalysis", "transition elements", "nickel", "unsaturated oils", "saturated fats", "addition reactions"], "real_world_example": "Converting vegetable oils to margarine."}}

{"explanation": "Interatomic attraction refers to the forces holding atoms together, which can be strong chemical bonds (metallic, ionic, covalent) or weaker intermolecular forces (like London dispersion forces between noble gas atoms or halogen molecules).", "urdu_meaning": "بین الجوہری کشش - ایٹموں کو جوڑنے والی قوتیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The strength of interatomic attraction determines many physical properties, such as melting and boiling points; strong metallic bonds in transition elements lead to high values, while weak dispersion forces in noble gases lead to very low values.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Forces that exist between atoms, dictating their aggregation into molecules or condensed phases.", "related_concepts": ["chemical bonding", "metallic bonding", "covalent bonding", "ionic bonding", "intermolecular forces", "London dispersion forces", "melting points", "boiling points"], "real_world_example": "Strong covalent bonds within a Cl₂ molecule, weaker London dispersion forces between Cl₂ molecules."}}

{"explanation": "Iron (Fe) is a d-block transition element widely used as a catalyst (e.g., in the Haber process), for its magnetic properties, and as the primary component of steel due to its strength and abundance.", "urdu_meaning": "لوہا - ایک عبوری عنصر، عمل انگیز اور ساختی مواد", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "The catalytic activity of iron in the Haber process is crucial for the industrial production of ammonia.", "properties": {"symbol": "Fe", "atomic_number": 26, "category": "metal (transition)", "state_room_temp": "solid", "common_uses": ["Steel production", "Catalyst (Haber process)", "Magnets", "Construction"]}}

{"explanation": "A layered structure describes materials where atoms are arranged in distinct planes or sheets, like graphite (a non-metal), where strong covalent bonds exist within layers and weaker forces between layers.", "urdu_meaning": "تہہ دار ساخت - مواد میں ایٹموں یا مالیکیولز کی تہوں میں ترتیب", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Graphite's layered structure allows it to act as a lubricant and conduct electricity along its planes.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Arrangement of atoms or molecules in parallel planes with anisotropic bonding.", "related_concepts": ["graphite", "carbon layers", "covalent bonding", "intermolecular forces", "electrical conductivity", "lubricant"], "real_world_example": "Graphite used in pencils."}}

{"explanation": "Luster describes the shininess of a material's surface. Metals, including alkali metals and transition elements, typically exhibit a characteristic metallic luster due to reflection of light by mobile electrons. Non-metals (except graphite in some forms) and noble gases lack this.", "urdu_meaning": "چمک / آب و تاب - سطح سے روشنی کے تعامل کا انداز", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The metallic luster is a common physical property of transition elements and alkali metals.", "properties": {"describes": "The way light interacts with the surface of a substance, particularly its shininess.", "related_concepts": ["physical properties", "metals", "alkali metals", "transition elements", "non-metals", "graphite", "mobile electrons"], "example_of_use": "Polished silver exhibits a bright metallic luster.", "measurement_type": "Qualitative (e.g., metallic, dull, vitreous)."}}

{"explanation": "Malleability is the ability of a material, especially metals like alkali metals and transition elements, to be hammered or pressed into thin sheets without breaking. Non-metals and noble gases are not malleable.", "urdu_meaning": "ورق پذیری - مواد کی بغیر ٹوٹے پتلی چادروں میں ڈھلنے کی صلاحیت", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The malleability of gold, a transition element, allows it to be beaten into extremely thin leaves.", "properties": {"describes": "The capacity of a solid to be shaped by hammering or rolling without fracture.", "related_concepts": ["physical properties", "metals", "alkali metals", "transition elements", "ductility", "metallic bonding"], "example_of_use": "Aluminum is highly malleable and can be easily formed into cans."}}

{"explanation": "Melting points are the temperatures at which solids become liquids. Transition elements generally have high melting points; alkali metals have lower melting points; non-metals vary (graphite is high, halogens vary, noble gases are very low).", "urdu_meaning": "نقطہائے پگھلاؤ - ٹھوس کے مائع میں تبدیلی کے درجہ حرارت", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The strong metallic bonding in most transition elements results in high melting points compared to the weaker bonds or forces in many non-metals.", "properties": {"describes": "Temperatures at which solids transition to liquids, reflecting bond/force strength.", "related_concepts": ["physical properties", "metallic bonding", "intermolecular forces", "covalent network solids", "alkali metals", "halogens", "noble gases", "transition elements", "graphite"], "example_of_use": "Tungsten (transition element) has one of the highest melting points, while helium (noble gas) has the lowest.", "measurement_type": "Degrees Celsius (°C) or Kelvin (K)."}}

{"explanation": "Metals, including alkali metals and transition elements, are characterized by properties like luster, high conductivity, malleability, and ductility, due to metallic bonding involving mobile electrons.", "urdu_meaning": "دھاتیں - مخصوص خصوصیات رکھنے والے عناصر کا گروہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Transition elements and alkali metals are distinct groups of metals with differing reactivities and physical properties.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Elements that typically form cations, conduct electricity and heat well, and are often malleable and ductile.", "related_concepts": ["alkali metals", "transition elements", "metallic bonding", "mobile electrons", "physical properties", "chemical properties", "luster", "conductivity", "malleability", "ductility"], "real_world_example": "Iron, copper, sodium, gold."}}

{"explanation": "Mobile electrons are delocalized electrons, not associated with a single atom or bond, that are free to move throughout a material. They are responsible for the high electrical and thermal conductivity of metals and graphite.", "urdu_meaning": "متحرک الیکٹران / آزاد الیکٹران - مواد میں آزادانہ حرکت کرنے والے الیکٹران", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The 'sea' of mobile electrons in metallic bonding allows metals like alkali metals and transition elements to conduct electricity.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Electrons that are not bound to a specific atom or covalent bond and can move freely within a material.", "related_concepts": ["delocalized electrons", "metallic bonding", "electron sea model", "electrical conductivity", "thermal conductivity", "metals", "graphite"], "real_world_example": "The valence electrons in a copper wire."}}

{"explanation": "Nickel (Ni) is a silvery-white, hard, ductile transition element known for its corrosion resistance and use as a catalyst, particularly in hydrogenation reactions.", "urdu_meaning": "نکل - ایک عبوری عنصر، عمل انگیز", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "Nickel is an effective catalyst for the hydrogenation of vegetable oils to produce margarine.", "properties": {"symbol": "Ni", "atomic_number": 28, "category": "metal (transition)", "state_room_temp": "solid", "common_uses": ["Alloys (stainless steel, nichrome)", "Electroplating", "Batteries (NiCd, NiMH)", "Catalyst (hydrogenation)", "Coins"]}}

{"explanation": "Noble gases (Group 18) are very unreactive monoatomic gases due to their completely filled outer electron shells, resulting in very weak interatomic attractions (London dispersion forces) and thus very low boiling points.", "urdu_meaning": "نبیل گیسیں - دوری جدول کے گروپ 18 کے غیر عامل عناصر", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The chemical inertness and stable electronic configurations of noble gases distinguish them from reactive groups like alkali metals and halogens.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Group 18 elements with full valence shells, making them exceptionally stable and unreactive.", "related_concepts": ["group 18", "inertness", "stability", "completely filled outer electron shells", "monoatomic gases", "London dispersion forces", "boiling points", "electronic configurations"], "real_world_example": "Helium, neon, argon."}}

{"explanation": "Non-metals are elements that typically are poor conductors, not malleable/ductile, and gain/share electrons. This group includes halogens, noble gases, and elements like carbon (e.g., graphite). Their properties contrast with metals.", "urdu_meaning": "غیر دھاتیں - دھاتی خصوصیات نہ رکھنے والے عناصر کا گروہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "While graphite, a non-metal, conducts electricity, most other non-metals like sulfur or halogens are insulators.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Elements generally found on the right side of the periodic table, lacking typical metallic properties.", "related_concepts": ["halogens", "noble gases", "graphite", "diatomic molecules", "covalent bonding", "electrical conductivity (poor, except graphite)", "physical properties"], "real_world_example": "Oxygen, chlorine, carbon, sulfur."}}

{"explanation": "Oxidizing agents are substances that cause oxidation by accepting electrons. Halogens (Group 17 elements) are strong oxidizing agents, with their oxidizing power decreasing down the group.", "urdu_meaning": "تکسیدی عامل - وہ مادے جو دوسروں کی تکسید کرتے ہیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Fluorine is the most powerful oxidizing agent among the halogens and all elements.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Species that gain electrons (are reduced) and cause another species to lose electrons (be oxidized).", "related_concepts": ["redox reactions", "oxidation", "reduction", "halogens", "group 17 elements", "electronegativity", "electron affinity"], "real_world_example": "Chlorine gas (Cl₂), Potassium permanganate (KMnO₄)."}}

{"explanation": "Partially filled d-orbitals are characteristic of transition elements (d-block elements), contributing to their variable oxidation states, formation of colored compounds, and catalytic activity.", "urdu_meaning": "جزوی طور پر بھرے ہوئے ڈی-مدار - عبوری عناصر کی خاصیت", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The ability of transition elements to act as catalysts is often linked to their partially filled d-orbitals.", "properties": {"key_principle": "d-orbitals in transition elements containing between one and nine electrons.", "related_concepts": ["transition elements", "d-block elements", "d-orbitals", "electron configuration", "variable oxidation states", "colored compounds", "catalytic activity"], "real_world_example": "Iron(II) with a d⁶ configuration has partially filled d-orbitals."}}

{"explanation": "Physical properties (e.g., melting/boiling points, density, conductivity, state, luster, malleability, ductility) vary distinctively between groups like alkali metals, halogens, noble gases, transition elements, and non-metals like graphite.", "urdu_meaning": "طبیعی خصوصیات - مادے کی وہ خصوصیات جو کیمیائی شناخت تبدیل کیے بغیر معلوم کی جا سکیں", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The physical properties such as high electrical conductivity and luster are characteristic of metals like alkali metals and transition elements, but not of noble gases.", "properties": {"describes": "Observable characteristics of substances that do not involve chemical change.", "related_concepts": ["melting points", "boiling points", "densities", "electrical conductivity", "thermal conductivity", "luster", "malleability", "ductility", "atomic size", "bonding types", "interatomic attraction"], "example_of_use": "Comparing the physical properties helps classify elements into metals, non-metals, etc.", "measurement_type": "Various quantitative and qualitative assessments."}}

{"explanation": "Reactivity describes the tendency to undergo chemical reactions. Alkali metals are highly reactive, halogens are reactive (decreasing down group), noble gases are very unreactive, and transition elements show varied reactivity but are often less reactive than alkali metals.", "urdu_meaning": "عاملیت / ردعمل کی صلاحیت - کیمیائی تعامل کرنے کا رجحان", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The reactivity of alkali metals is much higher than that of noble gases due to differences in their valence electron configurations and stability.", "properties": {"describes": "The ease and speed with which a substance undergoes chemical change.", "related_concepts": ["chemical behavior", "stability", "electronic configurations", "valence electron", "alkali metals", "halogens", "noble gases", "transition elements", "oxidizing agents"], "example_of_use": "Fluorine's high reactivity makes it a powerful oxidizing agent.", "measurement_type": "Often qualitative or by reaction rates."}}

{"explanation": "Stability in chemistry refers to resistance to chemical change. Noble gases exhibit high stability due to completely filled outer electron shells. Reactivity of other groups (alkali metals, halogens) is driven by their tendency to achieve such stable configurations.", "urdu_meaning": "استحکام - کیمیائی تبدیلی کے خلاف مزاحمت", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The exceptional stability of noble gases is attributed to their full valence electron shells.", "properties": {"describes": "The tendency of a substance to remain in its current state or resist chemical reaction.", "related_concepts": ["chemical stability", "inertness", "noble gases", "completely filled outer electron shells", "reactivity", "electronic configurations", "octet rule"], "example_of_use": "The stability of nitrogen gas (N₂) is due to its strong triple bond.", "measurement_type": "Qualitative assessment, or by thermodynamic parameters like enthalpy of formation."}}

{"explanation": "Thermal conductivity is a material's ability to conduct heat. Metals (alkali metals, transition elements) are good thermal conductors due to mobile electrons. Non-metals (except graphite in specific orientations) and noble gases are poor thermal conductors.", "urdu_meaning": "حرارتی موصلیت - حرارت گزرنے کی صلاحیت", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The high thermal conductivity of transition elements like copper makes them suitable for heat exchangers.", "properties": {"describes": "The capacity of a material to transfer heat energy through conduction.", "related_concepts": ["conductivity", "metals", "non-metals", "alkali metals", "transition elements", "graphite", "noble gases", "mobile electrons", "metallic bonding"], "example_of_use": "Diamond, a non-metal, has exceptionally high thermal conductivity for a non-metal due to its strong covalent lattice vibrations.", "measurement_type": "Watts per meter-Kelvin (W/(m·K))."}}

{"explanation": "Transition elements (d-block elements) are metals characterized by partially filled d-orbitals, variable oxidation states, formation of colored compounds, catalytic activity, and typical metallic properties like high density, melting/boiling points, conductivity, malleability, and ductility.", "urdu_meaning": "عبوری عناصر - دوری جدول کے ڈی-بلاک کے عناصر", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Unlike alkali metals, transition elements often exhibit multiple oxidation states and form complex ions.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Metals in Groups 3-12, generally with partially filled d-subshells, leading to unique chemical and physical properties.", "related_concepts": ["d-block elements", "metals", "partially filled d-orbitals", "variable oxidation states", "colored compounds", "catalytic activity", "catalysts", "physical properties", "metallic bonding"], "real_world_example": "Iron, nickel, copper, platinum, vanadium."}}

{"explanation": "A valence electron is an electron in the outermost shell of an atom, involved in chemical bonding and determining an element's chemical properties. Alkali metals have 1, halogens have 7, noble gases have 8 (or 2 for He), and transition elements involve d-electrons as valence electrons.", "urdu_meaning": "ویلنس الیکٹران - بیرونی شیل کا الیکٹران جو کیمیائی بندھن میں حصہ لیتا ہے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The single valence electron of alkali metals makes them highly reactive.", "properties": {"key_principle": "An electron in the outermost occupied electron shell of an atom that participates in chemical bonding.", "related_concepts": ["electronic configurations", "outermost shell", "alkali metals", "halogens", "noble gases", "transition elements", "reactivity", "bonding types"], "real_world_example": "Sodium has one valence electron (3s¹); Chlorine has seven valence electrons (3s²3p⁵)."}}

{"explanation": "Vanadium pentoxide (V₂O₅) is a compound of the transition element vanadium, widely used as a catalyst, notably in the Contact process for sulfuric acid manufacture.", "urdu_meaning": "ونیڈیم پینٹ آکسائیڈ - V₂O₅، ایک عمل انگیز", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "The catalytic activity of vanadium pentoxide is crucial for the efficient oxidation of sulfur dioxide to sulfur trioxide in the Contact process.", "properties": {"formula": "V₂O₅", "molar_mass": "181.88 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "solid (yellow-orange)", "hazards": ["Toxic by inhalation and ingestion", "Irritant"]}}

{"explanation": "Variable oxidation states refer to the ability of an element, particularly transition elements, to exist in multiple different positive charge states in its compounds. This property is key to their diverse chemistry and catalytic activity. Alkali metals typically show +1, halogens -1 (or positive with more electronegative elements), and noble gases rarely show any (except heavier ones).", "urdu_meaning": "متغیر تکسیدی حالتیں - ایک عنصر کا مختلف مرکبات میں مختلف چارجز کا حامل ہونا", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The catalytic properties of many transition elements are attributed to their ability to adopt variable oxidation states.", "properties": {"describes": "The capacity of an element to form compounds with different oxidation numbers.", "related_concepts": ["oxidation state", "transition elements", "d-block elements", "partially filled d-orbitals", "catalytic activity", "colored compounds"], "example_of_use": "Manganese (a transition element) can exhibit oxidation states from +2 to +7.", "measurement_type": "Determined from compound stoichiometry or electrochemistry."}}

{"explanation": "Altitudes refer to the height above a reference level, typically sea level. Oxygen content in the atmosphere decreases with increasing altitudes, impacting respiration.", "urdu_meaning": "بلندیاں / ارتفاعات - سطح سمندر سے اونچائی", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "At high altitudes, the lower partial pressure of oxygen makes it harder for humans to get enough oxygen through respiration.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Vertical distance above a reference point, affecting atmospheric pressure and composition.", "related_concepts": ["atmospheric pressure", "oxygen content", "respiration", "hypoxia", "partial pressure", "troposphere"], "real_world_example": "Mountaineers experience reduced oxygen availability at high altitudes."}}

{"explanation": "Asthma is a chronic respiratory condition characterized by inflammation and narrowing of the airways, which can be exacerbated by air pollutants often found in the lower atmosphere.", "urdu_meaning": "دمہ - سانس کی ایک دائمی بیماری", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "High levels of ground-level ozone and particulate matter in the air can trigger asthma attacks.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A chronic inflammatory disease of the airways causing breathing difficulties.", "related_concepts": ["respiration", "air pollution", "pollutants", "ground-level ozone", "particulate matter", "respiratory system"], "real_world_example": "An individual experiencing wheezing and shortness of breath after exposure to allergens or pollutants."}}

{"explanation": "Atmospheric composition refers to the mixture of gases that make up Earth's atmosphere, primarily nitrogen (about 78%) and oxygen (about 21%), with trace amounts of other gases like argon, carbon dioxide, and water vapor.", "urdu_meaning": "فضائی ترکیب - زمین کی فضا بنانے والی گیسوں کا آمیزہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The atmospheric composition has changed over geological time and is currently being altered by human activities, leading to climate change.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The relative abundance of different gases in the Earth's atmosphere.", "related_concepts": ["atmosphere", "nitrogen", "oxygen", "carbon dioxide", "argon", "trace gases", "water vapor", "greenhouse gases", "air pollution"], "real_world_example": "Dry air is approximately 78.09% nitrogen, 20.95% oxygen, 0.93% argon, and 0.04% carbon dioxide by volume."}}

{"explanation": "Carbon dioxide (CO₂) is a vital atmospheric gas involved in photosynthesis and respiration, and is also a major greenhouse gas contributing to climate change.", "urdu_meaning": "کاربن ڈائی آکسائیڈ - CO₂", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "Plants absorb carbon dioxide from the atmosphere during photosynthesis to produce glucose and oxygen.", "properties": {"formula": "CO₂", "molar_mass": "44.01 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Asphyxiant in very high concentrations", "Major greenhouse gas"]}}

{"explanation": "Chemical reactions in the atmosphere, such as those involving pollutants and sunlight (photochemistry), can form secondary pollutants like ground-level ozone or contribute to phenomena like acid rain.", "urdu_meaning": "کیمیائی تعاملات - مادوں کی ساخت میں تبدیلی کے عوامل", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Ozone in the troposphere is formed through complex chemical reactions involving nitrogen oxides and volatile organic compounds.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Processes that transform chemical substances. In the atmosphere, these include photochemical reactions, oxidation, and radical chemistry.", "related_concepts": ["atmospheric chemistry", "photochemistry", "oxidation", "pollutants", "ground-level ozone", "acid rain", "smog"], "real_world_example": "The formation of ozone from NOx and VOCs in the presence of sunlight."}}

{"explanation": "Climate change refers to long-term shifts in temperatures and weather patterns, largely driven by increased concentrations of greenhouse gases (like carbon dioxide and methane) in the atmosphere from human activities.", "urdu_meaning": "موسمیاتی تبدیلی - درجہ حرارت اور موسم کے نمونوں میں طویل مدتی تبدیلیاں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The increase in atmospheric carbon dioxide due to burning fossil fuels is a primary driver of current climate change.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Significant and lasting change in the statistical distribution of weather patterns over periods ranging from decades to millions of years.", "related_concepts": ["global warming", "greenhouse gases", "carbon dioxide", "methane", "fossil fuels", "atmospheric composition", "environmental science"], "real_world_example": "Rising global average temperatures, melting glaciers, more frequent extreme weather events."}}

{"explanation": "Combustion is a chemical process that involves rapid reaction between a substance with an oxidant, usually oxygen, to produce heat and light. It releases gases like carbon dioxide and water vapor into the atmosphere.", "urdu_meaning": "احتراق / جلنا - آکسیجن کے ساتھ تیز ردعمل جس سے حرارت اور روشنی پیدا ہوتی ہے", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "The combustion of fossil fuels in vehicles and power plants is a major source of atmospheric carbon dioxide.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A high-temperature exothermic redox chemical reaction between a fuel and an oxidant, usually atmospheric oxygen.", "related_concepts": ["oxygen", "carbon dioxide", "water vapor", "fossil fuels", "air pollution", "greenhouse gases", "vehicle emissions"], "real_world_example": "Burning wood in a fireplace; gasoline burning in a car engine."}}

{"explanation": "COPD (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease) is a group of progressive lung diseases, such as emphysema and chronic bronchitis, often caused or worsened by long-term exposure to irritating gases or particulate matter in the atmosphere.", "urdu_meaning": "سی او پی ڈی - پھیپھڑوں کی دائمی بیماری", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Air pollution, including particulate matter and vehicle emissions, is a significant risk factor for developing COPD.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A chronic inflammatory lung disease that obstructs airflow from the lungs.", "related_concepts": ["respiration", "air pollution", "particulate matter", "smoking", "lung diseases"], "real_world_example": "Long-term smokers developing emphysema or chronic bronchitis."}}

{"explanation": "Global warming refers to the ongoing increase in Earth's average surface temperature primarily due to the enhanced greenhouse effect caused by human emissions of greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide and methane.", "urdu_meaning": "عالمی حدت / گلوبل وارمنگ - زمین کے اوسط درجہ حرارت میں اضافہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The accumulation of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere traps more heat, leading to global warming.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The long-term heating of Earth’s climate system observed since the pre-industrial period due to human activities, primarily fossil fuel burning.", "related_concepts": ["climate change", "greenhouse effect", "greenhouse gases", "carbon dioxide", "methane", "fossil fuels", "atmospheric composition"], "real_world_example": "Observed increases in global average air and ocean temperatures."}}

{"explanation": "Greenhouse gases are atmospheric gases (e.g., carbon dioxide, methane, water vapor, nitrous oxide) that absorb and emit infrared radiation, trapping heat and causing the greenhouse effect, which contributes to global warming.", "urdu_meaning": "گرین ہاؤس گیسیں - حرارت جذب کرنے والی فضائی گیسیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Human activities, such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation, have significantly increased the concentration of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Gases in the atmosphere that trap heat by absorbing and emitting thermal infrared radiation.", "related_concepts": ["greenhouse effect", "global warming", "climate change", "carbon dioxide", "methane", "water vapor", "nitrous oxide", "ozone", "atmospheric composition"], "real_world_example": "CO₂ released from burning coal, methane from livestock and landfills."}}

{"explanation": "Ground-level ozone (O₃) is a harmful air pollutant formed in the troposphere from chemical reactions between nitrogen oxides (NOx) and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in the presence of sunlight. It is a major component of smog.", "urdu_meaning": "زمینی سطح کی اوزون - ٹروپوسفیئر میں بننے والی نقصان دہ اوزون گیس", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "High concentrations of ground-level ozone can cause respiratory problems and damage vegetation.", "properties": {"formula": "O₃", "molar_mass": "48.00 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Respiratory irritant", "Damages lung tissue", "Harmful to plants", "Component of smog"]}}

{"explanation": "Humidity levels refer to the amount of water vapor present in the air. Water vapor is a significant greenhouse gas and plays a crucial role in weather patterns and the Earth's climate system.", "urdu_meaning": "نمی کی سطحیں - ہوا میں آبی بخارات کی مقدار", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "High humidity levels can make hot temperatures feel more oppressive because they reduce the efficiency of evaporative cooling (sweating).", "properties": {"describes": "The concentration of water vapor in the atmosphere.", "related_concepts": ["water vapor", "relative humidity", "absolute humidity", "dew point", "weather", "climate", "greenhouse gases"], "example_of_use": "Tropical regions typically have high humidity levels throughout the year.", "measurement_type": "Percentage (for relative humidity), g/m³ (for absolute humidity), °C or °F (for dew point)."}}

{"explanation": "The ideal gas law (PV=nRT) is an equation of state for a hypothetical ideal gas, relating pressure (P), volume (V), number of moles (n), and temperature (T). It is useful for approximating the behavior of atmospheric gases under certain conditions.", "urdu_meaning": "مثالی گیس کا قانون - گیسوں کے رویے کی وضاحت کرنے والی مساوات", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Chemists can use the ideal gas law to calculate the density of atmospheric gases or changes in volume with temperature and pressure variations at different altitudes.", "properties": {"key_principle": "An equation (PV=nRT) that describes the relationship between pressure, volume, temperature, and amount (moles) of an ideal gas.", "related_concepts": ["ideal gas", "real gas", "pressure", "volume", "temperature", "moles", "gas constant (R)", "Boyle's Law", "Charles's Law", "Avogadro's Law", "atmospheric pressure"], "real_world_example": "Calculating the volume of oxygen gas in a container at a specific temperature and pressure."}}

{"explanation": "Methane (CH₄) is a simple hydrocarbon and a potent greenhouse gas found in Earth's atmosphere, produced by natural processes (e.g., decomposition in wetlands) and human activities (e.g., agriculture, fossil fuel extraction).", "urdu_meaning": "میتھین - CH₄، ایک گرین ہاؤس گیس", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "Although less abundant than carbon dioxide, methane is a more effective greenhouse gas per molecule over shorter timescales.", "properties": {"formula": "CH₄", "molar_mass": "16.04 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Highly flammable", "Forms explosive mixtures with air", "Greenhouse gas"]}}

{"explanation": "Nitrogen (N₂) is the most abundant gas in Earth's atmosphere (about 78%), relatively unreactive in its diatomic form but essential for life as a component of proteins and nucleic acids.", "urdu_meaning": "نائٹروجن - N₂، فضا کا سب سے بڑا جزو", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "The high concentration of nitrogen in the atmosphere dilutes oxygen and plays a role in moderating combustion.", "properties": {"formula": "N₂", "molar_mass": "28.014 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Asphyxiant in very high concentrations (displaces oxygen)"]}}

{"explanation": "Noble gases (e.g., argon, neon) are present in trace amounts in the Earth's atmosphere and are characterized by their chemical inertness due to filled valence electron shells.", "urdu_meaning": "نبیل گیسیں - فضا میں قلیل مقدار میں پائی جانے والی غیر عامل گیسیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Argon is the most abundant noble gas in the atmosphere, making up nearly 1% of its volume.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Group 18 elements, generally unreactive, present as minor components of the atmosphere.", "related_concepts": ["argon", "neon", "helium", "krypton", "xenon", "atmospheric composition", "inert", "trace gases"], "real_world_example": "Argon used in light bulbs; Neon in signs."}}

{"explanation": "Oxygen (O₂) is the second most abundant gas in Earth's atmosphere (about 21%), essential for aerobic respiration in most living organisms and for combustion processes.", "urdu_meaning": "آکسیجن - O₂، سانس لینے کے لیے ضروری گیس", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "The oxygen content in the atmosphere is maintained primarily through photosynthesis by plants and algae.", "properties": {"formula": "O₂", "molar_mass": "31.998 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Supports combustion (oxidizer)", "High concentrations can be harmful over long periods"]}}

{"explanation": "Oxygen content refers to the concentration or partial pressure of oxygen in a given environment, such as the atmosphere. It decreases with altitude, affecting organisms that rely on oxygen for respiration.", "urdu_meaning": "آکسیجن کا مواد / مقدار - ماحول میں آکسیجن کا ارتکاز", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "Variations in atmospheric oxygen content can significantly impact human physiology, especially at high altitudes or in enclosed spaces.", "properties": {"describes": "The amount of oxygen present, usually as a percentage or partial pressure.", "related_concepts": ["oxygen", "atmospheric composition", "partial pressure", "respiration", "altitudes", "hypoxia", "photosynthesis"], "example_of_use": "The oxygen content of air at sea level is approximately 21% by volume.", "measurement_type": "Percentage (%), partial pressure (e.g., kPa, mmHg)."}}

{"explanation": "Particulate matter (PM) consists of fine solid particles and liquid droplets suspended in the air, originating from natural sources (e.g., dust, pollen) and human activities (e.g., combustion, industrial processes). It is an air pollutant that can affect health and visibility.", "urdu_meaning": "ذراتی مادہ - ہوا میں معلق ٹھوس یا مائع ذرات", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "High levels of particulate matter in the atmosphere can lead to respiratory problems and reduce visibility.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A complex mixture of airborne solid and liquid particles of varying size and composition.", "related_concepts": ["air pollution", "aerosols", "pollutants", "combustion", "vehicle emissions", "dust", "soot", "smoke", "respiratory health", "visibility"], "real_world_example": "Smoke from wildfires, dust from construction sites, soot from diesel exhaust."}}

{"explanation": "Photosynthesis is the process used by plants, algae, and some bacteria to convert light energy into chemical energy, transforming atmospheric carbon dioxide and water into glucose (sugar) and releasing oxygen as a byproduct.", "urdu_meaning": "ضیائی تالیف - پودوں کا روشنی کی توانائی کو کیمیائی توانائی میں تبدیل کرنے کا عمل", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Photosynthesis is a crucial process that maintains the oxygen content of the atmosphere and removes carbon dioxide.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Conversion of light energy into chemical energy (stored in organic compounds) by living organisms.", "related_concepts": ["carbon dioxide", "oxygen", "water", "glucose", "chlorophyll", "light energy", "plants", "algae", "carbon cycle", "atmospheric composition"], "real_world_example": "Green plants using sunlight to produce food and release oxygen."}}

{"explanation": "Pollutants are substances introduced into the environment that have harmful or poisonous effects. Atmospheric pollutants include gases like CO, NOx, SO₂, ground-level ozone, and particulate matter.", "urdu_meaning": "آلودگی پھیلانے والے مادے - ماحول کو نقصان پہنچانے والے عناصر", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Vehicle emissions are a major source of atmospheric pollutants in urban areas.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Contaminants that cause adverse changes in the environment.", "related_concepts": ["air pollution", "water pollution", "soil pollution", "carbon monoxide", "nitrogen oxides", "sulfur dioxide", "ground-level ozone", "particulate matter", "heavy metals", "pesticides"], "real_world_example": "Sulfur dioxide from industrial plants causing acid rain; lead from old paint contaminating soil."}}

{"explanation": "Respiration is the metabolic process in living organisms by which they take in oxygen from the atmosphere and release carbon dioxide, converting biochemical energy from nutrients into ATP.", "urdu_meaning": "تنفس - جانداروں کا آکسیجن لینا اور کاربن ڈائی آکسائیڈ خارج کرنا", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Aerobic respiration requires oxygen from the atmosphere and produces carbon dioxide as a waste product.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The set of metabolic reactions and processes that take place in organisms to convert energy from nutrients into ATP, often involving oxygen uptake and CO₂ release.", "related_concepts": ["oxygen", "carbon dioxide", "ATP", "cellular respiration", "lungs", "gaseous exchange", "metabolism", "photosynthesis (as a complementary process)"], "real_world_example": "Humans breathing in oxygen and exhaling carbon dioxide."}}

{"explanation": "Supplemental oxygen is additional oxygen provided to individuals who cannot get enough oxygen from breathing ambient air, often used at high altitudes or for medical conditions like asthma or COPD.", "urdu_meaning": "اضافی آکسیجن - ناکافی آکسیجن کی صورت میں فراہم کی جانے والی اضافی آکسیجن", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Mountain climbers often use supplemental oxygen at very high altitudes where the atmospheric oxygen content is significantly reduced.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Administration of oxygen at concentrations higher than that in ambient air to treat or prevent hypoxia.", "related_concepts": ["oxygen", "oxygen content", "altitudes", "respiration", "hypoxia", "asthma", "copd", "medical treatment"], "real_world_example": "Oxygen tanks and masks used by patients with respiratory illnesses or by climbers on high mountains."}}

{"explanation": "Trace gases are gases present in Earth's atmosphere in very small concentrations (typically less than 1% by volume), including greenhouse gases like methane and nitrous oxide, and noble gases like neon and helium.", "urdu_meaning": "قلیل مقدار والی گیسیں - فضا میں بہت کم مقدار میں پائی جانے والی گیسیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Despite their low concentrations, some trace gases like methane can have a significant impact on the Earth's climate system.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Gases that make up a very small fraction of the atmosphere but can have significant chemical or physical effects.", "related_concepts": ["atmospheric composition", "greenhouse gases", "noble gases", "methane", "nitrous oxide", "ozone", "carbon monoxide", "parts per million (ppm)", "parts per billion (ppb)"], "real_world_example": "Ozone (O₃), Methane (CH₄), Neon (Ne)."}}

{"explanation": "The troposphere is the lowest layer of Earth's atmosphere, extending from the surface up to about 7-20 km, where weather phenomena occur and most atmospheric gases, including oxygen for respiration, are concentrated.", "urdu_meaning": "ٹروپوسفیئر - زمین کی فضا کی سب سے نچلی تہہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Most human activities and air pollution issues, such as the formation of ground-level ozone, occur within the troposphere.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The lowest region of the atmosphere, characterized by decreasing temperature with altitude, and containing most of the atmosphere's mass and weather.", "related_concepts": ["atmosphere", "stratosphere", "weather", "atmospheric composition", "air pollution", "ground-level ozone", "altitudes"], "real_world_example": "The air we breathe and where clouds form."}}

{"explanation": "Vehicle emissions are pollutants released from the exhaust systems of motor vehicles, including carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxides, unburned hydrocarbons, and particulate matter, contributing significantly to air pollution and impacting atmospheric composition.", "urdu_meaning": "گاڑیوں کا دھواں / اخراج - گاڑیوں سے خارج ہونے والے آلودگی پھیلانے والے مادے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Catalytic converters are designed to reduce harmful vehicle emissions before they are released into the atmosphere.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Gases and particles exhausted from vehicles, primarily due to incomplete combustion of fuel.", "related_concepts": ["air pollution", "combustion", "carbon monoxide", "nitrogen oxides", "hydrocarbons", "particulate matter", "smog", "ground-level ozone", "catalytic converters"], "real_world_example": "Exhaust fumes from cars, trucks, and buses."}}

{"explanation": "Water vapor (H₂O in gaseous state) is a variable component of the Earth's atmosphere, a potent natural greenhouse gas, and plays a crucial role in the water cycle and weather patterns (humidity, clouds, precipitation).", "urdu_meaning": "آبی بخارات - پانی کی گیسی حالت", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "The concentration of water vapor in the atmosphere varies greatly with location and altitude, influencing humidity levels.", "properties": {"formula": "H₂O", "molar_mass": "18.015 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas (variable concentration in air)", "hazards": ["Generally non-hazardous", "Contributes to greenhouse effect"]}}

{"explanation": "Acid rain is precipitation made acidic by atmospheric pollutants like sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides, often released from burning fossil fuels. It can harm ecosystems and materials.", "urdu_meaning": "تیزابی بارش - فضائی آلودگی سے تیزابی ہونے والی بارش", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The primary causes of acid rain are emissions of sulfur dioxide from power plants and nitrogen oxides from vehicles.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Rainfall with a pH lower than 5.6 due to dissolved atmospheric pollutants (SO₂ and NOx).", "related_concepts": ["air pollutants", "sulfur dioxide", "nitrogen oxides", "fossil fuels", "atmospheric chemistry", "pH", "environmental damage"], "real_world_example": "Damage to forests and aquatic life in lakes affected by industrial emissions."}}

{"explanation": "Air pollutants are substances in the air that can be harmful to humans, animals, plants, or materials. Common examples include carbon monoxide, sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, particulate matter, and ground-level ozone.", "urdu_meaning": "فضائی آلودگی پھیلانے والے مادے - ہوا کو آلودہ کرنے والے عناصر", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Industrial activities and vehicle emissions are major sources of air pollutants in urban environments.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Contaminants present in the atmosphere at concentrations high enough to cause adverse effects.", "related_concepts": ["air quality index", "carbon monoxide", "sulfur dioxide", "nitrogen oxides", "particulate matter", "ground-level ozone", "smog", "acid rain", "volatile organic compounds"], "real_world_example": "Soot from diesel engines, CO from incomplete combustion, SO₂ from coal burning."}}

{"explanation": "Air Quality Index (AQI) is a numerical scale used by government agencies to communicate to the public how polluted the air currently is or how polluted it is forecast to become, based on concentrations of major air pollutants.", "urdu_meaning": "ہوا کے معیار کا اشاریہ - ہوا کی آلودگی کی سطح بتانے والا پیمانہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "An Air Quality Index value above 100 indicates unhealthy air quality for sensitive groups.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A standardized indicator for reporting daily air quality, focusing on health effects.", "related_concepts": ["air pollutants", "particulate matter", "ground-level ozone", "carbon monoxide", "sulfur dioxide", "nitrogen dioxide", "health effects", "environmental monitoring"], "real_world_example": "Local news reporting the AQI to advise people on outdoor activities."}}

{"explanation": "An asphyxiant is a substance, typically a gas, that can cause unconsciousness or death by suffocation (asphyxia) by displacing or reducing the oxygen concentration in the air. Carbon monoxide is a chemical asphyxiant.", "urdu_meaning": "دم گھونٹنے والا مادہ - آکسیجن کی کمی سے بے ہوشی یا موت کا سبب بننے والا مادہ", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "Carbon monoxide is a dangerous asphyxiant because it binds to hemoglobin more strongly than oxygen, preventing oxygen transport in the blood.", "properties": {"describes": "A substance that can cause suffocation by interfering with oxygen supply.", "related_concepts": ["carbon monoxide", "hypoxia", "suffocation", "oxygen transport", "hemoglobin", "toxicity", "simple asphyxiant (e.g., N₂)", "chemical asphyxiant (e.g., CO, HCN)"], "example_of_use": "High concentrations of nitrogen gas in a confined space can act as a simple asphyxiant.", "measurement_type": "N/A (describes a toxicological effect)."}}

{"explanation": "The atmosphere is the envelope of gases surrounding the Earth, which can be contaminated by air pollutants from natural and anthropogenic sources, affecting air quality and climate.", "urdu_meaning": "فضا - زمین کے گرد گیسوں کا غلاف", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Burning fossil fuels releases various pollutants into the atmosphere, contributing to smog and acid rain.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The layer of gases surrounding a planet, essential for life and climate regulation.", "related_concepts": ["air pollutants", "atmospheric composition", "troposphere", "stratosphere", "air quality", "climate change"], "real_world_example": "Earth's atmosphere, composed mainly of nitrogen and oxygen, where weather occurs and pollution disperses."}}

{"explanation": "Biomass fuels are organic materials derived from living or recently living organisms (e.g., wood, crop residues, animal dung) that can be burned for energy. Their combustion can release air pollutants like particulate matter and carbon monoxide, especially with inefficient burning.", "urdu_meaning": "حیاتیاتی ایندھن - جانداروں سے حاصل کردہ نامیاتی مواد جو توانائی کے لیے جلایا جاتا ہے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Indoor air pollution from burning biomass fuels on open fires is a major health concern in many developing countries.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Renewable organic matter used as a source of energy.", "related_concepts": ["combustion", "air pollution", "indoor air pollution", "particulate matter", "carbon monoxide", "renewable energy", "bioenergy"], "real_world_example": "Wood used for cooking and heating, ethanol produced from corn, biodiesel from vegetable oils."}}

{"explanation": "Carbon dioxide (CO₂) is a major greenhouse gas produced by the combustion of fossil fuels and biomass, as well as by respiration and decomposition. Its increasing atmospheric concentration is a primary driver of global climate change.", "urdu_meaning": "کاربن ڈائی آکسائیڈ - CO₂", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "While essential for photosynthesis, excessive atmospheric carbon dioxide contributes to the greenhouse effect and global warming.", "properties": {"formula": "CO₂", "molar_mass": "44.01 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Asphyxiant (high conc.)", "Greenhouse gas"]}}

{"explanation": "Carbon monoxide (CO) is a colorless, odorless, toxic air pollutant produced by the incomplete combustion of carbon-containing fuels (e.g., fossil fuels, biomass). It impairs oxygen transport in the blood by binding to hemoglobin.", "urdu_meaning": "کاربن مونو آکسائیڈ - CO، ایک زہریلی گیس", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "Malfunctioning heating appliances or car exhaust in enclosed spaces can lead to dangerous levels of carbon monoxide.", "properties": {"formula": "CO", "molar_mass": "28.01 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Highly toxic by inhalation", "Flammable", "Chemical asphyxiant"]}}

{"explanation": "Decomposition is the process by which organic substances are broken down into simpler organic or inorganic matter by microorganisms or chemical processes. It can release gases like methane and carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.", "urdu_meaning": "گلنے سڑنے کا عمل / تحلیل - نامیاتی مادوں کا سادہ اجزاء میں ٹوٹنا", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "The decomposition of organic waste in landfills is a significant source of atmospheric methane, a potent greenhouse gas.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Breakdown of complex organic matter into simpler substances.", "related_concepts": ["biodegradation", "microorganisms", "organic matter", "carbon cycle", "methane", "carbon dioxide", "landfills", "composting"], "real_world_example": "Rotting leaves in a forest; food waste decomposing in a compost bin."}}

{"explanation": "Fog is a visible aerosol consisting of tiny water droplets or ice crystals suspended in the air at or near the Earth's surface, which can trap air pollutants, leading to events like smog.", "urdu_meaning": "دُھند - ہوا میں معلق پانی کے چھوٹے قطروں یا برف کے قلموں کا بادل", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Industrial pollutants can combine with fog to create hazardous smog conditions in urban areas.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A cloud at ground level, reducing visibility.", "related_concepts": ["aerosol", "water droplets", "ice crystals", "visibility", "smog", "thermal inversions", "air pollution"], "real_world_example": "Dense fog common in coastal areas or valleys under specific meteorological conditions."}}

{"explanation": "Fossil fuels (coal, oil, natural gas) are combustible geologic deposits of organic materials. Their combustion is a major source of air pollutants like CO₂, SO₂, NOx, and particulate matter, contributing to smog, acid rain, and global climate change.", "urdu_meaning": "رکازی ایندھن - قدیم نامیاتی مواد سے بننے والا ایندھن", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The widespread burning of fossil fuels for energy production and transportation is the primary cause of increased greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Carbon-based fuels derived from ancient biomass, formed over millions of years.", "related_concepts": ["combustion", "air pollutants", "greenhouse gases", "carbon dioxide", "sulfur dioxide", "nitrogen oxides", "particulate matter", "climate change", "acid rain", "smog"], "real_world_example": "Coal burned in power plants, gasoline in cars, natural gas for heating."}}

{"explanation": "Global climate change refers to long-term alterations in Earth's climate system, including temperature, precipitation, and wind patterns, primarily driven by human-induced increases in atmospheric greenhouse gases from sources like fossil fuel combustion.", "urdu_meaning": "عالمی موسمیاتی تبدیلی - زمین کے موسمی نظام میں طویل مدتی تبدیلیاں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The emission of greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide and methane from human activities is the main driver of global climate change.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Significant and lasting changes in Earth's climate patterns over extended periods.", "related_concepts": ["climate change", "global warming", "greenhouse effect", "greenhouse gases", "carbon dioxide", "methane", "fossil fuels", "atmospheric pollution"], "real_world_example": "Rising global temperatures, sea-level rise, changes in extreme weather events."}}

{"explanation": "A greenhouse gas is an atmospheric gas that absorbs and emits infrared radiation, causing the greenhouse effect and contributing to global warming. Key examples include carbon dioxide, methane, and nitrous oxide.", "urdu_meaning": "گرین ہاؤس گیس - حرارت جذب کرنے والی فضائی گیس", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Methane is a potent greenhouse gas, with a much higher global warming potential per molecule than carbon dioxide over shorter timeframes.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A gas in the atmosphere that traps heat by absorbing and re-radiating infrared radiation.", "related_concepts": ["greenhouse gases (plural)", "greenhouse effect", "global warming", "carbon dioxide", "methane", "nitrous oxide", "water vapor", "ozone", "infrared radiation"], "real_world_example": "CO₂ from burning fossil fuels."}}

{"explanation": "Greenhouse gases are atmospheric components (e.g., CO₂, CH₄, N₂O, water vapor) that trap heat by absorbing infrared radiation, contributing to the Earth's natural greenhouse effect and, at increased levels, to global warming and climate change.", "urdu_meaning": "گرین ہاؤس گیسیں - حرارت جذب کرنے والی فضائی گیسیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Human activities, particularly the burning of fossil fuels and deforestation, have led to a significant increase in the atmospheric concentrations of greenhouse gases.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Atmospheric gases that absorb and emit radiation within the thermal infrared range, causing the greenhouse effect.", "related_concepts": ["greenhouse gas (singular)", "greenhouse effect", "global warming", "climate change", "carbon dioxide", "methane", "nitrous oxide", "water vapor", "ozone", "fossil fuels", "atmospheric composition"], "real_world_example": "Carbon dioxide (CO₂), Methane (CH₄), Nitrous oxide (N₂O)."}}

{"explanation": "Ground-level ozone (O₃) is a secondary air pollutant formed by chemical reactions between nitrogen oxides (NOx) and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in the presence of sunlight. It is a major component of smog and harmful to human health and vegetation.", "urdu_meaning": "زمینی سطح کی اوزون - ٹروپوسفیئر میں بننے والی نقصان دہ اوزون", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "High concentrations of ground-level ozone are often found in urban areas during sunny weather due to emissions from vehicles and industry.", "properties": {"formula": "O₃", "molar_mass": "48.00 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Respiratory irritant", "Damages lung tissue", "Harmful to plants", "Key component of photochemical smog"]}}

{"explanation": "Hemoglobin is a protein in red blood cells that transports oxygen from the lungs to the body's tissues. Carbon monoxide binds to hemoglobin much more strongly than oxygen, impairing oxygen transport and causing CO poisoning.", "urdu_meaning": "ہیموگلوبن - خون میں آکسیجن منتقل کرنے والا پروٹین", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "The high affinity of carbon monoxide for hemoglobin makes it a dangerous asphyxiant, as it prevents adequate oxygen delivery to cells.", "properties": {"formula": "Complex protein (quaternary structure)", "molar_mass": "~64,500 g/mol (human)", "state_room_temp": "Protein in aqueous solution (blood)", "hazards": ["N/A (biological molecule, but its function can be impaired by toxins like CO)"]}}

{"explanation": "Hydrocarbons are organic compounds consisting entirely of hydrogen and carbon. Incomplete combustion of hydrocarbons (e.g., in vehicle engines) can release unburned hydrocarbons, carbon monoxide, and particulate matter as air pollutants.", "urdu_meaning": "ہائیڈروکاربن - ہائیڈروجن اور کاربن پر مشتمل نامیاتی مرکبات", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Volatile organic compounds (VOCs), many of which are hydrocarbons, contribute to the formation of ground-level ozone and smog.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Organic molecules composed solely of carbon and hydrogen atoms.", "related_concepts": ["organic chemistry", "fossil fuels", "volatile organic compounds (VOCs)", "combustion", "air pollution", "smog", "alkanes", "alkenes", "alkynes", "aromatic hydrocarbons"], "real_world_example": "Methane (CH₄), Propane (C₃H₈), Benzene (C₆H₆)."}}

{"explanation": "Indoor air pollution refers to the contamination of air within buildings, often caused by sources like burning biomass fuels or coal for cooking/heating, tobacco smoke, building materials, and household chemicals, posing significant health risks.", "urdu_meaning": "اندرونی فضائی آلودگی - عمارتوں کے اندر ہوا کی آلودگی", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Burning wood or coal indoors without proper ventilation can lead to high levels of indoor air pollution, including carbon monoxide and particulate matter.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Presence of air pollutants inside enclosed spaces.", "related_concepts": ["air pollution", "pollutants", "biomass fuels", "carbon monoxide", "particulate matter", "volatile organic compounds", "radon", "tobacco smoke", "health effects"], "real_world_example": "Smoke from cooking fires in poorly ventilated homes; formaldehyde emitted from new furniture or building materials."}}

{"explanation": "Methane (CH₄) is a potent greenhouse gas and air pollutant, released from natural sources (wetlands, termites) and human activities (agriculture, landfills, natural gas leakage, biomass burning).", "urdu_meaning": "میتھین - CH₄، ایک گرین ہاؤس گیس", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "Controlling methane emissions from sources like landfills and livestock is important for mitigating global climate change.", "properties": {"formula": "CH₄", "molar_mass": "16.04 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Highly flammable", "Greenhouse gas"]}}

It contributes to smog, acid rain, and respiratory problems.", "urdu_meaning": "نائٹروجن ڈائی آکسائیڈ - NO₂، ایک زہریلی فضائی آلودگی", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "Vehicle exhaust and power plants are major sources of atmospheric nitrogen dioxide.", "properties": {"formula": "NO₂", "molar_mass": "46.0055 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Toxic by inhalation", "Respiratory irritant", "Contributes to smog and acid rain"]}}

{"explanation": "Nitrogen oxides (NOx) are a group of highly reactive gases, primarily nitric oxide (NO) and nitrogen dioxide (NO₂), formed during high-temperature combustion (e.g., in engines and power plants). They are major air pollutants contributing to smog and acid rain.", "urdu_meaning": "نائٹروجن آکسائیڈز - NOx، فضائی آلودگی پھیلانے والی گیسیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Controlling emissions of nitrogen oxides from vehicles and industrial sources is crucial for improving air quality.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Reactive gases containing nitrogen and oxygen (mainly NO and NO₂), formed during combustion at high temperatures.", "related_concepts": ["nitric oxide (NO)", "nitrogen dioxide (NO₂)", "air pollutants", "combustion", "vehicle emissions", "industrial emissions", "smog", "acid rain", "ground-level ozone formation"], "real_world_example": "Exhaust from cars and trucks; emissions from power plants burning fossil fuels."}}

{"explanation": "Oxides of nitrogen (commonly NOx) refer to various compounds of nitrogen and oxygen, such as nitric oxide (NO) and nitrogen dioxide (NO₂), which are significant air pollutants.", "urdu_meaning": "نائٹروجن کے آکسائیڈ - نائٹروجن اور آکسیجن کے مرکبات", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The primary anthropogenic sources of oxides of nitrogen are combustion processes in vehicles and power plants.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A collective term for binary compounds of nitrogen and oxygen.", "related_concepts": ["nitrogen oxides (NOx)", "nitric oxide (NO)", "nitrogen dioxide (NO₂)", "air pollution", "smog", "acid rain"], "real_world_example": "NO and NO₂ found in vehicle exhaust."}}

{"explanation": "Oxides of sulfur, primarily sulfur dioxide (SO₂) and sulfur trioxide (SO₃), are air pollutants mainly produced by burning fossil fuels (especially coal) containing sulfur impurities. Air pollutants like carbon monoxide can impair oxygen transport.", "urdu_meaning": "آکسیجن کی نقل و حمل - پھیپھڑوں سے جسم کے حصوں تک آکسیجن کی منتقلی", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Carbon monoxide poisoning occurs because CO binds to hemoglobin more strongly than oxygen, thus inhibiting oxygen transport.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The delivery of oxygen from the respiratory system to tissues throughout the body.", "related_concepts": ["hemoglobin", "red blood cells", "respiration", "lungs", "oxygen", "carbon monoxide poisoning", "asphyxiant"], "real_world_example": "The circulatory system delivering oxygenated blood to muscles and organs."}}
