Sources include combustion (fossil fuels, biomass), industrial processes, and natural events.", "urdu_meaning": "ذراتی مادہ - ہوا میں معلق ٹھوس یا مائع ذرات", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Exposure to high levels of particulate matter is linked to increased rates of asthma and heart disease.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Microscopic solid or liquid particles suspended in the air, varying in size and composition (e.g., PM2.5, PM10).", "related_concepts": ["air pollutants", "aerosols", "smoke", "soot", "dust", "combustion", "fossil fuels", "biomass fuels", "vehicle emissions", "industrial emissions", "health effects", "air quality index"], "real_world_example": "Soot from diesel exhaust, dust from construction sites, fly ash from power plants."}}

{"explanation": "Particulate matter levels refer to the concentration of particulate matter (PM) in the air, often measured as PM2.5 (particles ≤ 2.5 μm) or PM10 (particles ≤ 10 μm). High levels indicate poor air quality.", "urdu_meaning": "ذراتی مادے کی سطحیں - ہوا میں ذراتی مادے کا ارتکاز", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "Urban areas with heavy traffic often experience high particulate matter levels, especially during rush hour.", "properties": {"describes": "The concentration of suspended particles in the air.", "related_concepts": ["particulate matter", "air quality index", "PM2.5", "PM10", "air pollution", "health effects"], "example_of_use": "Monitoring particulate matter levels is crucial for public health advisories.", "measurement_type": "Micrograms per cubic meter (µg/m³)."}}

{"explanation": "Parts per million (ppm) is a unit of concentration, representing one part of a substance per million parts of the total mixture (e.g., 1 mg per kg, or 1 μL per L). It's often used to express concentrations of air pollutants.", "urdu_meaning": "حصے فی ملین (پی پی ایم) - ارتکاز کی ایک اکائی", "term_type": "unit", "example_sentence": "The concentration of carbon monoxide in polluted air can reach several parts per million, posing a health risk.", "properties": {"measures_quantity": "Concentration (dimensionless ratio, or mass/volume, volume/volume)", "symbol_if_any": "ppm", "system": "Ratio (10⁻⁶)"}}

{"explanation": "Smog is a type of severe air pollution, originally a portmanteau of 'smoke' and 'fog'. It often consists of ground-level ozone, particulate matter, sulfur dioxide, and nitrogen oxides, reducing visibility and harming health.", "urdu_meaning": "اسموگ / دھواں دھند - شدید فضائی آلودگی کی ایک قسم", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Photochemical smog, common in sunny urban areas, is formed by reactions involving vehicle emissions (NOx and VOCs) and sunlight to produce ozone and other pollutants.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A visible haze of air pollution, often a mixture of smoke, fog, and chemical pollutants.", "related_concepts": ["air pollution", "ground-level ozone", "particulate matter", "nitrogen oxides", "sulfur dioxide", "volatile organic compounds", "fog", "smoke", "photochemical smog", "industrial smog", "thermal inversions"], "real_world_example": "The brown haze often seen over large cities like Los Angeles or Beijing."}}

{"explanation": "Smoke is a collection of airborne solid and liquid particulates and gases emitted when a material undergoes combustion or pyrolysis, together with the quantity of air that is entrained or otherwise mixed into the mass. It's a major component of particulate matter pollution.", "urdu_meaning": "دھواں - جلنے کے عمل سے خارج ہونے والے ہوا میں معلق ذرات اور گیسیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Smoke from wildfires or burning biomass fuels contributes significantly to air pollution and can travel long distances.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Airborne products of incomplete combustion, consisting of particles and gases.", "related_concepts": ["combustion", "particulate matter", "soot", "aerosols", "air pollution", "biomass fuels", "wildfires", "smog"], "real_world_example": "Smoke rising from a campfire; exhaust smoke from a diesel truck."}}

{"explanation": "Sulfur dioxide (SO₂) is a colorless, toxic air pollutant gas with a pungent odor, primarily produced by burning fossil fuels (especially coal) containing sulfur. It is a major cause of acid rain and respiratory problems.", "urdu_meaning": "سلفر ڈائی آکسائیڈ - SO₂، ایک زہریلی فضائی آلودگی", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "Power plants and industrial boilers burning high-sulfur coal are significant sources of sulfur dioxide emissions.", "properties": {"formula": "SO₂", "molar_mass": "64.066 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Toxic by inhalation", "Respiratory irritant", "Major contributor to acid rain", "Forms sulfurous acid with water"]}}

{"explanation": "Thermal inversions occur when a layer of warm air traps cooler, denser air near the ground, preventing vertical mixing and leading to the accumulation of air pollutants like smog and particulate matter close to the surface.", "urdu_meaning": "حرارتی الٹاؤ - گرم ہوا کی تہہ کا ٹھنڈی ہوا کو زمین کے قریب قید کرنا", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Thermal inversions can exacerbate air pollution episodes in valleys or coastal areas by trapping pollutants near their source.", "properties": {"key_principle": "An atmospheric condition where temperature increases with altitude in a layer, inhibiting vertical air movement.", "related_concepts": ["atmosphere", "air pollution", "smog", "particulate matter", "meteorology", "temperature gradient", "air quality"], "real_world_example": "A common occurrence in cities surrounded by mountains, leading to prolonged periods of poor air quality."}}

{"explanation": "Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs) are organic chemicals that have a high vapor pressure at ordinary room temperature, meaning they evaporate easily. They are air pollutants that contribute to the formation of ground-level ozone and smog.", "urdu_meaning": "غیر مستحکم نامیاتی مرکبات (وی او سی) - آسانی سے بخارات بننے والے نامیاتی کیمیکل", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Sources of volatile organic compounds include vehicle emissions, industrial processes, paints, solvents, and natural sources like vegetation.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Carbon-containing chemicals that readily evaporate into the air at room temperature.", "related_concepts": ["air pollutants", "organic compounds", "hydrocarbons", "ground-level ozone", "smog", "photochemical reactions", "indoor air pollution", "solvents", "paints"], "real_world_example": "Benzene, formaldehyde, terpenes (from pine trees), gasoline vapors."}}

{"explanation": "Volcanic eruptions are natural events that release large amounts of gases (e.g., sulfur dioxide, carbon dioxide) and particulate matter (ash) into the atmosphere, significantly impacting air quality and sometimes global climate on short timescales.", "urdu_meaning": "آتش فشانی پھٹنا - آتش فشاں سے گیسوں اور راکھ کا اخراج", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Major volcanic eruptions can inject sulfur dioxide into the stratosphere, leading to the formation of sulfate aerosols that can cool the planet temporarily.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Sudden emission of magma, ash, and gases from a volcano.", "related_concepts": ["natural disasters", "air pollutants", "sulfur dioxide", "carbon dioxide", "particulate matter (ash)", "aerosols", "stratosphere", "climate effects", "geology"], "real_world_example": "The 1991 eruption of Mount Pinatubo, which had a noticeable global cooling effect."}}

{"explanation": "Acid deposition refers to the transfer of acidic pollutants from the atmosphere to Earth's surface, occurring in both wet forms (acid rain, snow, fog) and dry forms (acidic gases and particles).", "urdu_meaning": "تیزابی جمعاؤ - تیزابی آلودگی کا زمین پر منتقل ہونا", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Acid deposition can affect large areas, damaging forests, soils, and aquatic ecosystems far from the original pollution sources.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The process by which acidic components (e.g., sulfuric acid, nitric acid) are deposited from the atmosphere onto surfaces.", "related_concepts": ["acid rain", "wet deposition", "dry deposition", "atmospheric pollution", "sulfur dioxide", "nitrogen oxides", "environmental impacts", "ecosystems"], "real_world_example": "Acidic sulfates and nitrates falling as dry particles or being washed out by rain."}}

{"explanation": "Acid rain is precipitation (rain, snow, fog) with a pH lower than normal (typically < 5.6) due to atmospheric pollution, primarily from sulfur dioxide (SO₂) and nitrogen oxides (NOx) released by burning fossil fuels.", "urdu_meaning": "تیزابی بارش - فضائی آلودگی سے تیزابی ہونے والی بارش", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The formation of acid rain involves complex atmospheric chemical reactions where SO₂ and NOx are converted into sulfuric acid and nitric acid.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Precipitation made acidic by atmospheric pollutants, primarily SO₂ and NOx.", "related_concepts": ["acid deposition", "atmospheric pollution", "sulfur dioxide", "nitrogen oxides", "sulfuric acid", "nitric acid", "pH", "fossil fuels", "environmental impacts", "acid rain damage"], "real_world_example": "Damage to marble statues and acidification of lakes in industrial regions."}}

{"explanation": "Acid rain damage refers to the adverse effects of acid rain on the environment, including acidification of lakes and soils, harm to forests and aquatic life, corrosion of buildings and statues, and leaching of toxic metals.", "urdu_meaning": "تیزابی بارش کا نقصان - تیزابی بارش سے ہونے والے مضر اثرات", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Acid rain damage to forests can manifest as stunted growth, leaf damage, and increased susceptibility to disease.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Harmful consequences of acidic precipitation on natural and man-made environments.", "related_concepts": ["acid rain", "acid deposition", "environmental impacts", "ecosystems", "acidification", "corrosion", "leaching", "toxic metals", "plant health", "aquatic life"], "real_world_example": "Death of fish in acidified lakes, erosion of limestone buildings, release of aluminum into soil water."}}

{"explanation": "Acid-base chemistry is relevant to understanding acid rain, as it involves the formation of acids (sulfuric, nitric) in the atmosphere and their subsequent neutralization or interaction with basic materials on Earth (e.g., limestone).", "urdu_meaning": "تیزاب-اساس کیمیا - تیزاب اور اساس کی خصوصیات اور تعاملات کا علم", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The principles of acid-base chemistry help explain how acid rain lowers the pH of water bodies and soil.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Study of acids, bases, and their reactions, including pH and neutralization.", "related_concepts": ["acids", "bases", "pH", "neutralization", "acid rain", "sulfuric acid", "nitric acid", "buffering capacity"], "real_world_example": "The reaction of acidic rainwater with limestone (calcium carbonate, a base) to neutralize the acidity."}}

{"explanation": "Acidic compounds are substances that can donate protons or increase hydrogen ion concentration. In the context of acid rain, sulfuric acid (H₂SO₄) and nitric acid (HNO₃) are the primary acidic compounds formed in the atmosphere.", "urdu_meaning": "تیزابی مرکبات - پروٹان دینے والے یا ہائیڈروجن آئن بڑھانے والے مرکبات", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The acidic compounds in acid rain are formed from the atmospheric oxidation of sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Chemicals that exhibit acidic properties (e.g., pH < 7 in solution, ability to donate H⁺).", "related_concepts": ["acids", "acid rain", "sulfuric acid", "nitric acid", "sulfurous acid", "pH", "atmospheric chemical reactions"], "real_world_example": "H₂SO₄ and HNO₃ dissolved in rainwater."}}

{"explanation": "Acidified describes something that has become acidic or has had its acidity increased, for example, lakes or soils affected by acid rain.", "urdu_meaning": "تیزابی بنایا گیا / تیزابی ہو جانا - تیزابی خصوصیات کا حامل ہو جانا", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "Lakes in regions with heavy acid rain can become acidified, harming fish populations.", "properties": {"describes": "The state of having been made acidic or more acidic.", "related_concepts": ["acidity", "pH", "acid rain", "acid deposition", "lakes", "soils", "environmental impacts"], "example_of_use": "Testing the pH of an acidified lake shows a value significantly below neutral.", "measurement_type": "pH measurement."}}

{"explanation": "Acidity refers to the level of acid in a substance, often measured by pH. Acid rain is characterized by high acidity (low pH) due to dissolved acidic compounds.", "urdu_meaning": "تیزابیت - کسی مادے میں تیزاب کی سطح", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The acidity of rainwater is increased by atmospheric pollutants like sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides.", "properties": {"describes": "The concentration of hydrogen ions (H⁺ or H₃O⁺) in a solution, indicating its acid strength.", "related_concepts": ["pH", "acids", "acidic compounds", "acid rain", "acidified", "hydrogen ion concentration"], "example_of_use": "Measuring the acidity of soil helps determine its suitability for different plants.", "measurement_type": "pH scale, titration."}}

{"explanation": "The atmosphere is where pollutants like sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides undergo chemical reactions to form the acidic compounds responsible for acid rain.", "urdu_meaning": "فضا - زمین کے گرد گیسوں کا غلاف", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Chemical reactions in the atmosphere convert primary pollutants into secondary pollutants like sulfuric acid and nitric acid found in acid rain.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The gaseous envelope surrounding Earth, where meteorological and chemical processes occur.", "related_concepts": ["atmospheric chemical reactions", "atmospheric pollution", "acid rain formation", "pollutants", "sulfur dioxide", "nitrogen oxides"], "real_world_example": "Clouds in the atmosphere are where acidic pollutants dissolve to form acid rain."}}

{"explanation": "Atmospheric chemical reactions are chemical transformations that occur in the Earth's atmosphere, including the oxidation of SO₂ and NOx to form sulfuric acid and nitric acid, the key components of acid rain.", "urdu_meaning": "فضائی کیمیائی تعاملات - فضا میں ہونے والے کیمیائی ردعمل", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Sunlight often plays a role in initiating atmospheric chemical reactions that lead to the formation of acid rain and smog.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Chemical processes occurring within the Earth's atmosphere, often involving photochemistry, oxidation, and radical species.", "related_concepts": ["atmosphere", "acid rain formation", "smog formation", "photochemistry", "oxidation", "sulfur dioxide", "nitrogen oxides", "ozone", "pollutants"], "real_world_example": "The reaction SO₂(g) + ½O₂(g) + H₂O(l) → H₂SO₄(aq) (simplified) in cloud droplets."}}

While relatively inert, it can be converted to nitrogen oxides (NOx) during high-temperature combustion, which then contribute to acid rain.", "urdu_meaning": "فضائی نائٹروجن - N₂", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "During lightning strikes or in combustion engines, atmospheric nitrogen can react with oxygen to form nitrogen oxides, precursors to acid rain.", "properties": {"formula": "N₂", "molar_mass": "28.014 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Asphyxiant (high conc.)"]}}

{"explanation": "Atmospheric pollution is the contamination of the atmosphere with harmful substances (pollutants) like SO₂, NOx, particulate matter, etc., which can lead to environmental problems such as acid rain and smog.", "urdu_meaning": "فضائی آلودگی - فضا کی نقصان دہ مادوں سے آلودگی", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The primary cause of acid rain is atmospheric pollution from industrial activities and vehicle emissions.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Introduction of harmful substances into the Earth's atmosphere.", "related_concepts": ["air pollutants", "acid rain", "smog", "greenhouse gases", "sulfur dioxide", "nitrogen oxides", "combustion", "fossil fuels", "environmental impacts"], "real_world_example": "Smoke from factories, exhaust from cars, dust storms."}}

{"explanation": "The 'chemical boomerang' effect can refer to how pollutants emitted in one region can be transported by atmospheric processes and deposited elsewhere, causing environmental damage (like acid rain) far from the source, effectively 'returning' the problem.", "urdu_meaning": "کیمیائی بومرینگ - آلودگی کا دور دراز علاقوں میں منتقل ہو کر نقصان پہنچانا", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Acid rain often exemplifies a chemical boomerang, as pollutants from industrial areas can damage sensitive ecosystems hundreds of miles away.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Long-range transport of pollutants leading to environmental impacts in distant areas.", "related_concepts": ["atmospheric transport", "acid rain", "pollutants", "transboundary pollution", "environmental impacts"], "real_world_example": "SO₂ emitted in an industrial region causing acid rain in a remote forest or lake."}}

{"explanation": "Chemical equation analysis involves examining balanced chemical equations to understand stoichiometry, identify reactants and products, and determine the conditions for reactions, such as those involved in acid rain formation.", "urdu_meaning": "کیمیائی مساوات کا تجزیہ - کیمیائی تعاملات کو سمجھنے کے لیے مساوات کا جائزہ", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Through chemical equation analysis, we can see how sulfur dioxide reacts with oxygen and water to form sulfuric acid, a component of acid rain.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Interpreting chemical equations to extract quantitative and qualitative information about reactions.", "related_concepts": ["chemical equation", "stoichiometry", "reactants", "products", "balancing equations", "acid rain formation"], "real_world_example": "Analyzing the equation 2SO₂(g) + O₂(g) ⇌ 2SO₃(g) to understand the molar ratios in sulfuric acid production."}}

{"explanation": "Chemicals are distinct compounds or substances. In the context of acid rain, key chemicals include sulfur dioxide (SO₂), nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulfuric acid (H₂SO₄), and nitric acid (HNO₃).", "urdu_meaning": "کیمیکلز / کیمیائی مادے - مخصوص ساخت اور خصوصیات والے مرکبات", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The release of certain industrial chemicals into the atmosphere can lead to the formation of acid rain.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Substances with defined chemical composition and structure.", "related_concepts": ["compounds", "elements", "pollutants", "acid rain", "sulfur dioxide", "nitrogen oxides", "sulfuric acid", "nitric acid"], "real_world_example": "SO₂, NOx, H₂SO₄, HNO₃ involved in acid rain."}}

{"explanation": "Combustion, especially of fossil fuels containing sulfur and in high-temperature engines (producing NOx), is a primary source of the atmospheric pollutants that lead to acid rain.", "urdu_meaning": "احتراق / جلنا - ایندھن کا آکسیجن کے ساتھ ردعمل", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "The combustion of coal in power plants releases sulfur dioxide, a major precursor to acid rain.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A rapid chemical reaction between a substance (fuel) and an oxidant (usually oxygen) producing heat and light.", "related_concepts": ["fossil fuels", "combustion engines", "air pollution", "acid rain", "sulfur dioxide", "nitrogen oxides", "carbon dioxide"], "real_world_example": "Burning coal, oil, or natural gas for energy."}}

{"explanation": "Combustion engines, such as those in vehicles, produce nitrogen oxides (NOx) at high temperatures by reaction of atmospheric nitrogen and oxygen. These NOx emissions are significant precursors to acid rain.", "urdu_meaning": "احتراقی انجن - وہ انجن جو ایندھن جلا کر توانائی پیدا کرتے ہیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Exhaust from combustion engines is a major source of nitrogen oxides that contribute to acid rain formation.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Engines that generate power by burning fuel internally.", "related_concepts": ["combustion", "vehicle emissions", "nitrogen oxides", "acid rain", "air pollution", "fossil fuels"], "real_world_example": "Gasoline and diesel engines in cars, trucks, and other machinery."}}

{"explanation": "Ecosystems are communities of living organisms interacting with their physical environment. Acid rain can severely damage various ecosystems, particularly aquatic (lakes, rivers) and forest ecosystems, by altering soil and water chemistry.", "urdu_meaning": "ماحولیاتی نظام - جانداروں اور ماحول کا باہمی ربط", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The acidification of lakes due to acid rain can lead to the loss of fish populations and disrupt entire aquatic ecosystems.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A biological community of interacting organisms and their physical environment.", "related_concepts": ["acid rain damage", "environmental impacts", "biodiversity", "food webs", "soil chemistry", "water chemistry", "acidification"], "real_world_example": "A forest ecosystem affected by acid rain showing tree decline; a lake ecosystem with reduced fish diversity due to acidification."}}

{"explanation": "An environmental problem is an issue arising from human activities or natural processes that negatively affects the environment. {"explanation": "Fossil fuels (coal, oil, natural gas) are primary sources of the sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides that cause acid rain when burned for energy in power plants, industries, and vehicles.", "urdu_meaning": "رکازی ایندھن - قدیم نامیاتی مواد سے بننے والا ایندھن", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The combustion of sulfur-containing fossil fuels like coal is a major contributor to acid rain.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Carbon-based fuels formed from ancient organic matter.", "related_concepts": ["combustion", "acid rain", "atmospheric pollution", "sulfur dioxide", "nitrogen oxides", "carbon dioxide", "climate change"], "real_world_example": "Burning coal in power stations; gasoline used in cars."}}

{"explanation": "Nitrogen oxides (NOx), primarily NO and NO₂, are air pollutants produced during high-temperature combustion (e.g., in engines, power plants). They react in the atmosphere to form nitric acid, a key component of acid rain.", "urdu_meaning": "نائٹروجن آکسائیڈز - NOx، تیزابی بارش کے پیش خیمہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Reducing emissions of nitrogen oxides from vehicles is essential for mitigating acid rain.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Reactive gases containing nitrogen and oxygen (mainly NO, NO₂), precursors to nitric acid in acid rain.", "related_concepts": ["nitric oxide (NO)", "nitrogen dioxide (NO₂)", "atmospheric pollution", "acid rain", "smog", "combustion", "combustion engines", "fossil fuels"], "real_world_example": "Exhaust fumes from cars contain NOx."}}

This is a mitigation strategy rather than a cause or component of acid rain itself.", "urdu_meaning": "حفاظتی سیلنٹ - سطحوں کو نقصان سے بچانے والی تہہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Applying a protective sealant to marble statues can help shield them from the corrosive effects of acid rain.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A material used to coat and seal surfaces to prevent damage from environmental factors.", "related_concepts": ["corrosion prevention", "acid rain damage", "coatings", "material protection"], "real_world_example": "Waterproof sealant for concrete; anti-corrosion paint for metal structures."}}

In the context of acid rain, liming (adding calcium carbonate or calcium hydroxide) acts as a specialized neutralizer for acidified lakes and soils.", "urdu_meaning": "خصوصی بے اثر کرنے والے مادے - تیزابیت یا اساسیت کو ختم کرنے والے مخصوص کیمیکل", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Liming lakes with specialized neutralizers like powdered limestone can help restore their pH after acidification by acid rain.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Substances used to specifically neutralize acids or bases in particular environmental or industrial contexts.", "related_concepts": ["neutralization", "acid-base chemistry", "acid rain", "liming", "calcium carbonate", "calcium hydroxide", "pH adjustment", "remediation"], "real_world_example": "Adding lime to acidified agricultural soil to improve crop growth."}}

{"explanation": "Toxic metals (e.g., aluminum, mercury, lead, cadmium) can be mobilized from soils and sediments into water bodies by acid rain due to increased acidity, posing risks to aquatic life and potentially human health through the food chain.", "urdu_meaning": "زہریلی دھاتیں - ماحول اور جانداروں کے لیے نقصان دہ دھاتیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Acid rain can leach toxic metals like aluminum from soil into lakes, where they can harm fish and other aquatic organisms.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Metallic elements that are poisonous or harmful to living organisms even at low concentrations.", "related_concepts": ["heavy metals", "acid rain", "leaching", "bioaccumulation", "biomagnification", "environmental pollution", "water pollution", "soil pollution", "aluminum", "mercury", "lead", "cadmium"], "real_world_example": "Increased levels of soluble aluminum in acidified lakes harming fish gills."}}

Its increasing concentration is the main driver of the enhanced greenhouse effect and global warming.", "urdu_meaning": "کاربن ڈائی آکسائیڈ - CO₂، ایک اہم گرین ہاؤس گیس", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "The burning of fossil fuels releases large amounts of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, enhancing the greenhouse effect.", "properties": {"formula": "CO₂", "molar_mass": "44.01 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Asphyxiant (high conc.)", "Major greenhouse gas"]}}

{"explanation": "Combustion of fossil fuels (coal, oil, natural gas) and biomass is a major anthropogenic source of carbon dioxide, a key greenhouse gas contributing to the enhanced greenhouse effect.", "urdu_meaning": "احتراق / جلنا - ایندھن کا آکسیجن کے ساتھ ردعمل، CO₂ کا ذریعہ", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "The vast scale of fossil fuel combustion for energy production has significantly increased atmospheric carbon dioxide levels.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Rapid chemical reaction with an oxidant (usually oxygen) that produces heat and light, often releasing CO₂.", "related_concepts": ["carbon dioxide", "fossil fuels", "greenhouse effect", "greenhouse gases", "air pollution", "climate change"], "real_world_example": "Burning gasoline in car engines; burning coal in power plants."}}

{"explanation": "Decomposition of organic matter by microorganisms in soil and oceans releases carbon dioxide (aerobic decomposition) and methane (anaerobic decomposition), both of which are greenhouse gases.", "urdu_meaning": "گلنے سڑنے کا عمل / تحلیل - نامیاتی مادوں کا ٹوٹنا، CO₂ اور CH₄ کا ذریعہ", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "The decomposition of dead plants and animals returns carbon to the atmosphere, partly as carbon dioxide.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Breakdown of organic substances by biological or chemical processes.", "related_concepts": ["carbon cycle", "carbon dioxide", "methane", "greenhouse gases", "organic matter", "microorganisms", "soil respiration"], "real_world_example": "Composting of garden waste releases CO₂; decomposition in waterlogged soils can release CH₄."}}

{"explanation": "Fossil fuels (coal, oil, natural gas) are carbon-rich deposits formed from ancient organic matter. Their combustion is the largest human-caused source of carbon dioxide emissions, significantly enhancing the greenhouse effect.", "urdu_meaning": "رکازی ایندھن - قدیم نامیاتی مواد سے بننے والا ایندھن، CO₂ کا بڑا ذریعہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The global reliance on fossil fuels for energy is a primary factor in the increasing atmospheric concentration of greenhouse gases.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Combustible geologic deposits of organic materials, primarily carbon and hydrogen.", "related_concepts": ["combustion", "carbon dioxide", "greenhouse gases", "greenhouse effect", "climate change", "energy resources"], "real_world_example": "Coal used for electricity generation, petroleum for transportation fuels, natural gas for heating."}}

{"explanation": "Geoengineering solutions are large-scale technological interventions designed to counteract climate change, such as by removing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere or reflecting sunlight. Their feasibility and impacts are subjects of ongoing research and debate.", "urdu_meaning": "جیو انجینئرنگ حل - موسمیاتی تبدیلی کا مقابلہ کرنے کے لیے بڑے پیمانے پر تکنیکی مداخلتیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Some proposed geoengineering solutions aim to reduce the greenhouse effect by artificially increasing Earth's albedo or capturing atmospheric carbon dioxide.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Deliberate, large-scale manipulation of Earth's climate system to mitigate climate change.", "related_concepts": ["climate change", "global warming", "greenhouse effect", "carbon dioxide removal (CDR)", "solar radiation management (SRM)", "carbon capture", "afforestation"], "real_world_example": "Proposals for ocean fertilization to enhance CO₂ uptake by phytoplankton; stratospheric aerosol injection to reflect sunlight."}}

{"explanation": "The greenhouse effect is a natural process where certain atmospheric gases (greenhouse gases like CO₂, CH₄, H₂O vapor) trap some of the Earth's outgoing infrared radiation, warming the planet's surface to a temperature suitable for life. Human activities are enhancing this effect.", "urdu_meaning": "گرین ہاؤس اثر - فضائی گیسوں کا زمین کی حرارت کو قید کرنا", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Without the natural greenhouse effect, Earth's average temperature would be much colder, making life as we know it impossible.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Warming of Earth's surface and lower atmosphere due to the absorption and re-emission of infrared radiation by greenhouse gases.", "related_concepts": ["greenhouse gases", "infrared radiation", "carbon dioxide", "methane", "water vapor", "global warming", "climate change", "atmospheric temperature"], "real_world_example": "The process that keeps Earth habitable, but its enhancement by human emissions leads to global warming."}}

{"explanation": "Infrared (IR) radiation is a type of electromagnetic radiation with wavelengths longer than visible light. Greenhouse gases in the atmosphere absorb and re-emit infrared radiation emitted by the Earth's surface, which is the mechanism of the greenhouse effect.", "urdu_meaning": "زیریں سرخ / انفراریڈ - نظر آنے والی روشنی سے لمبی طول موج والی برقی مقناطیسی تابکاری", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Carbon dioxide and water vapor are strong absorbers of infrared radiation, contributing significantly to the greenhouse effect.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Electromagnetic radiation in the wavelength range of approximately 700 nm to 1 mm.", "related_concepts": ["electromagnetic spectrum", "radiation", "heat", "greenhouse effect", "greenhouse gases", "absorption spectrum", "spectroscopy"], "real_world_example": "Heat felt from a fire or the sun; thermal imaging cameras detect infrared radiation."}}

{"explanation": "Methane (CH₄) is a powerful greenhouse gas, with a higher global warming potential per molecule than carbon dioxide over shorter timescales, produced by anaerobic decomposition, agriculture, and fossil fuel extraction.", "urdu_meaning": "میتھین - CH₄، ایک طاقتور گرین ہاؤس گیس", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "Reducing methane emissions from sources like landfills and livestock is considered an important strategy to mitigate short-term global warming.", "properties": {"formula": "CH₄", "molar_mass": "16.04 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Highly flammable", "Forms explosive mixtures", "Potent greenhouse gas"]}}

{"explanation": "Photosynthesis is a process used by plants and other organisms to convert light energy into chemical energy, taking in atmospheric carbon dioxide and releasing oxygen. It is a key process in the global carbon cycle, removing CO₂ from the atmosphere.", "urdu_meaning": "ضیائی تالیف - پودوں کا CO₂ جذب کرکے آکسیجن خارج کرنے کا عمل", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Large-scale deforestation reduces the capacity of photosynthesis to absorb atmospheric carbon dioxide, contributing to the greenhouse effect.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Biological conversion of light energy into chemical energy, consuming CO₂ and producing O₂.", "related_concepts": ["carbon dioxide", "oxygen", "carbon cycle", "plants", "algae", "chlorophyll", "glucose", "greenhouse effect (mitigation by CO₂ uptake)"], "real_world_example": "Forests and oceans act as major sinks for atmospheric CO₂ through photosynthesis."}}

{"explanation": "Water vapor (H₂O gas) is the most abundant natural greenhouse gas in the atmosphere and plays a crucial role in the Earth's climate system and greenhouse effect, acting as a positive feedback mechanism for warming caused by other greenhouse gases.", "urdu_meaning": "آبی بخارات - H₂O گیس، ایک اہم قدرتی گرین ہاؤس گیس", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "As the atmosphere warms due to increased CO₂, it can hold more water vapor, which further enhances the greenhouse effect.", "properties": {"formula": "H₂O", "molar_mass": "18.015 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas (variable concentration in atmosphere)", "hazards": ["Generally non-hazardous", "Most significant natural greenhouse gas"]}}

{"explanation": "Air Quality Index (AQI) is a numerical scale used to report the level of air pollution and its potential health effects, considering pollutants like sulfur dioxide, carbon monoxide, and particulate matter.", "urdu_meaning": "ہوا کے معیار کا اشاریہ - ہوا کی آلودگی کی سطح اور صحت پر اثرات بتانے والا پیمانہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "A high Air Quality Index value, often due to increased sulfur dioxide or particulate matter, can trigger respiratory issues in sensitive individuals.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A standardized system for communicating daily air quality based on concentrations of key pollutants.", "related_concepts": ["aqi", "air pollution", "pollutants", "sulfur dioxide", "carbon monoxide", "nitrogen oxides", "particulate matter", "ozone", "public health", "environmental protection"], "real_world_example": "Checking the local AQI before engaging in outdoor activities, especially for people with respiratory conditions."}}

{"explanation": "AQI is the abbreviation for Air Quality Index, a system used to measure and report air pollution levels.", "urdu_meaning": "اے کیو آئی - ہوا کے معیار کے اشاریہ کا مخفف", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The AQI helps the public understand the health risks associated with current air pollution levels.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Abbreviation for Air Quality Index.", "related_concepts": ["air quality index", "air pollution", "pollutants", "public health"], "real_world_example": "An AQI of 150 is considered unhealthy for all groups."}}

{"explanation": "Carbon (C) is a nonmetal element that is the fundamental constituent of hydrocarbons and all organic compounds, capable of forming four covalent bonds and diverse structures (chains, rings).", "urdu_meaning": "کاربن - C، نامیاتی مرکبات کا بنیادی عنصر", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "The unique ability of carbon to form stable single, double, and triple bonds with itself and other elements is central to the vastness of organic chemistry.", "properties": {"symbol": "C", "atomic_number": 6, "category": "nonmetal", "state_room_temp": "solid (e.g., graphite, diamond)", "common_uses": ["Basis of organic compounds", "Fuels", "Polymers", "Nanomaterials"]}}

{"explanation": "Crude oil is a naturally occurring, unrefined petroleum product composed predominantly of hydrocarbons (alkanes, cycloalkanes, aromatic hydrocarbons), which is refined by fractional distillation to produce various fuels and chemical feedstocks.", "urdu_meaning": "خام تیل - قدرتی طور پر پایا جانے والا غیر صاف شدہ پیٹرولیم", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Fractional distillation of crude oil separates it into fractions like gasoline, kerosene, and diesel based on differences in boiling points of the constituent hydrocarbons.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A complex mixture of hydrocarbons found in geologic formations beneath Earth's surface.", "related_concepts": ["petroleum", "hydrocarbons", "alkanes", "aromatic hydrocarbons", "fossil fuels", "fractional distillation", "petroleum refining", "gasoline", "diesel"], "real_world_example": "The raw material extracted from oil wells before refining."}}

{"explanation": "Fractional distillation is a separation technique used to separate a mixture of liquids with different boiling points, such as separating crude oil into various hydrocarbon fractions (e.g., gasoline, kerosene, diesel).", "urdu_meaning": "کسری کشید - مختلف نقطہ کھولاؤ والے مائعات کو الگ کرنے کا طریقہ", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Petroleum refining heavily relies on fractional distillation to separate crude oil into useful hydrocarbon components.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Separation of a liquid mixture into fractions differing in boiling point by means of distillation, typically using a fractionating column.", "related_concepts": ["distillation", "boiling points", "crude oil", "petroleum refining", "hydrocarbons", "alkanes", "separation techniques"], "real_world_example": "Refining crude oil to obtain gasoline, diesel fuel, and other petroleum products."}}

{"explanation": "Hydrocarbons are organic compounds consisting entirely of hydrogen and carbon atoms. {"explanation": "Hydrogen bonding is a strong type of dipole-dipole intermolecular force involving a hydrogen atom bonded to a highly electronegative atom (N, O, or F). For nonpolar hydrocarbons (like alkanes, many alkenes/alkynes, benzene), the primary IMFs are London dispersion forces, which increase with molecular size and affect physical properties like boiling points.", "urdu_meaning": "بین المالیکیولی قوتیں - مالیکیولز کے درمیان کشش کی قوتیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The boiling points of alkanes increase with the number of carbon atoms due to stronger intermolecular forces (London dispersion forces).", "properties": {"key_principle": "Attractive forces that exist between molecules, influencing physical properties.", "related_concepts": ["London dispersion forces", "dipole-dipole forces", "hydrogen bonding", "hydrocarbons", "alkanes", "alkenes", "alkynes", "aromatic hydrocarbons", "boiling points", "melting points", "viscosity"], "real_world_example": "The weak London dispersion forces between methane molecules explain why it's a gas at room temperature."}}

{"explanation": "IUPAC nomenclature is the standardized system developed by the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry for naming chemical compounds, including hydrocarbons like alkanes, alkenes, alkynes, and aromatic hydrocarbons.", "urdu_meaning": "آئی یو پی اے سی نام رکھنے کا نظام - کیمیائی مرکبات کے نام رکھنے کا معیاری نظام", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "According to IUPAC nomenclature, CH₄ is named methane and C₂H₄ is named ethene.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A systematic method for naming chemical compounds to ensure unambiguous identification.", "related_concepts": ["organic compounds", "hydrocarbons", "alkanes", "alkenes", "alkynes", "aromatic hydrocarbons", "functional groups", "structural isomers", "chemical formula"], "real_world_example": "Naming 2-methylpropane instead of isobutane using IUPAC rules."}}

{"explanation": "Liquid oxygen (LOX) is the liquid form of molecular oxygen, often used as an oxidizer in rocket propellants, where it reacts with hydrocarbon fuels.", "urdu_meaning": "مائع آکسیجن - آکسیجن کی مائع حالت", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "Many rockets use liquid oxygen as an oxidizer in combination with hydrocarbon fuels like kerosene or liquid hydrogen.", "properties": {"formula": "O₂", "molar_mass": "31.998 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "liquid (at very low temperatures, below -183°C)", "hazards": ["Strong oxidizer", "Supports combustion intensely", "Cryogenic hazard (extremely cold)"]}}

{"explanation": "Cracking is a process used in petroleum refining where large alkane molecules are broken down into smaller, more useful alkanes and alkenes by heat and/or catalysts.", "urdu_meaning": "کریکنگ - بڑے الکین مالیکیولز کو چھوٹے مالیکیولز میں توڑنے کا عمل", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Catalytic cracking is used to convert heavy oil fractions (long-chain alkanes) into gasoline components (shorter-chain alkanes and alkenes).", "properties": {"key_principle": "Breaking down large hydrocarbon molecules into smaller ones.", "related_concepts": ["petroleum refining", "alkanes", "alkenes", "hydrocarbons", "catalytic cracking", "thermal cracking", "gasoline", "feedstock"], "real_world_example": "Converting long-chain alkanes from crude oil into shorter chains suitable for gasoline."}}

{"explanation": "Diesel fuel is a type of fuel derived from petroleum (crude oil) through fractional distillation, primarily composed of a mixture of alkanes with carbon chain lengths typically between C₁₀ and C₂₀.", "urdu_meaning": "ڈیزل - پیٹرولیم سے حاصل کردہ ایندھن، الکینز کا آمیزہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Diesel engines combust a mixture of alkanes that vaporize and ignite under high compression.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A fuel fraction from petroleum refining, consisting mainly of alkanes in the C₁₀-C₂₀ range.", "related_concepts": ["fuels", "petroleum", "fractional distillation", "alkanes", "hydrocarbons", "combustion", "diesel engine"], "real_world_example": "Fuel used in trucks, buses, and some cars."}}

{"explanation": "Electronegativity values measure an atom's ability to attract bonding electrons. The small difference in electronegativity values between carbon and hydrogen results in the C-H bonds in alkanes being only slightly polar, making alkanes generally nonpolar molecules.", "urdu_meaning": "برقی منفیت کی قدریں - ایٹم کی الیکٹران کشش کی پیمائش", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The similar electronegativity values of carbon (2.55) and hydrogen (2.20) lead to nearly nonpolar C-H bonds in alkanes.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Numerical scale representing an atom's tendency to attract electrons in a covalent bond.", "related_concepts": ["electronegativity", "bond polarity", "nonpolar nature (of alkanes)", "carbon", "hydrogen", "Pauling scale"], "real_world_example": "Fluorine has the highest electronegativity value (~4.0)."}}

{"explanation": "Ethane (C₂H₆) is the second simplest alkane, consisting of two carbon atoms single-bonded to each other and each bonded to three hydrogen atoms. It is a component of natural gas.", "urdu_meaning": "ایتھین - C₂H₆، دوسرا سادہ ترین الکین", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "Ethane is used as a petrochemical feedstock for the production of ethene (ethylene).", "properties": {"formula": "C₂H₆", "molar_mass": "30.07 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Highly flammable", "Forms explosive mixtures with air"]}}

{"explanation": "Feedstock is raw material supplied to an industrial process. Alkanes, derived from natural gas and petroleum, are important feedstocks for the petrochemical industry to produce plastics, synthetic fibers, and other chemicals.", "urdu_meaning": "خام مال / فیڈ اسٹاک - صنعتی عمل کے لیے فراہم کردہ ابتدائی مواد", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Ethane and propane (alkanes) are common feedstocks for producing alkenes like ethene and propene through cracking.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Raw material used to supply or fuel a machine or industrial process.", "related_concepts": ["petrochemicals", "alkanes", "alkenes", "natural gas", "petroleum", "cracking", "organic synthesis", "plastics"], "real_world_example": "Naphtha (a mixture of alkanes) used as feedstock for steam crackers to produce olefins."}}

{"explanation": "Fractional distillation is a key process in petroleum refining used to separate crude oil into various fractions (like gasoline, kerosene, diesel) based on the different boiling points of its constituent alkanes and other hydrocarbons.", "urdu_meaning": "کسری کشید - خام تیل کو مختلف ہائیڈروکاربن حصوں میں الگ کرنے کا طریقہ", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Through fractional distillation, complex mixtures of alkanes in crude oil are separated into simpler mixtures with specific boiling point ranges.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Separation of a liquid mixture into fractions based on differences in boiling points using a fractionating column.", "related_concepts": ["petroleum refining", "crude oil", "alkanes", "hydrocarbons", "boiling points", "separation techniques", "gasoline", "diesel", "kerosene"], "real_world_example": "Separating ethanol from water in alcohol production (though simpler distillation often used)."}}

{"explanation": "A fuel is any material that can be made to react with other substances (usually by combustion) to release energy as heat or for work. Alkanes like methane, propane, butane, and gasoline components are widely used as fuels.", "urdu_meaning": "ایندھن - توانائی پیدا کرنے کے لیے جلایا جانے والا مادہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The combustion of alkane fuels powers vehicles, heats homes, and generates electricity.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A substance that is consumed to produce energy, typically through combustion.", "related_concepts": ["fuels (plural)", "alkanes", "methane", "propane", "gasoline", "diesel", "kerosene", "combustion", "energy", "fossil fuels", "cng", "lpg"], "real_world_example": "Natural gas (mainly methane) used for cooking; gasoline (a mixture of alkanes) for cars."}}

{"explanation": "Fuels are substances that store potential energy and can release it, usually through combustion. Alkanes are a major class of hydrocarbon fuels derived from petroleum and natural gas.", "urdu_meaning": "ایندھن (جمع) - توانائی کے ذرائع", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Common fuels derived from alkanes include natural gas, LPG, gasoline, and diesel fuel.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Materials that are burned or otherwise consumed to produce energy.", "related_concepts": ["fuel (singular)", "alkanes", "hydrocarbons", "combustion", "energy", "fossil fuels", "petroleum", "natural gas", "cng", "lpg"], "real_world_example": "Wood, coal, oil, natural gas, hydrogen."}}

{"explanation": "Functional groups are specific arrangements of atoms within organic molecules that determine their chemical properties and reactivity. Alkanes themselves lack functional groups (other than C-C and C-H single bonds), but they form the backbone for molecules that do contain them (e.g., alkyl halides, alcohols).", "urdu_meaning": "فعالی گروہ - نامیاتی مالیکیولز میں ایٹموں کے مخصوص گروہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "While alkanes are relatively unreactive, the introduction of functional groups like -OH (alcohol) or -Cl (alkyl halide) dramatically changes their chemical behavior.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Specific groups of atoms within molecules that are responsible for the characteristic chemical reactions of those molecules.", "related_concepts": ["organic compounds", "alkanes (as basic structures)", "alcohols", "alkyl halides", "amines", "carboxylic acids", "reactivity", "organic chemistry"], "real_world_example": "The hydroxyl group (-OH) in ethanol; the chloro group (-Cl) in chloromethane."}}

{"explanation": "Gases are substances in a state of matter with no fixed shape or volume. Short-chain alkanes (typically C₁ to C₄ like methane, ethane, propane, butane) are gases at room temperature.", "urdu_meaning": "گیسیں - مادے کی ایک حالت، چھوٹے الکینز گیس ہوتے ہیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Methane and propane, which are alkanes with few carbon atoms, are flammable gases commonly used as fuels.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A state of matter where particles are widely separated and move freely.", "related_concepts": ["physical state", "alkanes", "methane", "ethane", "propane", "butane", "lpg", "cng", "boiling points", "intermolecular forces"], "real_world_example": "Natural gas (mainly methane) is a mixture of gaseous alkanes."}}

{"explanation": "Gasoline is a fuel primarily used in spark-ignited internal combustion engines, consisting of a complex mixture of hydrocarbons, predominantly alkanes and cycloalkanes with 4 to 12 carbon atoms per molecule, derived from petroleum refining.", "urdu_meaning": "گیٹرولین / پیٹرول - گاڑیوں کا ایندھن، ہائیڈروکاربن کا آمیزہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The octane rating of gasoline indicates its resistance to knocking, which is related to the structure of the alkanes it contains.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A volatile, flammable liquid fuel derived from petroleum, mainly composed of C₄-C₁₂ hydrocarbons.", "related_concepts": ["fuels", "petroleum", "petroleum refining", "fractional distillation", "alkanes", "hydrocarbons", "octane rating", "combustion", "internal combustion engine"], "real_world_example": "Fuel used in most passenger cars."}}

{"explanation": "A general formula is a type of chemical formula that represents the composition of any member of an entire class of compounds. For acyclic alkanes, the general formula is CnH2n+2.", "urdu_meaning": "عمومی فارمولا - مرکبات کے ایک پورے طبقے کی ترکیب کی نمائندگی کرنے والا فارمولا", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The general formula CnH2n+2 can be used to determine the molecular formula of any straight-chain or branched alkane if the number of carbon atoms (n) is known.", "properties": {"key_principle": "An algebraic formula that describes the composition of any member of a homologous series of compounds.", "related_concepts": ["alkanes", "alkenes (CnH2n)", "alkynes (CnH2n-2)", "homologous series", "molecular formula", "stoichiometry"], "real_world_example": "For n=3 in the alkane general formula CnH2n+2, the molecular formula is C₃H₈ (propane)."}}

{"explanation": "Global Warming Potential (GWP) is a measure of how much heat a greenhouse gas traps in the atmosphere over a specific time period, relative to carbon dioxide. Methane, an alkane, has a significantly higher GWP than CO₂ over shorter timescales.", "urdu_meaning": "عالمی حدت کی صلاحیت - ایک گرین ہاؤس گیس کی حرارت قید کرنے کی صلاحیت بمقابلہ CO₂", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "Although methane has a shorter atmospheric lifetime than CO₂, its global warming potential is much higher over a 20-year period.", "properties": {"describes": "A relative measure of how much heat a greenhouse gas traps in the atmosphere compared to carbon dioxide.", "related_concepts": ["greenhouse gas", "methane", "carbon dioxide", "climate change", "greenhouse effect"], "example_of_use": "Methane's GWP is about 28-36 over 100 years (meaning it traps 28-36 times more heat per mass unit than CO₂ over that period).", "measurement_type": "Dimensionless ratio, often specified for a particular time horizon (e.g., 20 years, 100 years)."}}

{"explanation": "A greenhouse gas is an atmospheric gas that absorbs and emits infrared radiation, trapping heat. Methane (CH₄), the simplest alkane, is a potent greenhouse gas.", "urdu_meaning": "گرین ہاؤس گیس - حرارت جذب کرنے والی فضائی گیس", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Methane emissions from natural gas leaks and agriculture contribute to the overall concentration of greenhouse gas in the atmosphere.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A gas that contributes to the greenhouse effect by absorbing infrared radiation.", "related_concepts": ["methane", "carbon dioxide", "global warming potential", "climate change", "greenhouse effect", "alkanes"], "real_world_example": "CO₂, CH₄, N₂O, water vapor."}}

{"explanation": "A Grignard reagent is an organomagnesium halide (R-Mg-X) formed by reacting an alkyl or aryl halide with magnesium metal. They are powerful nucleophiles and bases used extensively in organic synthesis to form new carbon-carbon bonds, often starting from alkyl halides derived from alkanes.", "urdu_meaning": "گرینیارڈ ری ایجنٹ - ایک آرگینومیگنیشیم ہیلائیڈ، نامیاتی تالیف میں استعمال", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Grignard reagents react with aldehydes or ketones to produce alcohols, a key reaction in organic synthesis for extending carbon chains.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Organometallic compounds of magnesium (RMgX) that are strong nucleophiles and bases.", "related_concepts": ["organometallic compounds", "alkyl halides", "magnesium", "nucleophile", "carbon-carbon bond formation", "organic synthesis", "alcohols", "aldehydes", "ketones", "carboxylic acids (reaction with CO₂)"] ,"general_formula": "R-Mg-X (R=alkyl/aryl, X=Cl, Br, I)", "example_compound": "Methylmagnesium bromide (CH₃MgBr)"}}

{"explanation": "Halogenation is a chemical reaction that introduces one or more halogen atoms (F, Cl, Br, I) into a compound. Alkanes undergo free-radical halogenation in the presence of UV light to form alkyl halides.", "urdu_meaning": "ہیلوجینیشن - کسی مرکب میں ہیلوجن ایٹم شامل کرنے کا عمل", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "The halogenation of methane with chlorine yields chloromethane, dichloromethane, trichloromethane, and tetrachloromethane depending on reaction conditions.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Introduction of a halogen atom into a molecule.", "related_concepts": ["alkanes", "alkyl halides", "halogens", "chlorine", "bromine", "substitution reaction", "free-radical mechanism", "UV light"], "real_world_example": "Chlorination of methane to produce chloromethane."}}

{"explanation": "Hydrocarbons are organic compounds composed solely of carbon and hydrogen atoms. Alkanes are the simplest class of saturated hydrocarbons.", "urdu_meaning": "ہائیڈروکاربن - صرف ہائیڈروجن اور کاربن پر مشتمل نامیاتی مرکبات", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Alkanes, alkenes, and alkynes are all types of hydrocarbons, differing in their carbon-carbon bonding.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Organic molecules consisting only of carbon and hydrogen.", "related_concepts": ["alkanes", "alkenes", "alkynes", "aromatic hydrocarbons", "saturated hydrocarbons", "unsaturated hydrocarbons", "carbon", "hydrogen", "fossil fuels", "organic chemistry"], "real_world_example": "Methane (CH₄), Ethane (C₂H₆), Benzene (C₆H₆)."}}

{"explanation": "Hydrogen (H) is an element whose atoms are covalently bonded to carbon atoms in alkanes and all other hydrocarbons.", "urdu_meaning": "ہائیڈروجن - H، الکینز اور دیگر ہائیڈروکاربن کا جزو", "term_type": "element", "example_sentence": "In alkanes, each carbon atom is typically bonded to the maximum possible number of hydrogen atoms for its valency.", "properties": {"symbol": "H", "atomic_number": 1, "category": "nonmetal", "state_room_temp": "Exists as H₂ gas, but as bonded atoms in alkanes", "common_uses": ["Component of water and all organic compounds"]}}

{"explanation": "Hydrogen atoms are the atoms of hydrogen that are bonded to carbon atoms in alkane molecules, satisfying carbon's valency.", "urdu_meaning": "ہائیڈروجن ایٹم - الکین مالیکیولز میں کاربن سے جڑے ہائیڈروجن کے ایٹم", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The general formula for acyclic alkanes, CnH2n+2, indicates the number of carbon atoms and hydrogen atoms in the molecule.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Individual atoms of the element hydrogen present in organic molecules like alkanes.", "related_concepts": ["hydrogen", "alkanes", "c-h bonds", "molecular formula", "structural formula"], "real_world_example": "Propane (C₃H₈) contains eight hydrogen atoms."}}

{"explanation": "Hydrogen chloride (HCl) is a compound that can be a byproduct or reactant in some reactions involving hydrocarbons or their derivatives, though not directly formed from typical alkane reactions under normal conditions. It's a strong acid.", "urdu_meaning": "ہائیڈروجن کلورائیڈ - HCl، ایک تیزابی مرکب", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "While alkanes don't react with hydrogen chloride directly, HCl can react with alkenes via addition.", "properties": {"formula": "HCl", "molar_mass": "36.46 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas (dissolves in water to form hydrochloric acid)", "hazards": ["Corrosive gas", "Respiratory irritant"]}}

{"explanation": "Intermediate products (or intermediates) are chemical species that are formed during a multi-step reaction mechanism and then consumed in subsequent steps to form the final products. For example, free radicals are intermediates in alkane halogenation.", "urdu_meaning": "درمیانی مصنوعات - کثیر مرحلہ تعامل میں بننے اور پھر استعمال ہونے والی کیمیائی انواع", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "In the free-radical chlorination of methane, methyl radicals (CH₃•) are key intermediate products.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Transient species formed during a chemical reaction that are neither reactants nor final products.", "related_concepts": ["reaction mechanism", "transition state", "catalysis", "free radicals", "carbocations", "carbanions", "alkane halogenation"], "real_world_example": "Carbonium ions in SN1 reactions."}}

{"explanation": "Intermolecular forces (IMFs) are attractions between molecules. For alkanes, which are nonpolar, the only IMFs are weak London dispersion forces, which increase with molecular size and surface area, affecting their physical properties like boiling points.", "urdu_meaning": "بین المالیکیولی قوتیں - الکین مالیکیولز کے درمیان کمزور لندن ڈسپرشن قوتیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The relatively low boiling points of small alkanes are due to weak intermolecular forces.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Attractive forces existing between molecules.", "related_concepts": ["London dispersion forces", "alkanes", "alkane properties", "boiling points", "melting points", "viscosity", "nonpolar nature", "molecular size", "branching"], "real_world_example": "The forces that cause methane to condense into a liquid at very low temperatures."}}

{"explanation": "The IUPAC name is the systematic name assigned to a chemical compound according to the rules of the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry, ensuring unambiguous identification. Alkanes are named based on their longest carbon chain and substituent groups.", "urdu_meaning": "آئی یو پی اے سی نام - کیمیائی مرکب کا معیاری نام", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The IUPAC name for CH₃CH(CH₃)CH₂CH₃ is 2-methylbutane, which clearly defines its branched alkane structure.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A standardized chemical name assigned by IUPAC rules.", "related_concepts": ["iupac nomenclature", "alkanes", "organic compounds", "structural formula", "parent hydrocarbon", "substituent", "methyl group"], "real_world_example": "'Ethane' is the IUPAC name for C₂H₆."}}

{"explanation": "IUPAC nomenclature is the globally recognized system for naming chemical compounds, including alkanes and other organic molecules, based on their structure to avoid ambiguity.", "urdu_meaning": "آئی یو پی اے سی نام رکھنے کا نظام - کیمیائی مرکبات کے نام رکھنے کا معیاری طریقہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Understanding IUPAC nomenclature is essential for correctly identifying and communicating about specific alkane isomers.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A systematic set of rules for naming chemical compounds, established by the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry.", "related_concepts": ["iupac name", "organic chemistry", "alkanes", "alkenes", "alkynes", "functional groups", "structural isomers", "chemical formula"], "real_world_example": "The IUPAC nomenclature system allows chemists worldwide to understand the structure of a compound from its name, e.g., naming pentane and its isomers."}}

{"explanation": "The IUPAC nomenclature system provides a standardized set of rules for naming chemical substances, including alkanes, ensuring that each compound has a unique and universally understood name based on its molecular structure.", "urdu_meaning": "آئی یو پی اے سی نام رکھنے کا نظام (تفصیلی) - کیمیائی مرکبات کے نام رکھنے کا جامع معیاری طریقہ کار", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The IUPAC nomenclature system uses prefixes, suffixes, and numbering to denote the parent hydrocarbon chain, substituents, and functional groups in organic molecules like branched alkanes.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A comprehensive and systematic methodology for naming chemical compounds to achieve unambiguous global communication.", "related_concepts": ["iupac nomenclature", "iupac name", "organic compounds", "alkanes", "parent hydrocarbon", "substituent", "locants (numbers)", "prefixes", "suffixes"], "real_world_example": "Correctly applying the IUPAC nomenclature system to name complex branched alkanes or molecules with multiple functional groups."}}

{"explanation": "Kerosene is a combustible hydrocarbon liquid derived from petroleum through fractional distillation, consisting of a mixture of alkanes typically in the C₁₂ to C₁₅ range. It is used as a fuel for jet engines and lamps.", "urdu_meaning": "مٹی کا تیل / کیروسین - پیٹرولیم سے حاصل کردہ ایندھن، الکینز کا آمیزہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Kerosene, a mixture of medium-chain alkanes, has a higher boiling point range than gasoline.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A fuel fraction from petroleum refining, mainly C₁₂-C₁₅ alkanes.", "related_concepts": ["fuels", "petroleum", "fractional distillation", "alkanes", "hydrocarbons", "jet fuel", "lamp oil", "combustion"], "real_world_example": "Fuel for jet aircraft (Jet A, Jet A-1); heating and lighting fuel in some regions."}}

{"explanation": "Key differences refer to the principal distinguishing features between classes of compounds, such as between alkanes, alkenes, and alkynes (e.g., type of C-C bonds, reactivity, saturation).", "urdu_meaning": "بنیادی فرق / اہم اختلافات - مرکبات کے طبقوں کے درمیان نمایاں امتیازی خصوصیات", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The key differences between alkanes and alkenes include the presence of a double bond and higher reactivity in alkenes compared to the single bonds and relative inertness of alkanes.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Significant distinguishing characteristics when comparing chemical species or concepts.", "related_concepts": ["alkanes", "alkenes", "alkynes", "saturated hydrocarbons", "unsaturated hydrocarbons", "bonding", "reactivity", "physical properties"], "real_world_example": "A key difference between methane and ethane is the number of carbon atoms."}}

{"explanation": "Laboratory reagents are chemical substances used in laboratory experiments for analysis, synthesis, or testing. Some alkanes (e.g., hexane as a nonpolar solvent) or chemicals derived from alkanes (like alkyl halides for Grignard reagents) are used as laboratory reagents.", "urdu_meaning": "تجربہ گاہی ری ایجنٹ - تجربات میں استعمال ہونے والے کیمیائی مادے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Hexane, an alkane, is often used as a nonpolar solvent and laboratory reagent for extractions.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Chemicals used for conducting experiments and analyses in a laboratory.", "related_concepts": ["reagents", "solvents", "alkanes (e.g., hexane)", "alkyl halides", "grignard reagent", "organic synthesis", "analytical chemistry"], "real_world_example": "Concentrated sulfuric acid, sodium hydroxide pellets, organic solvents like ethanol or hexane."}}

{"explanation": "Liquids are a state of matter with a definite volume but no fixed shape. Medium-chain alkanes (roughly C₅ to C₁₇) are liquids at room temperature, such as those found in gasoline and kerosene.", "urdu_meaning": "مائعات - مادے کی ایک حالت، درمیانی زنجیر والے الکینز مائع ہوتے ہیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Alkanes like pentane and hexane are volatile liquids at room temperature.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A state of matter where particles are close together but can move past one another, taking the shape of their container.", "related_concepts": ["physical state", "alkanes", "gasoline", "kerosene", "diesel", "boiling points", "intermolecular forces"], "real_world_example": "Water, ethanol, mercury (at room temp)."}}

{"explanation": "LPG (Liquefied Petroleum Gas) is a flammable mixture of hydrocarbon gases, primarily propane (C₃H₈) and butane (C₄H₁₀), both alkanes, liquefied through pressurization and used as fuel for heating, cooking, and vehicles.", "urdu_meaning": "ایل پی جی - مائع پیٹرولیم گیس، بنیادی طور پر پروپین اور بیوٹین", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "LPG, consisting mainly of short-chain alkanes, is a convenient and portable fuel source.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Mixture of light hydrocarbon gases (mainly propane, butane) liquefied under pressure for use as fuel.", "related_concepts": ["fuels", "alkanes", "propane", "butane", "hydrocarbons", "natural gas processing", "petroleum refining", "combustion"], "real_world_example": "Gas cylinders used for cooking and heating; autogas for vehicles."}}

{"explanation": "Medicines (pharmaceuticals) are substances used to treat or prevent disease. While alkanes themselves are not typically active medicinal ingredients, hydrocarbon structures form the backbone of many medicinal compounds, and alkane-derived solvents or intermediates are used in pharmaceutical manufacturing.", "urdu_meaning": "ادویات - بیماریوں کے علاج یا روک تھام کے لیے استعمال ہونے والے مادے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The synthesis of many complex medicines involves reactions utilizing hydrocarbon frameworks, sometimes starting from alkane-derived feedstocks.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Substances with therapeutic effects used in healthcare.", "related_concepts": ["pharmaceuticals", "organic synthesis", "organic compounds", "hydrocarbons (as structural units)", "solvents", "drug discovery"], "real_world_example": "Aspirin, penicillin, various painkillers and antibiotics."}}

{"explanation": "Methane (CH₄) is the simplest alkane (one carbon atom), the main component of natural gas, a potent greenhouse gas, and a significant fuel source.", "urdu_meaning": "میتھین - CH₄، سب سے سادہ الکین", "term_type": "compound", "example_sentence": "The combustion of methane is a highly exothermic reaction, releasing energy used for heating and power generation.", "properties": {"formula": "CH₄", "molar_mass": "16.04 g/mol", "state_room_temp": "gas", "hazards": ["Highly flammable", "Greenhouse gas"]}}

{"explanation": "The parent hydrocarbon in IUPAC nomenclature is the longest continuous carbon chain (for alkanes) or the principal chain/ring containing the main functional group or unsaturation, which forms the base name of the compound.", "urdu_meaning": "بنیادی ہائیڈروکاربن - آئی یو پی اے سی نام رکھنے میں بنیادی زنجیر یا حلقہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "In naming 2-methylpentane, 'pentane' is the parent hydrocarbon, indicating a five-carbon continuous chain alkane.", "properties": {"key_principle": "The longest continuous carbon chain or main ring system that determines the root name of an organic compound.", "related_concepts": ["iupac nomenclature", "alkanes", "organic compounds", "carbon backbone", "substituent", "methyl group"], "real_world_example": "For 3-ethylhexane, 'hexane' is the parent hydrocarbon."}}

{"explanation": "Petroleum refining is the industrial process of separating crude oil (a mixture of hydrocarbons like alkanes) into various useful fractions and converting some fractions into others through processes like cracking and reforming.", "urdu_meaning": "پیٹرولیم صاف کرنا - خام تیل کو مفید مصنوعات میں تبدیل کرنے کا صنعتی عمل", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Fractional distillation is the primary step in petroleum refining to separate alkanes based on boiling point differences.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Transforming crude oil into marketable products such as fuels and chemical feedstocks.", "related_concepts": ["petroleum", "crude oil", "hydrocarbons", "alkanes", "fractional distillation", "cracking", "reforming", "gasoline", "diesel", "kerosene", "petrochemicals"], "real_world_example": "An oil refinery converting crude oil into gasoline, jet fuel, and other products."}}

{"explanation": "Physical properties of alkanes (e.g., boiling point, melting point, density, physical state, solubility) are determined by their molecular structure, size, and weak intermolecular forces (London dispersion forces).", "urdu_meaning": "طبیعی خصوصیات - الکینز کی وہ خصوصیات جو کیمیائی شناخت تبدیل کیے بغیر معلوم کی جا سکیں", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "The physical properties of alkanes, such as their insolubility in water and lower density than water, are due to their nonpolar nature.", "properties": {"describes": "Observable characteristics of alkanes that do not involve chemical change.", "related_concepts": ["alkanes", "alkane properties", "boiling points", "melting points", "density", "physical state", "solubility", "viscosity", "intermolecular forces", "nonpolar nature"], "example_of_use": "The trend of increasing boiling points with increasing carbon chain length is an important physical property of alkanes.", "measurement_type": "Various quantitative (e.g., °C, g/cm³) and qualitative assessments."}}

{"explanation": "The physical state (solid, liquid, or gas) of alkanes at room temperature depends on the number of carbon atoms: C₁-C₄ are gases, C₅-C₁₇ are liquids, and C₁₈+ are waxy solids, due to increasing intermolecular forces with size.", "urdu_meaning": "طبیعی حالت - الکینز کی ٹھوس، مائع یا گیس حالت جو کاربن ایٹموں کی تعداد پر منحصر ہے", "term_type": "property", "example_sentence": "Methane, the simplest alkane, exists in a gaseous physical state at room temperature.", "properties": {"describes": "The form (gas, liquid, solid) of alkanes under ambient conditions.", "related_concepts": ["alkanes", "alkane properties", "gases", "liquids", "solids", "number of carbon atoms", "boiling points", "melting points", "intermolecular forces"], "example_of_use": "Pentane is a liquid, while propane is a gas at room temperature.", "measurement_type": "Observation at given temperature and pressure."}}

{"explanation": "Plastics are synthetic polymers, many of which are derived from petrochemicals that originate from alkanes (via cracking to alkenes, then polymerization).", "urdu_meaning": "پلاسٹک - مصنوعی پولیمر، اکثر الکینز سے ماخوذ پیٹروکیمیکل سے بنتے ہیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Alkanes from petroleum are cracked to produce alkenes like ethene and propene, which are then polymerized to make common plastics.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Moldable polymeric materials, often synthetic and derived from petrochemicals.", "related_concepts": ["polymers", "petrochemicals", "alkanes (as source)", "alkenes (as monomers)", "polymerization", "synthetic fibers"], "real_world_example": "Polyethylene (from ethene), Polypropylene (from propene), PVC."}}

{"explanation": "Cracking is the process of breaking down large hydrocarbon molecules (long-chain alkanes) from petroleum into smaller, more useful ones (shorter-chain alkanes and alkenes) by heat (thermal cracking) or catalysts (catalytic cracking).", "urdu_meaning": "کریکنگ - بڑے ہائیڈروکاربن مالیکیولز کو چھوٹے مالیکیولز میں توڑنے کا عمل", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Cracking of heavy oil fractions is essential in petroleum refining to increase the yield of gasoline and other valuable hydrocarbons.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Thermal or catalytic decomposition of large hydrocarbon molecules into smaller ones.", "related_concepts": ["petroleum refining", "alkanes", "alkenes", "hydrocarbons", "catalytic cracking", "thermal cracking", "gasoline production", "diesel fuel", "naphtha"], "real_world_example": "Increasing the proportion of gasoline from crude oil by cracking larger alkane molecules."}}

enrichment_data: {"explanation": "Fossil fuels (crude oil, natural gas, coal) are the primary source of alkanes and other hydrocarbons, obtained through processes like fractional distillation and cracking.", "urdu_meaning": "رکازی ایندھن - الکینز اور دیگر ہائیڈروکاربن کا بنیادی ذریعہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Alkanes used as fuels and chemical feedstocks are predominantly derived from the refining of fossil fuels.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Natural fuels formed from ancient organic matter, rich in hydrocarbons.", "related_concepts": ["hydrocarbons", "alkanes", "petroleum", "natural gas", "coal", "fractional distillation", "cracking", "fuels"], "real_world_example": "Gasoline, diesel, and natural gas are all derived from fossil fuels."}}

{"explanation": "Fractional distillation is a key process in petroleum refining used to separate crude oil into different fractions (e.g., gasoline, naphtha, kerosene, diesel fuel) based on the varying boiling points of the constituent hydrocarbon molecules (mostly alkanes).", "urdu_meaning": "کسری کشید - خام تیل کو مختلف ہائیڈروکاربن حصوں میں الگ کرنے کا طریقہ", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Through fractional distillation, alkanes of different chain lengths are separated from crude oil to produce fuels and chemical feedstocks.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Separation of a liquid mixture into fractions based on differences in boiling points.", "related_concepts": ["petroleum refining", "crude oil", "alkanes", "hydrocarbons", "boiling points", "gasoline", "diesel fuel", "naphtha"], "real_world_example": "Refining crude oil in an oil refinery."}}

{"explanation": "Fuels are substances combusted to produce energy. Alkanes, such as methane, propane, butane, gasoline, and diesel fuel components, are widely used as fuels and are obtained from fossil fuels or synthesized.", "urdu_meaning": "ایندھن - توانائی پیدا کرنے کے لیے جلائے جانے والے مادے", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The efficient production of alkane-based fuels from petroleum is vital for transportation and energy generation.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Materials that release energy upon chemical or nuclear transformation.", "related_concepts": ["alkanes", "hydrocarbons", "fossil fuels", "combustion", "gasoline", "diesel fuel", "methane", "propane", "energy"], "real_world_example": "Natural gas for heating, gasoline for cars."}}

{"explanation": "Gasoline is a fuel primarily composed of a mixture of volatile liquid hydrocarbons (mainly alkanes and cycloalkanes with C₄-C₁₂ chains), produced by petroleum refining processes like fractional distillation and catalytic cracking.", "urdu_meaning": "گیٹرولین / پیٹرول - گاڑیوں کا ایندھن، ہائیڈروکاربن کا آمیزہ", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "The catalytic cracking of long-chain alkanes from heavier petroleum fractions increases gasoline production.", "properties": {"key_principle": "A volatile, flammable liquid fuel for spark-ignition engines, derived from petroleum.", "related_concepts": ["fuels", "petroleum refining", "fractional distillation", "catalytic cracking", "alkanes", "hydrocarbons", "octane rating"], "real_world_example": "Fuel used in most cars."}}

{"explanation": "Gasoline production involves refining crude oil through processes like fractional distillation to isolate existing alkanes and catalytic cracking or reforming to convert other hydrocarbon fractions into gasoline-range alkanes and aromatics.", "urdu_meaning": "گیٹرولین کی پیداوار - خام تیل سے گیٹرولین بنانے کا عمل", "term_type": "process", "example_sentence": "Catalytic cracking of heavy alkanes is a crucial step in modern gasoline production to meet demand.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Industrial processes for manufacturing gasoline from crude oil.", "related_concepts": ["gasoline", "petroleum refining", "fractional distillation", "catalytic cracking", "reforming", "alkanes", "hydrocarbons"], "real_world_example": "Operations in an oil refinery focused on producing high-octane gasoline."}}

Alkyl halides contain one or more halogen atoms bonded to an alkyl group, and these can be reduced to alkanes.", "urdu_meaning": "ہیلوجن ایٹم - گروپ 17 کا ایک عنصر کا ایٹم", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "In an alkyl halide, the carbon atom bonded to the halogen atom is the site of reaction in many reduction processes to form alkanes.", "properties": {"key_principle": "An atom of a halogen element (F, Cl, Br, I, At).", "related_concepts": ["halogens", "alkyl halides", "reduction", "electronegativity"], "real_world_example": "The chlorine atom in chloromethane."}}

{"explanation": "Hydrocarbon classes categorize hydrocarbons based on their structure and bonding, including alkanes (saturated, single bonds), alkenes (C=C double bonds), alkynes (C≡C triple bonds), and aromatic hydrocarbons (cyclic, delocalized pi systems).", "urdu_meaning": "ہائیڈروکاربن کے طبقات - ہائیڈروکاربن کی درجہ بندی بلحاظ ساخت اور بندھن", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "Alkanes represent one of the fundamental hydrocarbon classes, serving as a reference for understanding others like alkenes and alkynes.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Classification of hydrocarbons based on types of carbon-carbon bonds and structure.", "related_concepts": ["hydrocarbons", "alkanes", "alkenes", "alkynes", "aromatic hydrocarbons", "saturated hydrocarbons", "unsaturated hydrocarbons"], "real_world_example": "Differentiating between propane (alkane), propene (alkene), and propyne (alkyne)."}}

{"explanation": "Hydrogenation is a chemical reaction involving the addition of hydrogen (H₂) to a molecule, typically to reduce unsaturated C=C or C≡C bonds in alkenes or alkynes to C-C single bonds, thus forming alkanes. {"explanation": "Industrial settings are environments where large-scale manufacturing and chemical processes occur, such as petroleum refineries where alkanes are processed (cracked, distilled) and synthesized (e.g., via some reforming processes).", "urdu_meaning": "صنعتی ماحول - وہ جگہیں جہاں بڑے پیمانے پر پیداوار اور کیمیائی عمل ہوتے ہیں", "term_type": "concept", "example_sentence": "In industrial settings, catalytic cracking is performed at high temperatures to convert heavy alkanes into more useful products.", "properties": {"key_principle": "Locations and environments associated with large-scale industrial production.", "related_concepts": ["industrial applications", "petroleum industry", "petroleum refining", "chemical plants", "catalysis", "reactors"], "real_world_example": "An oil refinery or a chemical manufacturing plant."}}
